PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs confirm that an Aboriginal alcohol counsellor has been employed by the Central Gippsland Aboriginal Advancement Co-operative for 18 months under a special works project grant? Can the Minister explain why the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has refused to provide funding for a permanent position of alcohol counsellor at the Central Gippsland service and for full time counsellors at Shepparton and East Gippsland? Is the Minister aware that this refusal is undermining the Aboriginal health services in these areas because there are no resources to attack the major basic health problem of alcohol?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will not be surprised to know that, among the many briefs I bring into the Senate, I do not have one containing detailed information of what is going on in the Central Gippsland service. I can advise the honourable senator that, about a year ago, a very constructive arrangement was made between Victoria and the Commonwealth whereby Victoria gave up to the Commonwealth much of its States grants funding in the area of Aboriginal health. The Commonwealth then reapplied that same money to set up, as the honourable senator knows, a number of Aboriginal medical services including the service at, I think, the Rumbalara Aboriginal community in the Shepparton area. In fact, I have visited that service and seen it in operation.

ANSWER.PARA: Negotiations as to what the staffing levels should be have involved the Victorians, the Commonwealth and the Aboriginal groups. I understood that arrangements were made which were satisfactory to the parties. Those arrangements may not have included the entire establishment that was sought but they were enough to get the services started. I also know that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, to try to assist organisations to take on board extra staff members, uses a number of other mechanisms such as special works projects to provide extra funding capacity on a temporary basis.

The honourable senator asks whether the funding arrangement which she describes is in any way inhibiting the work that needs to be done in alcohol counselling in the area. I will refer that to the Minister whom I represent. I would emphasise once again that what has gone on in Victoria with the provision and promotion of Aboriginal controlled Aboriginal medical services is really a model for what is possible in other parts of the country. I will take the question on board against that kind of background, which is a background of achievement and progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. What effect is the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's recent ruling, that ability to pay be allowable grounds for pay rise exemptions, likely to have as a precedent in the wage fixing system and on employment? Has the Government evaluated the guidelines that apply in these situations?
—I am not personally aware of any such evaluation. I will ask Mr Macphee to examine the matter raised by the honourable senator and to let him have a reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. The Government continually claims that there has been a 17 per cent increase in the average national wage over the past six months in an attempt to justify a wages freeze and place the burden on the wage earner. I ask the Minister: Are these figures not misleading? To illustrate my point I give the Senate the following example: A is an unskilled worker on $200 a week, B is a semi-skilled worker on $300 a week and C is a professional on $400 a week. Their average weekly pay is $300. A is the most likely to become unemployed, so the average weekly wage of B and C is $350, or a statistical increase of $50. Similarly, the employers of B and C are not paying out more, neither has their standard of living risen because of the supposed $50 a week increase since A became unemployed. In actual fact, prices have probably risen on the basis of this supposed weekly increase, so the purchasing power of wages is less. Because these figures can be manipulated, is it not dishonest of the Government to seek wages restraint and wages freezes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is certainly not dishonest of the Government to seek to overcome the difficulties that many people are suffering with their employment prospects. The wages pause that has been suggested by the Government is one of the ways in which we may be able to redress the shedding of employment . What the Government said at the outset was that there should be a pause in award wages. I think we have had several discussions about the 17 per cent increase in certain wages during the year. It is acknowledged that certain wage earners have received that level of increase and others have not.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not taken note in detail of the figures that Senator Elstob produced this morning. I think there is a fair consensus around the community that the wage increases over the past year, two years or three years have meant that increasingly the profitability of employers has not been maintained or improved and they are unable to continue providing employment. I think, if there is a realistic look at the level of wages, the wage demands and the effect that they have on employment, then consideration could honestly be given to whether a wages pause for a period would be helpful. That is precisely what it is proposed will be done at the meeting of the Premiers on 7 December. I think we should await the outcome of those discussions before we go along with the proposals that are obviously attractive to the Opposition parliamentary party but not necessarily to the rest of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the $550,000m lent to underdeveloped countries and the $80 ,000m lent to communist countries by the Western world's 31 largest international banks, most of which now have had to reschedule those debts because of the inability of those countries to meet their commitments. I ask: Is the Government monitoring this problem to ensure that Australian banks are not sucked into a global collapse of banks? What percentage of Australian banking funds are invested in overseas international banks? Are Australian banks in any way insulated against the collapse of one or more of these overseas international banks. If so, how? Is the Minister satisfied that Australian investment in overseas banks is only with banks which are owned or guaranteed by their governments? I indicate to Senator McLaren that I have given notice of the question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian authorities keep a close watch on developments in the international money and capital markets and assess their implications for the depositors of Australian banks. It is not accurate to suggest that the rescheduling by some countries of their debts is likely to lead to a global collapse of banks. Each of the major Australian banks has assets in Australia considerably in excess of its deposit liabilities in Australia. Australian banks' holdings of overseas assets, including claims on international banks, are funded almost entirely by borrowings abroad. In managing their international banking business, Australian banks limit their exposures to any one international bank or borrower. As part of its prudential supervision of Australian banks, the Reserve Bank in conformity with its depositor protection responsibility consults with the banks about their management practices. Within the above framework Australian banks do not confine their placements or loans to banks which are either government-owned or government-guaranteed. Of course, it will be appreciated that not all Australian banks have a government guarantee.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, concerns the Government's continuing evasion of its obligations to the people of East Timor. Did the Minister for Foreign Affairs say that it was time the international community put the Timor question behind it and looked at the future constructively and positively? Did the Minister go on to say that the best way to help the East Timorese now is to work through the Indonesian authorities? If so, what action has the Federal Government taken to persuade the Indonesian Government to help the people of East Timor or even to allow Australian assistance to be passed through to those people? Further, how does the Government justify now its complete and continuing disregard of what the Timorese people plainly want-the right to self- determination?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The question started with some quotes from the Minister for Foreign Affairs. On 20 November he did comment that the Government believed it was now time for the international community to put the Timor question behind it and to look to the future constructively and positively. In this regard the Australian Government's position accords with that put recently in the United Nations Fourth Committee by a former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam. Since 1978 the Government's view has been that, as Indonesia is in effective control of East Timor, United Nations resolutions on East Timor have been both unrealistic and impractical. The overwhelming majority of countries in the Asia- Pacific region oppose the United Nations resolution questioning Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor. Support for that proposition is now confined to less than one-third of the United Nations membership. The Minister for Foreign Affairs said in his statement of 20 November that the Government hoped that the number of countries opposing it would be increased when the resolution on East Timor was voted on in plenary session of the United Nations General Assembly this week. This in fact occurred, with four more countries voting against it.

ANSWER.PARA: We have discussed this matter in this place on a number of occasions. It has been said by the Government in many of the comments made by the Foreign Minister that the only realistic way in which to help the people of East Timor is to work through the Indonesian authorities. The Government has provided over $6m in humanitarian relief and development assistance since 1975, and the Government also attaches importance to the reunification of families separated by events in the province. The suggestions made by Senator Mason in his question I think ignore the reality of the fact that the Government of Indonesia has the responsibility with regard to the people of East Timor and that to work with it is the best way in which we can assist those people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. The Minister has not quite answered my question, with respect to her. I would like from her on behalf of the Government a plain statement as to whether this Government of Australia agrees or does not agree that there should be some act of self-determination amongst the people of East Timor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have nothing to add to what I have already said. The Australian Government regards the position with regard to Indonesia's attitudes to and sovereignty over East Timor to be as has been stated. To suggest that this Government ought to be taking the steps suggested by Senator Mason ignores the debates that have been held and the statements made and the position that undoubtedly exists between Indonesia and East Timor.

—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Today's edition of the Sun-News Pictorial reports that a gallup poll indicates that 65 per cent of Australians favour a wages freeze, with 31 per cent opposed and 4 per cent undecided. The poll was conducted over two weekends this month during the period the three Labor Premiers met in Melbourne. The poll indicated, too, that the majority of supporters of the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Australian Labor Party favoured a pay freeze. In view of the poll what is the Government's attitude to the poll and what future action is contemplated by government in regard to the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all honourable senators will be thoroughly interested in the poll that has been taken. It shows that a substantial majority of people of all political parties and a substantial majority of all Australians favour a wages freeze. Indeed, a significant number-there was an unqualified question on this-favour a wages freeze.
—With a prices freeze.

—There was no question of a prices freeze at all. The question was: 'Do you favour a wages freeze?' The result was that 65 per cent said yes; 31 per cent said no; and 4 per cent did not know. Incidentally, of those, 58 per cent of Labor voters said yes, 38 per cent said no; and 61 per cent of Australian Democrats voters said yes, 34 per cent said no. The fact of the matter is that this is overwhelming. I think that, more importantly still, one should look at the Age newspaper of this morning and the very significant paragraph which says:

ANSWER.PARA: At a time when the average Australian is coming to realise, often through unhappy personal experience, that direct links do exist between excess wage rises, falling corporate profits and disappearing jobs, it is distressing that the nation's current alternative Prime Minister-
That is Mr Hayden-
appears unable to accept this reality or the necessary consequences that flow from it.
The article goes on to say:
Mr Hayden and the Federal shadow Cabinet are persisting with, even strengthening, their opposition to the Fraser Government's proposed wages freeze .

I said some days ago that there was a growing consensus in Australia that the Government's move for a wages freeze for a year was right. Nothing could emphasise that more than the very substantial support in all sections of the community-men and women, members of all political parties. Now the only people out of step in the regiment are the members of the Labor Party. I said last week how important it is that at a time when the country is losing employment, when that is being caused by high wages, there should be a consensus in Australia. In fact, for the Labor Party to be pursuing the negative attitude against the mainstream of Australians is to be destructive and, indeed, to contribute to disemployment. I once again suggest to members of the Labor Party that the sensible approach is to join with the public who want this consensus to get a wages freeze, to get on with the job, to stop the haemorrhage of employment in Australia and to get on with the job to make sure that one man's pay rise is not another man's job. That is what a former Labor Treasurer said. That is what Labor recognised in the past. That is what the people of Australia are saying now. The only people resisting this now are the members of the Opposition in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry follows in a sense the answer which Senator Sir John Carrick just gave and in which he indicated who was responsible for unemployment. My question relates to who is responsible for inflation. I ask: Has the Government agreed to lift dairy industry equalisation levies by 5 per cent? Will this decision result in an increase in the retail price of dairy products by the same amount? Is official disclosure of this decision being delayed until after the Premiers Conference on 7 December? Why has the Government suppressed this news while it is vigorously promoting a wage freeze?

—The position with respect to dairy products is that in accordance with statutory marketing arrangements the Australian Dairy Corporation, after consultation with the Australian Dairy Industry Advisory Committee, sought the approval of the Minister for Primary Industry for levy rate increases. The Government considered the recommendations of the Australian Dairy Corporation against the background of the commercial criteria which are taken into account in the determination of levy rates and hence domestic bulk wholesale prices. On that basis it was considered that the proposed increases were justified. Indeed, this is basically a commercial judgment which is made by the dairy industry. I do not believe, although I will have to check it, that any requests of this sort have ever been refused. Like other price increases, they are subject to the discipline of the market and to the fact that, if increases are excessive, of course, consumption will reduce.
—But they are not.

—In the sense that consumption will be affected, they certainly are affected by the market. There has been an approval of that rise although the rates will apply a month later than was actually sought by the industry. The Government has asked the Industries Assistance Commission to undertake an inquiry into the dairy industry. As part of the inquiry, it can be expected that the operation of the dairy industry marketing and pricing arrangements, including the procedures for the determination of the stabilisation levies and the appropriateness of the criteria used in the formulation of domestic prices, will be subject to detailed public examination.

—I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether that answer to my question is a formal announcement of the Government's decision. If not, when is it intended that the decision will be announced by the Minister?

—The decision was considered by the Government very recently. As is normal procedure, no public statement was made in respect of the decision because it was subject to Executive Council consideration. Honourable senators will be aware that in those circumstances the decision is not finally taken until the Governor-General has agreed to the matter put to him in Executive Council. This was done on 23 November and I am advised that the Corporation was told of the changes early on 24 November, which was yesterday.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Minister noted an article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald in which the writer, under the heading 'Asians challenge Antarctica ''club'' ', claims that pressure is mounting from several Third World states in Asia to strip Australia and six other countries of their territorial claims to Antarctica and to internationalise the vast polar continent? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Department of Foreign Affairs has any knowledge of this alleged pressure and whether any approaches on this issue were made to Australia by any of the Third World countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer that matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for his response.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce seen a publication of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia entitled 'Housing Australia: Let's get to Work' in which it is claimed that $100m would create 8,150 jobs in the home building industry? In view of the unemployment crisis and the housing shortage, will the Government consider as a matter of urgency allocating more finance to the housing industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the particular report but I am, of course, aware of the fact that the housing industry is a large employer of labour and that expenditure in that area is likely to produce a very useful employment result. It was precisely that thinking, and the knowledge that there was a predicted reduction in private investment, that led the Government to alter significantly its approach to the welfare housing industry at the time of the last Premiers Conference. Honourable senators will remember that at the time of the Premiers Conference the Commonwealth announced that this year it would make available an increase in funds to the States of some 27 per cent. In addition, it was indicated to the States that, if they chose to increase their housing effort, they could receive additional parts of the works and housing loans at the concessional rate which applies under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: I am delighted to say that those Commonwealth initiatives have resulted in a substantial increase in the public housing effort in Australia this year. I speak from memory, but I think that the expenditure on public housing by all governments last year was about $650m. It will be in excess of $900m this year. In Victoria, where there is the largest single increase, the offer that the Commonwealth made was taken advantage of substantially. A very large additional part of the Victorian works and housing moneys was sought and obtained at the concessional rate under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. In recent communications that I have had with Mr Cathie, the Victorian Minister of Housing , he has acknowledged that the large housing package which was announced by Victoria was made possible by the combined policies of the Commonwealth, with its increase to Victoria and its freeing up of those votes, and the determination of the Victorian Government to see an increased effort in that area.

The position is that, in light of the pending economic conditions that were seen in the middle of this year, additional effort was made in the welfare housing area. That has produced a welcome lift in activity in that area around Australia. It remains to be seen what success the Commonwealth will have in getting the States to join with it in the proposed wage pause. It is the earnest hope of the Commonwealth Government that by getting co-operative action between the Commonwealth and the States we shall free up some resources which can be directed into areas which will be employment creating. In that event, I have little doubt that the Commonwealth Government and State governments will give very careful consideration to welfare housing as one of the possible areas for increased activity which would have both beneficial social effects and beneficial employment effects.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to a report in yesterday's Melbourne Age under the heading '12 months too long a pause says Chamber'. Does the Minister not agree with the Director of the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures, Mr Brian Powell, that a 12-month wage pause would reduce real wages by too much too quickly? Also does the Minister not agree with Mr Powell that the average worker cannot be expected to take a 12 per cent real wage cut at present? Can the Minister tell the Senate what effect a 12 per cent cut in real wages would have on consumer spending?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am aware of some of the comments of the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures. I cannot agree with what seems to be a conclusion that it has drawn, namely, that a 12-month freeze would be too much too quickly. Unless there is some change in the way in which the employment prospects of average wage earners are being dealt with, it will not be a case of having a 12 per cent reduction in wages; it may be a loss of jobs. Some people have been saying that one man's rise is another man's job. I think it is probably reaching nearer to the stage where a rise is that man's own job, and not someone else's job. So, unless realistically we are able to get a better relationship between wage levels and profitability, employment prospects will simply worsen. If the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures has some views, no doubt they can be put and considered in the proper forum.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not only manufacturing industry which would be affected by any such pause . It is hoped that any pause that occurs will reach the wider section of the Australian community, the public sector and the private sector, and not only those engaged in manufacturing. If there were some sort of decline in the level of wages, of course one would expect that that would flow through to bring about a reduction in the level of inflation. It is not sensible to look at one aspect of the economic effects of a wage pause and to suggest that, because people are earning something less than they may have hoped to earn over the next 12-month period, by virtue of that there would be an equal loss in demand. What we are looking at is the employment level. It is not a matter of saying that employment is static and that whatever one may reduce wages by will be the only effect on the economy. What we are hoping to achieve out of this is better employment prospects and ultimately a reduction in inflation. Unless one puts all those factors into the mix about which we are talking one cannot draw the conclusions that have been drawn by the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS: RESEARCH FACILITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen an article written by Professor T. B. Millar, who is an academic specialist in foreign affairs at the Australian National University, and published in the Australian Foreign Affairs Record, the Department's own magazine, in which he claims that the quality of information on which foreign policy is based is inadequate and that a major problem is that in the Department there is very little in the way of an institutionalised memory with information easily retrievable? Further he made the comparison that this Parliament has more facility for research advice on foreign policy than the Department. Will the Minister study Professor Millar's remarks and confirm the Government's confidence in the research and analytical abilities of the Department of Foreign Affairs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the article to which Senator Teague referred. From what he said there seems to be a fairly general comment by Professor Millar with regard to resource information in the Department of Foreign Affairs. I am sure that any defects in information collection or retrieval will have the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I am not able to comment on whether what has been stated by the professor in his article in the Australian Foreign Affairs Record is an accurate statement of the way in which information is provided and retained in the Department. I will refer that question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether he has any comment that he wishes to make or whether he is able to advise of any changes that may be in contemplation.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction. Is it a fact that the Government has overcharged international airlines by $55m? If so, what factors have contributed to this overcharging? What steps does the Government intend to take to deal with the claims of the international airlines?

—Senator Ray gave no authority for the statement that he made in relation to overcharging by the Government of $55m. I have no information on this matter. I am afraid that the honourable senator did not draw our attention to any material on the fact. I would need to research that matter, and I undertake to do so.

—Can the Minister for Social Security advise what is the average delay in Queensland between the lodgment of an appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal against the rejection of a claim for an invalid pension and the hearing of that appeal? Does the Minister consider that there has been a reasonable delay when an appeal which was lodged on 26 November last year will be heard today?

—I will be able to get the figure asked for by the honourable senator, but my general answer would be that the average delay has been longer than it should have been. There are two reasons for that. The first is that we have had some difficulties with respect to primary decision making; in other words, we think there have been more difficult decisions than we would like. That matter has been addressed very carefully by us. The second reason is that there have been some difficulties-more so in New South Wales than in Queensland- in maintaining an adequate flow of appeals. A great deal of attention has been given to both those areas. I would expect to see very significant improvements. I will give the precise figure requested as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware that New Zealand butter is being sold to Hong Kong for approximately $1, 514 per tonne? Does this price directly compete with Australia's Daisy brand by undercutting our price by some $500 per tonne? Will the Minister raise this matter urgently with the Minister for Trade and Resources on the grounds that New Zealand's action to increase its market share in a non-commercial manner will prejudice the agreements reached in the dairy industries of both countries pending closer economic relations?
—Yes, I will raise that matter with the Minister for Trade and Resources.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to a statement by the Prime Minister quoted in the National Times of 4 November 1978. The Prime Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: Employment creation schemes . . . increased Government spending of $300m or $ 400m-
Which was exactly what the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet wanted-
could reduce private investment and consumer spending by much more than that.
He went on to say:
That, I believe, is a bad bargain. It is not one that my Government will entertain.

Is the Government still of the opinion that transferring funds from the private sector to be spent by the public sector is bad economics? Is this not what the Government is attempting to do by its current wage freeze proposal? Has the Government been advised by other than meretricious players of the advisory stage that its attempts at draining the pockets of Australian wage and salary earners through a wages freeze in order to fund public works will deepen the recession by decreasing the spending power of individual consumers? Finally, does not this obvious inconsistency in Government policy indicate that the Government, after seven years in office, still has no clear economic direction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly the people of Australia believe that the Government has a clear economic direction because the gallup poll of supporters of all parties shows that what the Government is aiming to do has the overwhelming support-two to one support-of Australians. I commend that opinion and I commend also the comments of the Press in this regard. I repeat that there is a very substantial consensus now in Australia that what the Government is trying to do is right. I do not know what the full text of the November 1978 article is and I would need to read it. Senator Bolkus is calling for job creation by inflating the deficit, just as in the case of the Regional Employment Development Scheme, but the Government holds the view that anything that simply seeks to create money by inflating the deficit, therefore inflating paper money, will do what Mr Hayden said it would do. Mr Hayden said that that device would create more unemployment. So I commend Senator Bolkus to a reading of his own leader's premise that we cannot solve this matter by inflating deficits. Inflation of the deficit would do the very reverse of what is being sought-it would create more inflation and more unemployment.
—You have a Budget of stagnation.

—No matter what members of the Australian Labor Party say, they cannot get away from the fact that that was its official text in government. That was a statement made by Mr Hayden, as Treasurer, and the premise on which he brought down his final Budget. In other words, he basically said that the kind of things that he and Mr Hawke are now advocating are wrong, that they will create inflation and that they will create unemployment. So the commentators throughout the media are saying at the moment, and so they are condemning that action. What we are seeking to do-I repeat that it is now supported by the substantial majority of the Australian community and political parties-is to get wage restraint because the increase of some 17 per cent to 18 per cent in wages in the past year has been recognised by all authorities as being the main reason for the shedding of employment, the main reason that Australia's inflation today is higher than that of our trading partners, and the reason that we cannot trade outwards. That is basically being accepted as the case. We are seeking first of all to get wage restraint and then, if we get that wage restraint, the money saved at Federal, State and local government levels and at the commerce, industrial and service levels can be used to maintain and to increase employment. In other words, there would be no new creation of money by inflating the deficit; it would be the same money. Of course that would be a full acceptance of Mr Crean's principle that one man's wage increase is another man's job.

ANSWER.PARA: As honourable senators can see, these statements which were made by former Ministers of the Australian Labor Party strongly support what the Government is now aiming to do, in the same way as the public supports what the Government is aiming to do. Quite clearly, what we are aiming to do is the sensible thing. We are not trying to create more money by inflating the deficit for this purpose. We are trying to rearrange the expenditure of money to slow down and stop the shedding of employment, to bring about a conversion of loss-making into some minor profitability which holds people in employment, and to have money to do some public works and create more employment. I would have thought that that was so eminently sane, having now been accepted by the great majority of the community, that the continued opposition by honourable senators in the Labor Party can only be regarded as utterly destructive and indeed un-Australian. When the bulk of the Australian people recognises that one man's wage increase is another man's job and the Australian Labor Party is now resisting that premise, the Labor Party is taking a negative and destructive attitude and must continue to have the condemnation of the community and of the media that is now occurring .

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. It was reported this morning that powerful groups within the Australian Council of Trade Unions will attempt to use industrial muscle to put up additional trade barriers. The stated justification is to increase employment in Australia. What is the Government's assessment of the effects on employment of a reduction in trade?

—I suppose that the presence of Mr Anthony at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade meeting and the views which have been put forward on behalf of Australia at that meeting are the best answer to the question which has been put by the honourable senator. I think it was yesterday during Question Time that I pointed out that a country like Australia, with an economy so heavily geared to international trade, is a country which has a very strong interest in maintaining international trade. The restrictions which are likely during periods of economic adversity are certainly not in Australia's interests. As far as that part of the question relating to the use of industrial muscle is concerned, I cannot think of anything less likely to encourage economic activity in Australia than industrial anarchy. The sort of suggestion which apparently has been floated around that there should be some form of trade union action to prevent imports seems to me to be just a form of industrial anarchy of the sort which can only damage Australia's interest and damage the employment prospects of many Australians. I hope that that suggestion will be put aside by the trade union movement and indeed rejected by all honourable senators in this Senate as a sensible course of action.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that helpful guidelines for Social Security Appeals Tribunal appellants and those who assist them are available in at least one State? Does the document say that, while as a general rule the Tribunal does not permit legal representation at hearings, the Tribunal does have the discretion to allow legal representation in some circumstances-for instance, where it is essential in the appellant's interests? Is this modification of what was previously understood as a strict no-lawyers rule nationwide? If so, why has the Minister not made sure that this modification has been made more widely known in fairness to appellants? Will he make sure that the Social Security Appeals Tribunal guidelines to which I have referred are published for the benefit of people in all States? Further, will he make sure that the policy of supplying an appellant with the case of the Department of Social Security before the hearing, whether or not the appellant is represented by an advocate, is strictly adhered to?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a developing area in the Department's activities. Recently there was a national meeting at which representatives of the SSATs got together to look at some of the issues which have arisen with respect to their operation. Honourable senators would know that recommendations have been made by the Administrative Review Council with respect to possible alternative approaches to appeals within the Department of Social Security. The whole area is one which is receiving careful consideration, both within the Department and in consultations between me and the Department. I will take up the points raised by the honourable senator with respect to uniform practice. We have before us at the moment a series of recommendations from that national meeting. They are matters to which I am giving attention. I hope from that will flow guidelines which will ensure that appellants around Australia do receive even treatment.

ANSWER.PARA: I stress for those honourable senators who are not particularly familiar with the operation of Social Security Appeals Tribunals that they are essentially administrative bodies. They do not have a separate legal existence. Indeed, that is one of the criticisms which is made of them. A recommendation from the SSAT- it does not make the decision itself-which leads to a decision adverse to an appellant gives rise to a right to a formal legal appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Of course, persons going to that formal appeal structure all are entitled to be represented by counsel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Education to a recent speech by Professor Bill Ford, head of the organisational behaviour department at the University of New South Wales, in which he claimed that Australia is ' racing rapidly towards being an unskilled, untrained, under educated Third World country'. Is it correct, as alleged by Professor Ford, that only about 35 per cent of Australians completed 12 years of schooling as compared with 92 per cent of Japanese and, leaving aside hairdressing, approximately only 2 per cent of Australian school leavers are apprenticed? Does the Minister agree that we should stop being complacent about unemployment and look to nations such as Japan and West Germany which have made a massive commitment to training people at all levels as examples of how unemployment problems could be dealt with? If this is so, I ask: Firstly, what action is currently being taken by the Government in an effort to educate Australian people to cope with the age of high technology? Secondly, will there be a fundamental shift in the Government's education and employment policies in an effort to achieve a highly skilled work force both to meet the challenges of high technology and to help alleviate our growing unemployment problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The goals which Senator Missen has set out for education are goals which the Government shares and which it is pursuing. I have read a paper given by Professor Bill Ford at the conference of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science. I am not sure whether that is the paper to which Senator Missen is referring. It would not matter because Professor Ford makes his points in the paper he gave to ANZAAS. What he is really calling for is the development of a national pool of skills larger than that which we have at present.

ANSWER.PARA: Some of the figures given by Senator Missen I think are only partly correct; certainly they need some amplification. The completion rate to year 12 in Australia is 30 per cent for government schools, 65 per cent for government schools in the Australian Capital Territory, 45 per cent for schools in the Catholic system and 85 per cent for other independent schools. So it varies between different groups of schools. It is fair to say, however, that we want a much higher rate of participation to year 12. That, in turn, would involve in the schools curriculum a variety of offerings more acceptable and more appropriate to the needs of a larger number of students. While schools concentrate unduly on an academic stream a number of students will make very sensible decisions that that is not for them and they will withdraw at an appropriate stage.

I must say to Senator Missen that a lot of work is going on as to how we approach this question of the best way for a Commonwealth Government, with a quite satisfactory retention rate in its school system, to try to influence its colleagues in the States who run their own systems if we think some change is needed both in the offerings and in the approach, particularly to senior schooling. They might even try to do some of the things we have done in the Australian Capital Territory with senior colleges or try other means by which a more flexible and acceptable schooling stream may eventuate.

Senator Missen also made some comment about apprenticeships. In fact, apprenticeship has been a major area for post-secondary placement for males in Australia. It is still a quite significant area. The honourable senator mentioned a very low figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two per cent.

—I think the actual rate is higher than that, but I will try to get the exact figures for the honourable senator. I still think that something like 30 per cent of males in the age cohort 15 to 19 years head towards apprenticeship. I think the honourable senator will find that the figure quoted is unduly low.

ANSWER.PARA: One point to make about international comparisons, which was another part of Senator Missen's question, is that it is quite difficult in some international comparisons to know whether we are comparing like with like. The definition of what constitutes full time employment varies between countries. For example, some countries might include trade training as being in full time education. Given a certain structure of education, that might be an appropriate way of measuring involvement in certain countries. In Australia we regard trade training through apprenticeship as being in the work force. The international comparison figures therefore have to be understood and analysed with some care in order that one makes appropriate judgments and comparisons. Nevertheless, we would like to see higher participation rates in schooling to the end of year 12 and in higher education, and we would like to continue to enhance the contribution which is being made through TAFE-technical and further education- particularly in the higher technology areas, to develop the kinds of outcomes to which the honourable senator referred to his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I ask: Is it a fact that 13 of the Navy's 19 Tracker aircraft at Nowra in New South Wales are in mothballs? Is it also a fact that while these planes and their highly trained crews are idle the Government is hiring private aircraft for naval duties? Were two Piper Aztec aircraft hired last month from a Melbourne company which has been in receivership since August? Did Royal Australian Navy personnel have to repair faults in door locks, radio equipment and other parts of these hired planes before they could fly?
—Obviously Senator Button is seeking a great deal of detailed information which is not available to me. I will refer the question to the Minister for Defence.

—I direct a question to the Minister Assisting the Treasurer. To what extent is the Government concerned about the underwriting losses of $430m in the general insurance business for the calendar year 1981, as reported in the Insurance Commissioner's most recent annual report? Is the Minister aware that these losses are almost double those of the previous year? Can the Minister assure the Senate that the assets of general insurance companies are invested under supervision similar to that exercised over the investments of life insurance companies? Can the Minister also assure the Senate that there are no general insurance companies with major or controlling shareholdings in companies whose business could easily endanger the security that policy-holders may expect ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can say that the Government is concerned about the considerable losses that are occurring in the general insurance industry. In fact the Insurance Commissioner's report which was presented to the Senate last week clearly indicated the situation in the industry and gives rise to considerable concern. The major point is that insurance companies are losing substantially on general insurance business and are required to offset those losses with investment income. The point to which Senator Archer leads us is that the security of those investments is therefore paramount in retaining the stability of the insurance industry as a whole. Those matters are very much in the forefront of the Government's mind and, in particular, the mind of the Insurance Commissioner who has the duty to scrutinise and to monitor the performance of insurance companies on a regular basis.

ANSWER.PARA: There are numerous methods by which this is undertaken. I can, of course, obtain more detailed information for Senator Archer in respect of that matter. But suffice to say that the Government is aware of the difficulties and is taking steps from time to time to ensure that the security of policyholders is maintained at the highest possible level. I point out that at present within the House of Representatives awaiting debate is a Bill put forward by the Government which seeks to safeguard further the rights of policyholders and to impose certain responsibilities upon insurers to maintain the highest possible levels of security in their investment strategies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the FA18 program will proceed? Can the Minister indicate whether the contract for the purchase of the FA18 includes provisions for Australian withdrawal if the aircraft does not meet the requirements specified at the time of contract? Does the Government intend to continue current expenditure and preparation for the manufacture of the FA18 while the future production of the aircraft is in doubt? Does the present contract provide for compensation payments to the Australian Government and private firms involved in the Australian industry participation program for accrued costs arising from the production contracts should production of the aircraft not be approved by the Congress of the United States of America?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked a question in connection with the current evaluation program going forward in relation to the FA18. I made the point then that there had been considerable concern in the Press and in other places, particularly in the Senate in recent times, about reports that the United States Navy had had difficulty in assessing the FA18 to its fullest and highest level of concern, for its own purposes. Earlier, in response to Senator Robert Ray, I had indicated that in fact there were considerable differences between aircraft required for service on aircraft carriers by the United States Navy and those which might be used by the Royal Australian Air Force in relation to land-based activity. On those particular matters, I believe that the evaluation test which the Australian Air Force is currently undertaking will investigate very closely all claims of any deficiencies in relation to the FA18. But as I indicated yesterday, at this stage the Australian Government is satisfied with the performance of the aeroplane in relation to its future Australian activity.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the detailed matters that Senator Sibraa has raised about the contracts and the various questions of what might happen in particular circumstances, I would need to refer them to the Minister. I think that that would satisfy Senator Sibraa in obtaining a most detailed reply for him.
