DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Burden of Proof in Criminal Proceedings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I present a report on the burden of proof in criminal proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I have prepared a tabling statement which sets out in summary what this report is about. It concerns a complicated and, at first sight, perhaps uninteresting matter so far as the Senate is concerned. But I think that honourable senators will discover that it is a matter of great concern and importance to the civil liberties of the people of this country in cases where the Commonwealth is reversing the onus of proof and where some steps need to be taken. I seek to incorporate this statement to save time but I trust that Hansard on this occasion will print it not in a microscopic form which would discourage people from reading about this subject but in such a form that it can be properly read by persons in this place. On that basis I seek leave to have my tabling statement incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is today tabling a report entitled 'The Burden of Proof in Criminal Proceedings'. The subject matter of this inquiry is technical and somewhat complex and at first glance may appear to have little significance outside academic legal circles. However, the issues raised in this inquiry are of fundamental significance as they affect the civil liberties of every Australian citizen. What the report is in fact concerned with is the age-old common law presumption that a person is innocent until proved guilty. This presumption is being eroded by stealth in both Commonwealth and State legislation. This erosion is occurring because of the increasing body of legislation which places upon the defendant the burden of proving his innocence.
The inquiry was referred to the Committee by resolution of the Senate on 9 September 1980. The terms of reference were as follows:
The desirability of prohibiting or limiting use of statutory provisions, including delegated legislation, imposing a burden of proof upon defendants.

The reference arose out of a Report by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee which, among other matters, had been considering provisions in delegated legislation which placed the burden of proof upon defendants. That Committee concluded that the persuasive burden of proof should always lie on the prosecution and not on the defendant but considered that, as this was a matter of legislative policy, it should be referred to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. Although some of the principles regulating the incidence of the burden of proof go back many centuries, the practical implementation of these rules has been fraught with difficulty and confusion. The confusion partly stems from the term 'burden of proof' which is used in two very distinct senses and to which a variety of different names are given.

The first sense refers to the duty of a party to persuade a judge or jury by the end of the case, of the truth of certain propositions. Under the criminal law this burden of proof usually refers to the general rule that the prosecution bears the burden of proving the accused's guilt beyond reasonable doubt. However , there are two exceptions to this general rule, the first being when a plea of insanity is raised by the defendant, and the second consisting of statutory provisions which either expressly or by implication place the burden of proving certain matters upon the defendant. In both cases the standard of proof cast upon the defendant is proof upon a balance of probabilities.

The second sense of the phrase 'burden of proof' refers to the obligation of a party to show that there is sufficient evidence to raise an issue as to the existence or non-existence of a fact in issue. If the judge is not satisfied that there is enough evidence to make the issue one sufficiently arguable to be placed before the jury, he may withdraw that particular issue from them. In order to ensure clarity and uniformity of expression, the Committee has described these two senses of the burden of proof as the 'persuasive burden' and the 'evidential burden' respectively.

The Committee's consideration of the substantive law and of Commonwealth policy with regard to statutory provisions placing burdens on defendants has led us to make a number of recommendations both prohibiting and limiting the use of such provisions. The effect of these recommendations may be basically stated as follows. First, the Committee considers that there should be no exceptions to the common law principle that it is the duty of the prosecution to prove the guilt of the accused. Secondly, the Committee considers that evidential burdens should be kept to a minimum: they should only be placed on an accused by statute in clearly-defined circumstances, although evidential burdens placed on an accused by the common law are untouched by our proposals.

The primary justification raised by Commonwealth and State Crown Law Authorities for provisions imposing persuasive burdens on defendants is that they relate to information peculiarly within the knowledge of the accused. An overlapping consideration is that, in many cases, proof of the particular matter by the prosecution may be extremely difficult and expensive or perhaps even impossible to achieve. While the Committee recognises that there is a need to place burdens of proof on defendants in these situations, we have strong objections to resolving these difficulties by imposing persuasive burdens on defendants by statute. We take the view that such provisions are abhorrent to our legal system, create difficulties in explaining the varying degrees of proof to juries, prejudice the right of an accused to a fair trial, and we find no compelling policy considerations justifying their use. The Committee reached the conclusion that the difficulties faced by prosecutors could be overcome by placing merely an evidential burden on the accused. The Committee seeks to achieve this objective by recommending the enactment of legislation similar to that proposed by the English Criminal Law Revision Committee in its 11th Report. Such legislation would reduce all persuasive burdens on defendants presently existing under statute and delegated legislation to evidential burdens.

The adoption of our recommendation would, however, have the additional effect of making any persuasive burden of proof presently imposed by the common law on the accused an evidential one only. A major effect of this proposal would be to change the common law rule that the burden of proving insanity rests on the accused. The Committee is of the view that the present common law rule is anomalous and illogical and sees no reason why the prosecution should not prove beyond reasonable doubt the sanity of the accused, along with all other elements of the offence, once that matter has been raised in issue by the defendant. However, we recognise that the adoption of our major recommendation might confront the prosecutor with some difficulty in proving the accused's sanity. Accordingly we further recommend that if our major recommendation is adopted an accused person who wishes to raise the defence of insanity at his trial should be precluded from so doing, without the leave of the court, unless he has given written notice to the prosecution at some appropriate time before the date fixed for the hearing of his trial.

While the Committee reached the conclusion that there were no policy considerations warranting the placing of persuasive burdens on defendants, there are sound practical and policy reasons for casting evidential burdens on defendants. The practical difficulties occasionally faced by prosecutors in proving certain matters, and the need for effective law enforcement and an efficient administration of justice, make it desirable, and perhaps even essential, that evidential burdens be imposed on defendants. Nonetheless, we do not advocate that evidential burdens be placed on defendants merely as a matter of convenience. There are situations where the evidential burden currently rests on the accused, for instance in licence matters, where the required information can be easily obtained by the prosecution. In such circumstances, we consider the placing of evidential burdens on defendants to be inappropriate.

Thus, we make three recommendations with respect to evidential burdens. First, that as a matter of legislative policy, provisions imposing an evidential burden of proof on defendants should be kept to a minimum. Secondly, that this policy be achieved by imposing evidential burdens only where the defendant is presumed to have peculiar knowledge of the facts in issue or where proof by the prosecution of a particular matter in issue would be extremely difficult or expensive but could be readily and cheaply provided by the defendant. Thirdly, we recommend that a detailed review of Commonwealth legislation imposing evidential burdens, and in particular licensing provisions, should be undertaken to ensure that evidential burdens do not rest on defendants unless the above criteria apply.

The final area dealt with by the Committee in this report concerns averments. Some statutes provide that where the prosecutor alleges certain facts the allegation is prima facie evidence of the matter alleged, or that those facts should be taken to be proved unless the accused calls evidence to the contrary. Such allegations are technically known as averments. The effect of an averment is to place the onus of proof with regard to the matter averred on the defendant . It has been generally accepted that averment provisions only impose an evidential burden on the defendant since, if the accused adduces some evidence, a jury or magistrate must determine on the whole of the evidence whether the Crown has proved its case. The wide powers given to the prosecutors by virtue of averment provisions are open to, and have on occasion been subject to, abuse. Although the courts have defined and substantially restricted the use of averment provisions, the Committee is of the opinion that further restraint of a legislative character is required in this area of the law. First, we recommend that as a matter of legislative policy averment provisions should be kept to a minimum. Secondly, it is our view that Parliament should enact legislation to ensure that existing and future averment provisions are only resorted to by prosecutors in strictly-defined circumstances which we set down in the report. Thirdly, whenever prosecutors seek to rely on these provisions they should have regard to certain criteria adverted to by the courts. These criteria are specifically set out in our recommendations.

In conclusion, I reiterate the point I made at the outset: the subject matter of this report may be technical, but its significance for civil liberties in this country is vital. This Senate is a watchdog of liberty and I accordingly urge all senators to study the report and to press for the implementation of its recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly on this report entitled 'The Burden of Proof in Criminal Proceedings'. It is a most important report because it is concerned with the fact that in many instances before any penalty is imposed on a citizen, whether by way of fine or imprisonment, or some disadvantage is suffered by a citizen-for example, he may lose the right to undertake some activity, particularly a remunerative activity-whereas normally one would expect that the Government should prove the elements of any offence which leads to those drastic consequences, we find in Australia that at Commonwealth, State and Territory levels a citizen is quite often required to prove his innocence or prove the absence of any elements of the offence, be they mental or physical.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been faced over the years with a great increase in the number of such provisions in Commonwealth legislation which reverse the onus of proof. With the help of a computer search the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs was able to find nearly 100 instances of Commonwealth Acts which reversed the onus of proof-that is, required the accused or the defendant to prove his innocence or carry the burden of proving the absence of various elements in the offence. In the case of delegated legislation one can be sure that the number of such actions was multifold. The Committee dealt with very technical matters concerned with the burden of proof. The categories of persuasive burden and evidential burden recur throughout the report. The question is: On whom should those persuasive or evidential burdens rest-the prosecution or the defendant?

The Committee covered a wide range of matters in its report. But I think the core of it which would be of most interest to honourable senators would be that part of the report which deals with the fundamental issue of the present way in which burdens of proof are dealt with in criminal trials relating to insanity. Because that is the essence of the discussion, I will confine my remarks in the five minutes allotted to me to that issue. The general rule established since the nineteenth century in common law has been, of course, that the burden of proving the guilt of the accused beyond reasonable doubt rests on the prosecution. That was stated in the celebrated case of Woolmington in 1935 by Lord Sankey as indeed being the golden thread that runs through the web of English criminal law, namely, that the prosecution must always bear the burden of proving the prisoner's guilt beyond reasonable doubt. That has always been subject to certain exceptions, some at common law to do with insanity where the accused has had to prove his insanity. Also there have been a multitude of statutory exceptions to which, of course, I have already adverted.

But on the rare occasions on which insanity is raised as the defence for a murder charge, whilst it is true that the prosecution must satisfy the jury beyond reasonable doubt that the accused killed the deceased-in other words, the physical elements of the offence-the accused has to satisfy the jury on a balance of probabilities that he is insane; that is, he bears that persuasive burden. In such a case the law requires a conviction even though the jury may be left with a reasonable doubt as to whether the accused was indeed insane.

The Committee on reviewing this area decided that the prosecution should bear the burden of proving all elements in a criminal offence-physical and mental-and that requires, of course, that in the case of insanity, if the Committee's recommendations were taken into law by Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities, the prosecution from now on would bear the burden of proving the sanity of the accused beyond all reasonable doubt along with all the other elements of the offence. As I say, this proposal departs from the common law tradition insofar as it has had application in Australia. The fact is that we have recommended this change in an attempt to bring this area of the law into conformity with that general common law principle said to be the golden thread that runs through the web of our criminal law. In doing so we would be bringing Australian law into harmony with that which prevails in the United States of America. Mr Justice Harland, in the course of delivering the impressive judgment of the Supreme Court of the United States in Davis against the United States in 1895, said:

. . . how, then, upon principle or consistently with humanity, can a verdict of guilty be properly returned if the jury entertains a reasonable doubt as to the existence of a fact which is essential to guilt, namely, the capacity in law of the accused to commit that crime?

The Committee concluded that it is only consistent with humanity that the prosecution bear the burden of proving the sanity of the accused. It recognised, however, that in the needs of justice and fairness to all parties there should be a requirement of notice that that particular defence be given before the trial. Therefore, if an accused or his legal advisers were of the view that sanity ought to be put in issue, the accused should give notice of that defence, bear an evidential burden-in other words, make the question of sanity a live issue-and adduce sufficient evidence to require the judge to say that the prosecution needs to prove the sanity of the accused beyond reasonable doubt.

Finally, I make a plea that it not be thought for one moment that the Committee is advocating an adoption of the United States law concerning sanity of the accused in all its aspects. We do not advocate less stringent demarcation between sanity and insanity. We do not advocate any change in the general definition of what mental states should constitute insanity as have developed and served us reasonably well in Australia. We say that the accused has to make the question of insanity a live issue by giving notice before the trial and then adducing sufficient evidence for the judge to determine that the prosecution needs to adduce evidence to prove sanity beyond reasonable doubt. That is, we say the burden of proving the mental well being of the accused in relation to the physical activities which also have to be proved beyond reasonable doubt should rest on the prosecution. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Pesticides and the Health of Vietnam Veterans

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, I present a report on Pesticides and the Health of Australian Vietnam Veterans, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This first report of the pesticides inquiry concerns that part of the terms of reference of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment which refers to the possible effects on Vietnam veterans of exposure to herbicides. In the preface to the report the Committee has drawn attention to the need for an urgent response to the report by the Government. The issues raised in the report are of such importance that we, as a Committee, believe that the Government should respond by 31 March next year. The Committee has also stated that it will meet again to consider the Government's response and any further information arising from the current research and make a further report to the Senate.

The Committee realised early in the inquiry that it would be impossible to consider the potential exposure of Vietnam veterans to herbicides in isolation from other issues affecting veterans such as the nature of problems affecting their health and that of their children and their position under the repatriation legislation. The Committee has therefore taken a broad interpretation of its terms of reference and has attempted to consider all issues adversely affecting those who served Australia with honour and dignity in Vietnam. In taking this approach, the Committee considers the issue of possible exposure to herbicides in Vietnam to be only one of a number of problems affecting Vietnam veterans. While the Committee gave special consideration to herbicide exposure and exposure to the contaminant dioxin as a possible cause of the health problems experienced by Vietnam veterans, it also examined other potential causes. These included insecticides, anti-malarial drugs, melioidosis and war neurosis.

After examining the evidence, the Committee believes that it is impossible today to obtain a precise picture of the extent to which Australian servicemen may have been exposed to potentially harmful chemicals. Nevertheless, the Committee is of the opinion that the potential for direct exposure to herbicides sprayed by Australian and United States forces was low. Direct exposure to insecticides sprayed both by Australian and United States forces was highly probable. The Committee believes that, while possible, indirect exposure to herbicides and TCDD, through drinking water and foodstuffs, was unlikely. The Committee decided it would be more realistic to assume some exposure and, therefore, proceeded to examine the degree to which such exposure would produce the type of health problems reported by Vietnam veterans and their families.

One of the aspects of most pressing concern to Vietnam veterans is the possibility that their exposure to pesticides could be the cause of birth abnormalities among their children. From the evidence presented to it, the Committee concluded that it is highly improbable that the birth abnormalities reported among the children of Vietnam veterans are the result of the veteran's exposure to pesticides while serving in Vietnam. The birth abnormalities reported are primarily teratogenic in origin and, as such, are almost always produced as a result of exposure of the mother to toxic agents while pregnant. The Committee believes that there is no biologically plausible mechanism whereby the father's exposure in Vietnam can lead, years later, to exposure of the foetus in the uterus, as would be required to produce teratogenic abnormalities.

It became clear to the Committee during the inquiry that a great deal of confusion exists in the general community about the nature and origin of birth abnormalities. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended a public education program to help alleviate this confusion. In relation to the health problems of veterans, the Committee concluded that, on the available evidence, it is unlikely that the psychiatric disorders reported by Vietnam veterans are caused by exposure to potentially harmful chemicals whilst in Vietnam. The Committee was impressed by the striking similarities between the veterans' disorders and psychiatric disorders found among veterans of previous wars. These similarities include such symptons as the rage reaction on which the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia placed a great deal of emphasis. Although there are some similarities between the veterans' symptoms and those of toxic neuropsychiatric syndromes, the Committee believes that the level of exposure, even if at the level claimed by the VVAA, is insufficient to match the daily exposure over eight to 10 years which is found in the literature on toxic psychiatric disorders.

However, further research is desirable. In the first instance the Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth Institute of Health, with the co-operation of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, establish a mutually acceptable panel of psychiatrists and neurologists to examine Vietnam veterans who claim to be afflicted by chemically-caused psychiatric conditions in order to provide an independent assessment of the symptom profile commonly reported among Vietnam veterans. In relation to the Commonwealth Institute of Health the Committee noted that the epidemiologial studies may be of limited use in resolving the claims made about agent orange and other chemicals. Nevertheless, the Committee recommended that, in view of the time taken over the morbidity study, a decision be made to proceed with due emphasis being placed on attempting to establish whether psychiatric symptoms in veterans are due to a war neurosis or to exposure to harmful chemicals.

The Committee is unable to reach a conclusion on claims made about an increased rate of mortality among Vietnam veterans due to cancer. Insufficient is known about the human carcinogenicity of the chemicals to which the Vietnam veterans may have been exposed to warrant any definite statement about the likelihood of an increase in the rate of deaths caused by cancer. However, the Committee believes that there may be other reasons-for example, suicides and accidents due to psychiatric disorders-for expecting an increase in mortality. Accordingly the Committee recommended the rapid completion of the Commonwealth Institute of Health morbidity study.

Regarding their position under the Repatriation Act, the Committee concluded that the liability provisions of the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962 narrow the criteria by which compensation can be made to Vietnam veterans. The Committee welcomes the removal of this anomaly by the current amendments to the legislation. In addition, the Committee recommended that the proposed review of the repatriation legislation should include an examination of the evidentiary provisions, especially the reliance on information provided by departmental sources. The Committee was most impressed by the services offered through the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service and has recommended that serious consideration be given to extending it beyond 31 December 1983. The Committee also recommends that adequate staffing levels at the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service be provided to enable the collection and publication of relevant data.

The Committee examined several other aspects of the repatriation system as it affects Vietnam veterans, including veterans in non-metropolitan areas and prisons and the relations between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and veterans. Honourable senators would be aware that the Army Office of the Department of Defence has been examining some 21,000 files held at the Australian War Memorial seeking information about the use of pesticides in Vietnam. I understand that the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) will shortly be tabling a report in the House of Representatives based on the material in these files. The Committee was anxious to ensure that the material contained in this report did not contradict the substance of departmental evidence to the Committee in relation to pesticide spraying. Following a meeting with officers of the Department of Defence, the Committee is satisfied that the main thrust of departmental evidence presented to the Committee in relation to pesticide spraying in Vietnam was substantially correct. However, the Committee did obtain from the Department of Defence specific information relating to pesticide spraying from the War Memorial files and this is reflected in the report.

I welcome the statement on 11 November by Senator Sir John Carrick, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, that it is keenly interested in and aware of its self-imposed task to present a response within six months of the tabling of a parliamentary committee report. I believe also that the Government, apart from taking action to ensure speedier responses, should take the following measures:

Firstly, when responses are to extend beyond six months a statement should be made to the Senate indicating when a response could be expected and the reasons why the timeframe could not be kept; and secondly,

committee chairmen should be provided with a copy of the Government response at least one sitting day in advance of the response being tabled. This would enable committee chairmen to make an immediate reply to the response if desired. If these measures are implemented it will place the system of responses to reports on a much more business-like footing.

There is another matter on which I should comment. Throughout the inquiry there have been suggestions that the Committee was unwilling to call as a witness Dr Keith Fleming, formerly the Chief Director (Medical Services) in the Department of Veterans' Affairs. On behalf of the Committee I wish to refute totally this suggestion. The Committee's decision not to call Dr Fleming was based entirely on advice from the Committee secretary following discussions with Dr Fleming late last year and early this year. Dr Fleming advised the secretary that he would be willing to appear before the Committee if requested to do so; however, he doubted whether his evidence would be of much value to the Committee. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to table a letter from Dr Fleming confirming his willingness to appear before the Committee. In that letter he states:
To my knowledge, I have no information not already made available concerning toxic chemicals and Vietnam veterans.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I must say that I deeply regret the absence from the Senate today of Senator Mulvihill, the Deputy Chairman of the Committee . As all honourable senators would know, he is recovering in hospital following an operation. We hope to see him back in the Senate very soon. Senator Mulvihill has been a member of the Science and the Environment Committee since 1976. I regard myself as being extremely fortunate to have had him as both a committee colleague and Deputy Chairman during numerous inquiries. However, I wish to pay a particular tribute to his invaluable contribution to the work of the Committee during the present inquiry. Honourable senators will appreciate that on occasions this inquiry was an extremely controversial one. It is in no small measure due to Senator Mulvihill's experience and influence that the Committee is presenting a unanimous report.
—Tell him that John Carrick misses him too.

—I will do that. I am sure that Senator Mulvihill would appreciate that. I thank also my other colleagues-Senator Townley, Senator MacGibbon, Senator Mason and Senator Jones-for their conscientious work during this part of our inquiry. I am very grateful also to the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Health for their co-operation in providing additional material as requested by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Committee I must express also our complete appreciation for the loyalty and work rendered to us by our staff-Peter Roberts, secretary; Susan Thomson, research officer; and June Fallick, our steno-secretary. On this occasion we enlisted the advice of consultants because of the technical nature of our report. I am grateful to Dr Wayne Hall, an epidemiologist, and Dr Donald MacPhee, a geneticist, for their valuable contribution to the report. Finally, I think we must pay our tribute to the committee office word processor operators Linda Curtis and Robyn Graham, for their assistance in ensuring that this report met the tabling timetable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make only a few comments in relation to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and Environment. I will then seek leave to continue my remarks. I should emphasise a couple of points made by Senator Jessop in relation to the report. Senator Jessop in his tabling statement said that this was the first report of the Science and the Environment Committee in relation to the reference that had been given to it by the Senate. I believe that is the point that needs to be emphasised. It certainly is the first report of the section which deals with Vietnam veterans. It is worth pointing out and re-emphasising that we have undertaken in this first report to seek a response from the Government by 31 March 1983. Following that response from the Government, and following inquiries and further evidence that may be gathered, a further report will be given to the Senate by this Committee. As I cannot say what the Committee will do, I cannot say whether that will be the final report. At this stage my belief is that it probably will be the final report.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that a number of members of the Committee had some reservations about this report. However, after much discussion with and much heartburn on the part of members of the Committee, it was decided, I think rightly so, that this report should be brought down so that those people interested in it whether they be Vietnam veterans, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Health or whoever, could have some time to look at the report, to discuss it and to take into consideration the points made in the report by the Committee so that if they have any further evidence or wish to make some further comment, maybe we can take that into consideration when we make the final report to the Senate. I think it needs also to be mentioned that it is fairly important that this report be brought down-because of the type of inquiry that it was and because of the amount of time that has been spent in discussions with Vietnam veterans-before any resolutions are made on the problems that face Vietnam veterans after service in Vietnam. I think it is important that this report be brought forward so that the recommendations to date can be given to test the validity of the Government's claims and to see whether it will respond to some of the claims made in the report.

As a member of the Opposition, I had some doubt about the Government's response to the recommendations in the report. But, as a member of the Committee, I felt that it was important that the report be made and that we undertake to give the Government a chance to respond to it. The Committee can then have a further look at the problems facing Vietnam veterans before the final report is brought down in this place.

Another point that I would like to make-I want to keep my remarks short-relates to the point raised by Senator Jessop when tabling the report. He said that we had had discussions with members of the Department of Defence regarding the report that it will bring down relating to the 21,000 files which were found, I think at the Australian War Memorial. The result of that report will be known some time later. It has not been tabled at this stage. It is fairly important to note that the Committee would have had some difficulty in bringing down a final report. Whilst we had information from members of the Department of Defence, and whilst the Chairman has said that we were satisfied, I think it is reasonable to expect that the Committee should look in some detail at the report being prepared by the Department of Defence on those 21,000 files. In order to bring down a comprehensive and reasonable report, it behoves us to take some more detailed look at the report being brought down by the Department of Defence on those 21,000 files because as a Committee we may find that we need to make further inquiries following that report. We may find that that report satisfies the needs of the Committee and we will not need to go any further. However, that is a decision for the Committee and it is reasonable enough to expect that the Committee should have that report available to it.

Another point I would like to make is one of criticism. I am slightly critical of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) in this matter. I raise this matter because it happened in the course of the Committee's inquiry. I was quite taken aback by the answers given to me when I questioned a witness who was giving to the Committee a final report from the Department of Veterans' Affairs in relation to spraying in Vietnam. The submission being given to the Committee was quite detailed. It was detailed in the form in which it was given, the words used and the way in which things were described, and in the visual aids, maps and other details given by the members of the Minister's Department I asked one of the witnessess: 'Did the Minister see the submission before it was given to the Committee?' The answer from the witness from the Department was that the Minister was vaguely told about the submission-I am not quoting the exact words- but that he certainly did not see the total submission.

I felt that with a committee which was investigating such a very serious situation as that of the effects of pesticides on the health of Australians who have returned from Vietnam, it would be reasonable to expect that if a final submission were to be put to the Committee, that submission would have to be approved by the Minister, or at least that the Minister would see the submission in its totality. Maybe I shall stand some correction on this matter, but as a member of the Committee I was amazed that that was not so and did not happen.

Finally, the Committee worked together extremely well. I believe that this report will allow the Vietnam veterans and the departments which are interested in the matter to look in some detail at what evidence has been given to the Committee and at some of the conclusions. I hope the Government will look at the recommendations and respond to them by the set date of 31 March 1983, and then the Committee should be able to complete its work and produce a further report following the Government's response. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave not granted.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I present a report on the ANZUS Alliance, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave, Mr Acting Deputy President, to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

On 8 September 1981, the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence passed a resolution referring to its Sub-committee A, the Sub-committee on the Pacific Basin, the following terms of reference: 'Australian-United States' Relations'.

The Sub-committee, which is chaired by Mr Stephen Lusher, M.P., called for submissions on the reference through newspaper advertisements and direct contact with interested persons and organisations in Australia and the United States.

The Sub-committee has conducted a wide-ranging inquiry into all the major aspects of Australian-United States' relations, including foreign policy, security and defence matters, as well as economic and cultural relations. I would like to thank those individuals and government departments who spent time and effort in preparing written submissions and who gave oral evidence before the Sub-committee.

The focus of the report is Australia's long-standing security relationship with the United States, as embodied in the ANZUS Treaty. The Sub-committee on the Pacific Basin will continue its examination of the other aspects of the reference, and these will be discussed in future reports of the Committee as appropriate.

The Committee believes that it is particularly appropriate that it should be considering this reference in 1982, the thirtieth anniversary of the ANZUS Treaty. As the Committee points out in the introduction to the report, ANZUS underpins the Australian-United States' relationship, which, during the last thirty years, has become increasingly complex and multifaceted, and remains Australia's single most important external relationship.

The Committee acknowledges that a number of Australians have serious reservations concerning Australia's close security relationship with the United States, including fears that the presence of US installations may make Australia a nuclear target in the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union.
Doubts have also been expressed as to whether the United States would be willing to become involved militarily on Australia's side in the event of a regional conflict breaking out.

The Committee believes that these reservations over Australia's membership of ANZUS reflect misunderstandings concerning both the nature of ANZUS and Australia's expectations of the pact as a security shield. The purpose of this report, therefore, is to discuss the issues that have been raised and to clarify the Australian-United States' security relationship.

The Committee recognises that the basic asymmetry of the relationship between the two countries is an undeniable fact-the United States is a 'superpower' with global pre-occupations, while Australia is a smaller power concerned with defining its own role as a 'middle-power' in regional and international affairs.

The report also discusses the extent to which Australian diplomacy is, or need be, constrained by our close relationship with the United States. The Committee believes that Australia's basic objective is to fulfil its commitment to the Alliance, with due regard to our national interest and the maintenance of our national sovereignty.

Chapter 1 of the report traces the history of the ANZUS pact and examines its terms. The views of a number of scholars who have written on the Treaty are noted and discussed, as are statements made by Australian and American statesmen and officials who were involved in the negotiation of the pact.

In examining the legal interpretation of Articles II, III, IV and V of the ANZUS Treaty, which spell out the pact's guarantees of mutual assistance, the report notes that it has often been said that Article IV of ANZUS is not so binding a mutual guarantee of protection as that contained in Article 5 of the NATO Treaty. This is because Article 5 of the NATO pact contains the phrase 'an armed attack against one . . . shall be considered an armed attack against all', whereas Article IV of ANZUS states only that 'in case of an armed attack in the Pacific Area on any of the Parties, each party would act to meet the common danger in accordance with its constitutional processes'. The report points out, however, that at the time the ANZUS Treaty was negotiated spokesmen for all the parties to the Treaty stated that the general intention of the two treaties was the same. It was explained that the language used in the NATO Treaty gave rise in the United States Senate to a debate as to whether that precise language involved any shift in the responsibility between the President and the Congress. As the then US Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, stated before the US Senate Foreign Relations Committee, it seemed to him and to the other governments concerned best to not reopen that kind of debate again by using in the ANZUS Treaty language that might not be acceptable to the United States Senate.

The report also points out that, as emphasised in evidence heard in the course of the inquiry, the formal wording of any treaty is only an indication of the obligation felt by the partners, and that the 'formal' or 'paper' aspects of the Alliance, especially in the case of ANZUS, are really peripheral to the essence of the relationship.

The Committee concludes this chapter by stating that the recent significant signs of renewed US interest in the Pacific-Indian Ocean region are in accord with the spirit of ANZUS, and that it also believes there is a need for Australia to assert its position as a middle power in our own region, in addition to providing a stable base for the US Pacific Command in the Western Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean.

In Chapter 2, entitled the 'ANZUS Security Guarantee', the Committee emphasises that no major threat has emerged, or is likely to emerge in the short term, which would test American willingness to commit its forces to protect either Australia or New Zealand under the ANZUS Treaty.

In this Chapter, the report discusses the significance of ANZUS in the light of past events, including the Malaysian-Indonesian 'confrontation' in the early 1960s, and goes on to discuss current Australian and American perceptions of ANZUS and its role, including the extent to which, realistically, Australia could expect assistance under the terms of the Treaty, should this country ever face a serious threat to its security.

The Committee makes two main points: first, while Australia's security against a serious threat may ultimately depend on military assistance from the United States, Australia must be in a position to mount a national defence effort that would maximise the risks and costs of any aggression against us. Secondly, the Committee emphasises that, on a number of occasions under recent administrations , the United States has made it perfectly clear to its allies in the region, including Australia, that it expects them to defend themselves except in the case of a threat from a major power.

As stated in the report, the Committee considers that the mutual security provisions of the ANZUS Treaty represent a stronger assurance of military assistance in the event of an attack on Australian territory than a commitment merely to consult. The Committee believes that, in the event of a threat to Australia which proved beyond the capacity of the Australian defence force to meet unaided, US support would be forthcoming in accordance with the mutual security provisions of the Treaty. However, no such threat is visible in the near future; nor is it clear what form of assistance would be provided, should a serious threat emerge.

The Committee also points out that there are other considerations to be taken into account, including the possibly limited capability of the United States to supply support and assistance to the Pacific region in the event of a crisis which coincided with a crisis elsewhere in the world. The Committee notes that there is also the question of how the United States would react should there be a conflict in its support of Australia against a hypothetical adversary in the region with which the United States also had a security agreement, in the event that Australia and that hypothetical adversary were in conflict.

Finally, in Chapter 2, the Committee emphasises again that current United States defence thinking in relation to the Asian-Pacific region, as well as its expectations of Australia's role within the framework of ANZUS, indicate that the United States' view of its role in the region precludes direct military involvement, except in an extreme situation. The Committee believes that the official Australian view of ANZUS acknowledges this.

In Chapter 3, the committee discusses the benefits and costs of ANZUS. In addition to providing reassurance that, in the event of a fundamental threat to Australia's security, it could reasonably be expected that United States support would be forthcoming, there are a number of other benefits which Australia obtains from its participation in ANZUS. These benefits are in the area of supply and support, the training benefits the Australian Defence Force derives from joint military exercises, and the strategic dialogue which the ANZUS relationship facilitates between Australia and the United States. In its submission to the Sub-Committee, the Department of Defence emphasised that this dialogue gives Australia valuable access to United States strategic thinking and allows closer assessment of global and regional developments which also might affect Australia's own strategic outlook.

Again, the Committee notes that there is the benefit of deterrence: in the geopolitical context ANZUS conveys to the Soviet bloc powers and potential aggressors within the region a strong signal, both from the United States and the local powers concerned, that this is not an area of low-cost, low-risk opportunities. The Committee also notes another benefit brought to the attention of the Sub-Committee, in that membership of ANZUS gives Australia an enhanced status in the region.

The report then looks at the question of whether the costs of ANZUS are too high in relation to the benefits Australia receives from it. Witnesses who appeared before the Sub-Committee have argued that the main costs are:

the extent to which the joint Australian-United States' facilities (especially those at Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape) may be nuclear targets in the event of global war between the United States and the Soviet Union;

loss of sovereignty, due in part to the presence of the above installations, since Australia is said to have insufficient control over, or to be inadequately consulted about certain aspects of their operation;
distortion of our national defence posture as a result of adopting policies better suited to the global defence strategy of the United States than our own defence needs;
diplomatic constraints on Australia, due to our close links with the United States, which may conflict with our foreign policy priorities as a regional power.

The Committee's report examines each of these points. On the issue of whether Australia is a nuclear target due to the presence of the Australian-United States' joint defence facilities, the Committee draws attention to the points raised in a previous report, Threats to Australia's Security, tabled in 1981.

That report, which was prepared by the Committee's Sub-Committee C-the Sub- Committee on Defence Matters-concluded that 'it would be prudent for Australian defence planners to assume that the joint facilities at North West Cape, Pine Gap and Nurrungar are on the Soviet target list and might be attacked in the course of a nuclear conflict between the two superpowers'.

However, both in that report and in the report being tabled today, the Committee points out that the part played by the facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar in monitoring and gathering intelligence on Soviet forces and weapon movements, their verification capabilities in regard to arms limitations agreements, as well as the important contribution made by the facility at North West Cape to United States' defences, make a vital contribution to the defences of the whole Western Alliance. Therefore, on balance, the Committee agrees with the assessment made by this and former Australian governments, that the benefits to Western defences and therefore Australia's ultimate security outweigh any risks the presence of these facilities entails.

On the question of whether the presence of the facilities entails a loss of Australian sovereignty, the Committee draws attention to statements on the subject made by Government and Opposition spokesmen. These statements stress that Australians share control of, and participate in, the functioning of the facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar at all levels of operation.
The report also notes the reservations expressed by the Leader of the Opposition, the Honourable W. G. Hayden, concerning Australian control over the operation of the North West Cape Station.

The report states that no substantive evidence was presented to the Committee that would contradict the views of the Department of Defence (and the statements just referred to) that the facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar are both conducted with Australia's full knowledge and concurrence.

Again, the Committee concludes that, on balance, Australian access to and participation in the operations of the joint facility at North West Cape is appropriate in the context of Australia's responsibilities under the ANZUS Alliance.
The Committee therefore states that it is satisfied that there is no unacceptable loss of sovereignty arising from the presence of the joint facilities.

The Committee also points out that, along with other features of the Australian -American intelligence co-operation, the facilities are a major Australian contribution and therefore a 'card of entry' to allied intelligence policies and decision making.

Next, the Committee looks at the value of the Australian-United States defence co-operation. It acccepts the Defence assessment that, overall, the exchange of intelligence information is of high quality and is of benefit to Australia, particularly in respect of those areas where Australia's own national resources can provide only limited coverage.

The Committee also states that the ANZUS relationship is of such crucial importance that the partners must conduct themselves on the basis of full equality, consulting each other where major changes are contemplated in the security relationships which link them and, in particular, sounding out opinions well in advance of any likely need for commitments to be made either under the Alliance or of a less formal nature. The Committee believes that, if this is done, the future of the Australian-United States' security relationship is likely to be smooth.

Again, the Committee concludes that the present level of defence co-operation between Australia and the United States, is not inimical to Australia's national or regional intersts, and that it offers a measure of protection for Australia should Soviet penetrations of the South Pacific-Indian Ocean areas become a more direct threat to Australia's own interests in the region.
The Committee also accepts that the Australian defence forces obtain a wide range of practical benefits from bilateral and multilateral co-operation within the framework of ANZUS.

Finally, in Chapter 3, the Committee looks at the question of whether Australia 's security relationship imposes constraints on Australia's own diplomacy, especially in relation to issues in our own region.

The report points to a lack of substantial evidence that Australia's foreign policy in the region might be adversely affected by our membership of ANZUS. The report also points to areas where Australia has openly expressed disagreement with the United States' policies on significant issues, such as the Law of the Sea negotiations. It notes that Australian policies towards the region differ from those of the present United States Administration on certain issues on which Australia has attempted to exert diplomatic influence on the United States , for example, over the issue of arms sales to Taiwan. Again, in August this year, the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, publicly criticised United States policies towards Israel.

As a neighbouring power of modest size with an attractive decolonisation record and anti-nuclear testing credentials, Australia is able to bring influence into Papua New Guinea and the rest of the South Pacific in ways quite unavailable to the United States, including through the South Pacific Forum, of which the United States is not a member.
After consideration of the available evidence, the Committee concludes that Australia's foreign policy is not constrained by its participation in ANZUS.

The Committee points out that, in many ways, Australia's position differs markedly from that of its ally. The United States has global preoccupations, whereas Australia has its own role, including distinct regional responsibilities . As a member of the Western Alliance, Australia shares with the United States many foreign policy concerns. However, the Committee considers that Australia can, and should, act separately where our interests diverge.

The Committee also agrees with the view that Australia, as a middle power, can sometimes operate more effectively by itself, taking the lead regionally on behalf of the Alliance, for example, in the South Pacific.

As stated in the introduction to the report, the basic asymmetry of the Australian-United States' relationship is an inescapable reality, and Australia should not, therefore, over-estimate its ability to influence its ally. We do not dominate their thinking and we must bear this in mind in assessing the relationship.

Despite this basic asymmetry and the difficulties that have arisen from time to time, and despite the fact that the United States sometimes overlooks or ignores Australia's position, the Committee believes that the Australia-United States' relationship is, and can continue to be, mutually advantageous.

As discussed in Chapter 2 of the report, the United States expects Australia to pay a significant and, indeed, an increasing part in the defences of the Pacific and Indian Ocean areas. The Committee considers that in this situation our superpower ally needs more than ever to behave circumspectly and with sensitivity in all aspects of its relations with Australia. This means that the United States should take seriously Australia's views on matters of mutual concern where we may have a separate national perspective. In this regard, the Committee endorses the assessment of the Department of Foreign Affairs that the United States does adopt this position.
In Chapter 4, the Committee evaluates what is perhaps the most significant concern in relation to ANZUS-the future of the Alliance.

The complexities of the relationship between the two powers are reiterated and summarised. The Committee rejects the extreme position of withdrawal from ANZUS, as withdrawal would not only have immediate and widespread implications for Australia's own security, but any significant decrease in the US presence in the South Pacific and Indian Oceans resulting from it could seriously affect the stability of the whole region.

No security agreement can provide for every eventuality or satisfy every need, but ANZUS does provide an instrumentality that can be effective in responding to crisis situations, and its mere existence may keep some adverse circumstances from developing.

The option of redrafting sections of the Treaty was also discussed and rejected on the grounds that Australia would be unlikely to secure from the United States a more specific commitment to safeguard our security than that which already exists in the Treaty. Even if, as a hypothesis, the United States Administration were to offer Australia a guarantee of assistance in all circumstances affecting our security, an important consideration is whether any Australian government would give a similar guarantee to the United States.

In the Committee's view, ANZUS has assumed new importance because of the recent shift in the geo-political sphere of contest to the Indian Ocean-Persian Gulf area. The continued security of the sea lanes of communication between the Pacific and Indian Oceans are of vital importance not only to Australia's security, but to the whole economic functioning of the Western world. The report points out, therefore, that the stability of Australia's own strategic environment is linked in no small measure to the effective involvement of the United States' interest and policies throughout the region.

The Committee believes that differences between the United States and Australia will continue to exist, but that the management of these differences is likely to be conducted in an atmosphere which favours accommodation.
The Committee's conclusion is, therefore, that the ANZUS Alliance remains both useful and necessary, and that Australia should remain within its framework.

Finally, the report emphasises that the security links between Australia and the United States spring from shared values, compatible institutions and objectives and continuing popular support within the Australian community for ANZUS and the wider Western Alliance.
I commend this report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement that I have incorporated is the formal tabling statement of the Committee. May I briefly expand upon several points for the information of the Senate. I do so because I find myself in the unusual position of tabling this report this morning as the Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and as someone who has signed a minority report. Further, I am not a member of Sub-committee A. The remarks that I intend to make now are therefore a summary of the Sub-committee's report.

The Sub-committee, which is chaired by Mr Stephen Lusher, M.P., has conducted a wide -ranging inquiry into all major aspects of Australian-United States relations, including foreign policy, security and defence matters, as well as economic and cultural relations. The focus of the report is Australia's long-standing security relationship with the United States of America as embodied in the ANZUS treaty. The Sub-committee will continue its examination of other aspects of the reference and these will be discussed in future reports. ANZUS underpins the Australian-United States relationship which during the last 30 years has become increasingly most important external relationship. Chapter 1 of the report traces the history of the ANZUS pact and examines its terms. In chapter 2 the significance of ANZUS in the light of past events, including the Malaysian-Indonesian confrontation in the early 1960s, is discussed as also are current Australian and American perceptions of ANZUS and its role, including the extent to which realistically Australia could expect assistance under the terms of the treaty should this country ever face a serious threat to its security.

The Committee considers that the mutual security provisions of the ANZUS treaty represent a stronger assurance of military assistance in the event of an attack on Australian territory than a commitment merely to consult. At the same time, the Committee emphasises that official United States statements of its defence thinking in relation to the Asian-Pacific region, as well as United States expectations of Australia's role within the framework of ANZUS, indicate that the United States view of its role in the region precludes direct military involvement, except in an extreme situation. The Committee believes the official Australian view of ANZUS acknowledges this. In Chapter 3 of the report the Committee discusses the benefits and costs of ANZUS. The Committee concludes that the Australian-United States relationship is, and can continue to be, mutually advantageous. It also points out that the United States should take seriously Australia's views on matters of mutual concern where we may have a separate national perspective. In this regard the Committee endorses the assessment of the Department of Foreign Affairs that the United States does adopt this position.

In Chapter 4 the Committee evaluates what is perhaps the most significant concern in relation to ANZUS-that is, the future of the alliance. The report points out that the stability of Australia's own strategic environment is linked in no small measure to the effective involvement of United States interest and policies throughout the region. The Committee believes that differences between the United States and Australia will continue to exist, but that the management of these differences is likely to be conducted in an atmosphere which favours accommodation. The Committee's conclusion is, therefore, that the ANZUS alliance remains both useful and necessary and that Australia should remain within its framework. Finally, the report emphasises that the security links between Australia and the United States spring from shared values, compatible institutions and objectives and continuing popular support within the Australian community for ANZUS and the wider Western alliance.

There are features of this report which I and other members of the Committee who signed two minority reports find unsatisfactory. Both of the minority reports relate to matters canvassed in chapter 3 regarding the benefits and costs of ANZUS. These matters are covered on pages 95 to 99 of the report. The first relates to the question as to whether the joint installations in Australia involve an unacceptable loss of Australian sovereignty. In general, we would agree that the installations do not involve an unacceptable loss of Australian sovereignty in their operations. Nevertheless, the Committee has cited a number of instances in the past when Australian governments have been unpleasantly surprised as a result of their ignorance of operations and developments involving the installations. In particular, we are concerned that the operations at North West Cape do involve an unacceptable loss of sovereignty for Australia. Currently it is impossible for the Australian Government to determine when the installations are being used to relay messages that are related to military actions. This holds the possibility of Australian involvement in conflict without our consent. We believe it is possible to extend the agreement on consultation achieved by the former Minister for Defence, Lance Barnard, and the then United States Defence Secretary, Schlesinger, in 1974 related to operations of installations to overcome this problem. It is our belief that the Government should initiate efforts to ensure that this happens.

The second dissent relates to the question of whether Australian policy has been constrained by our participation in ANZUS. We hold the view that whilst Australian foreign policy need not be unacceptably constrained by ANZUS as it has been in the past and may be in the future, these constraints have not arisen as a result of United States policy. I make that point clear. The United States Administration has invariably been prepared to countenance a higher degree of independent Australian initiative than Australian governments have displayed. The constraints have been self-imposed and have been a result of false assessments of what was important to maintain the ANZUS alliance.

The Committee has cited two examples, one arising from Australian participation in the war in Vietnam. In that instance, Australian governments argued that the commitment of forces to the conflict was necessary as advance payment on the United States alliance. Few other allies of the United States arrived at the same conclusion. Most assessed the war as a dangerous and debilitating distraction for the United States. So strait-jacketed were Australian governments by the fear that less than 100 per cent undeviating support would jeopardise our security that they were even unable to use Australian participation to give us a say in the process by which the war was resolved.

The failure to analyse the Vietnam war for its impact on Australian-American relations is a glaring omission from this report, made even more obvious by a lengthy and excellent analysis of a lesser problem for the alliance, that being the diplomacy surrounding the Malaysian-Indonesian confrontation. The same sort of self-imposed constraints have caused excessive secrecy about the purposes of the joint installations in Australia. We still rely for most of our information on American sources of a semi-official nature gleaned by Australian academics. Unless these tendencies in Australian foreign policy making are acknowledged and dealt with, Australian governments may find themselves unnecessarily constrained in the future.

The Chairman of the Sub-committee, Mr Stephen Lusher, M.P., has asked me to thank the staff who worked so excellently with the Sub- committee, especially Andrea Edvi-Illes and Dan Barton. I commend the report to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) adjourned.
