PROCTEXT.PARA: Report on the Australian Loan Council and Inter-governmental Relations

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations on the Australian Loan Council is another demonstration of the intensity with which the Loan Council is presently being scrutinised. It is probably fair to say that the Loan Council is being more closely scrutinised now that at any previous time since its establishment in 1927. Apart from this major report with which we are dealing today we have had, of course, the paper of Professor Russell Mathews presented back in January 1982 to the Australian Institute of Political Science summer school in which he urged that the role of the Council be broadened into what he described as a federal fiscal council, which contribution sparked off a very considerable national debate. We also have a situation where quite intensive internal scrutiny is going on, insofar as the Loan Council is concerned, by all the participating governments. This follows the decline which has been perceived by a number of commentators and indeed is objectively the case so far as the role of the Loan Council is concerned. One way of making clear that decline is the following statistic that, whereas in 1953-54 some 80 per cent of State, local government and authority capital funds were raised by the Loan Council, by the latter half of the 1970s this proportion had fallen to less than 40 per cent.

The ACIR report gives a number of other figures of a comparable kind which demonstrate the extent of the decline. The report states, for example, that the Loan Council's borrowing program in the mid-1960s amounted to approximately one- half of gross fixed capital expenditure by the public sector but this dropped to just over one-third by 1980-81. It stated further that in 1980-81 more than 90 per cent of Commonwealth payments to the States were interest free, non- repayable grants compared with only 60 per cent in the mid-1960s while over the same period the ratio between Loan Council approved borrowings and gross domestic product fell by one-third. In addition, there is the evidence of the June Loan Council this year when electricity authority domestic borrowings were removed from Loan Council control-another demonstration of the declining influence and role of the Loan Council.

The ACIR report is a serious-minded attempt to come to grips with the issues posed by this state of affairs. It endeavours to identify a role for the Loan Council to enable it to contribute more usefully to the labyrinth of Federal- State financial relations. At the very least it is a highly informative document pulling together a mass of material on the history, the mode of operation and the economic significance of the Loan Council and identifying options at the same time for changes to the present system. I make it clear that I do not agree with everything in this report. As a member of the Council at the time the report was being compiled I dissented from some of its recommendations. But certainly I and members of the Australian Labor Party welcome its appearance and we believe that the Parliament should do so too.

I think those responsible for its production, especially the ACIR research director, Mr John Jameson, ought to be congratulated for the huge amount of effort and thought that has gone into it. The kinds of questions one needs to ask in analysing or contemplating the role of the Loan Council can, I guess, be summarised roughly as follows: Should the jurisdiction of the Loan Council be varied to give it a greater or a lesser role with respect to borrowing and capital funding? Should the Loan Council have expanded powers of investment appraisal and allocation decisions? Should the Loan Council have a role in the area of macroeconomic policy formulation or at least macroeconomic advice; that is, with respect to overall economic management? Then again, what are the implications for the structure, the organisation, the voting powers and the mode of operation of the Loan Council if any one of these sorts of changes are made?

At first sight it would appear to be the case that two broad approaches, two differing approaches, could be taken to the future of the Loan Council. One could take the view that the Council should go on doing what it is doing now, but doing it better. For example, with more precise criteria for infrastructure borrowing and with little, if any, changes in the structure, the voting arrangements, the voting powers and so on of the Council. Alternatively, one could take the view that the Loan Council ought to significantly change its character so as to become a key central instrument in overall investment planning and co-ordination with significant changes arguably then following so far as structure voting arrangements, mode of operation and so on are concerned. The ACIR report falls somewhere between these two stools. It does not recommend any fundamental changes to the structure, the voting arrangements or the mode of operation of the Loan Council, but it does recommend a significant expansion of its functions with the establishment of a secretariat to reflect that expanded role and also a name change to match, with the Loan Council becoming the Federal Financial Council.

The effect of the ACIR's recommendation in this respect can perhaps be best summarised by referring to recommendation 21 in the report which appears at paragraph 363 and reading that in conjunction with paragraph 298 of the report which identifies the existing and proposed new functions of the Council. The existing functions of the Loan Council are describable as follows:
(a) to determine the volume of public sector borrowing;
(b) to distribute public sector borrowing limits between States and between types of authority;
(c) to determine the terms and conditions of loans;
(d) to determine priorities for different types of loans (e.g. infrastructure program);
(e) to develop orderly marketing systems for government securities;
(f) to co-ordinate the approach of governments to overseas capital markets;

Not all of those functions have been performed with an equal degree of vigour in recent years, but that is basically what the Charter of the Council in the past has provided that it should do. It is now proposed by the ACIR that those functions should be added to with the following additional functions:
(g) to advise on development policy and allocate funds for special development and infrastructure projects;
(h) to examine and review from time to time the necessity for, and extent of, controls over public sector borrowing;
(i) to review the financial terms and conditions for specific purpose grants,
trends in financial transfers, the balance between different types of transfers and the implications for the Commonwealth and the States of changes in the patterns of transfers, and--
Finally and more controversially-
the effects of policies relating to such matters as tariffs, exchange rates, monetary aggregates, wages and taxation . . .

I, and I suspect the Australian Labor Party on the preliminary consideration that we have given these matters, generally take the view that most of these additional functions ought to be supported with the major exception, however, of the last one I mentioned; that is, giving macroeconomic advice, and playing a consultative role in relation to those macroeconomic management matters in the areas of tariffs, exchange rates, monetary aggregates, wages and taxation. That is a position that is made clear in paragraph 361 of the report, that there were dissenting voices when it came to the question of giving these macroeconomic functions to the new proposed Federal Financial Council.

I believe, and I think I can state that the Labor Party believes, that while it is appropriate for the Loan Council to take account of macroeconomic considerations in its decision making it should have no specific consultative or advisory role in this area. That role is better played by what the Labor Party has been constantly proposing; that is, the establishment of a National Economic Planning Advisory Council which would have representatives not only from the Commonwealth and the States, but also from local government and from trade unions, business and consumer interests.

The general approach of the Labor Party, then, is to take the view that the Loan Council should be retained in basically its present form but to acknowledge that there needs to be a major review of the causes and consequences of the declining scope of its influence, a review that obviously will be much assisted by the presentation of this report. It would be our view that there needs to be an increase in the effectiveness of its co-ordination of major public works and, in particular, a more effective role for it in relation to investment appraisal and allocation decisions. Even if it has no specific advisory role in relation to macroeconomic matters, we certainly believe the Loan Council should work in close co-operation with other bodies, particularly this proposed economic planning advisory council, with responsibilities in that area. We welcome the appearance of this report and hope that an early opportunity will present itself for a fuller parliamentary consideration of it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Government's proposal to sell the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to the private sector was made back in 1979 and it was reaffirmed as part of the recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. This annual report refers to a number of the factors operating in the insurance industry as it relates to this publicly owned insurance corporation which has to be regarded as one of the real success stories of public enterprise. The organisation was established during the Menzies period. I am sure that Sir Robert Menzies would turn over in his grave if he knew that the proposal of this Government-this very tory Government-is to sell off such an important public instrumentality which was established by a Liberal government for the purposes of protecting home owners and providing a service-and a competitive service indeed-as each year's report shows. Therefore, it is another example of the ideological position taken by the Government as it attempts to sell off to the lowest bidder all the public enterprises which conservative governments as well as Labor governments have set up. In the post-war years this country has been ruled by conservative administrations, and numerous public instrumentalities have been developed in that period. It is a matter of grave regret that this Government is hocking them off to the lowest bidder.
The report of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation states:

The Government announced its intention of selling HLIC to the private sector in July 1979. In April 1981, the Government reaffirmed that decision following its Review of Commonwealth Functions. In June 1981, registrations of interest in the purchase of HLIC were invited through the press. Expressions of interest were evaluated in 1981-82 and the drafting of an invitation to bid completed. Formal offers from selected registrants were sought in July 1982. At the date of this Report, offers were under consideration by the Commonwealth.

Not only the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation but also the Belconnen Mall and a number of other important public endeavours, instrumentalities and corporations are under threat of sale. It seems to me that a time of economic downturn is the wrong time to sell off public enterprises. Clearly, we are not in a period in which we can realise the potential of those enterprises. The Government is not proceeding with the tenders that have been received because it is finding that it is not able to realise the potential, even according to its own philosophical position. As a result of that decision, this organisation has been under a cloud for three years or more. It is somewhat symptomatic that the organisation suffers as a result of government policy. So, with the future of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation remaining unclear, and in the general downturn which can be attributed to the direct financial policies being pursued by this Government, it is a matter of considerable concern and regret that this organisation faces the Government's propositions with some degree of wonder and concern as to its future. This is just another example of the complete failure of the Review of Commonwealth Functions which, in the presentation of its argument a couple of years ago, promised that the sale of government instrumentalities would result in savings to the general public and revenue to the Commonwealth of some $600m. Nowhere near that amount of money has been realised. Whilst the Government took the ideological decision, it has found that it is not able to realise the objectives it set itself. So again we find ourselves in a game of ideological bluff with this Government, which is attempting to convince the Australian public that it will make a revenue gain whereas in fact, of course, it will have a major loss, even if it persists with the sale of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.

It is worth noting that the insurance of home loans is the main business of the Corporation. It is a very important safeguard that exists for those who use the facilities, largely those persons involved with the war service organisation that provides a great deal of assistance to serving servicemen and ex-servicemen . What the report shows, and this is another example of the failure of the Government's economic policies, is a reflection of the drastic downturn in the home building industry. The report points out that loans insured under full cover fell by 35 per cent in number and 31 per cent by amount in 1981-82. It draws attention to the fewer loans that were insured and then goes on to say:
Despite a general expectation that claims against mortgage insurers might have risen under the pressure of rising interest rates, HLIC's total claims for 1981- 82 were 11% lower than in 1980-81.

That situation is not any reflection upon the organisation. It arises because of the general state of the home ownership market. The Corporation is further instructed to look at the drop in the home loans insured in recent years. Here we find that there has been a considerable fall-off in one year. In 1981 there were 55,495 insurers. In 1982 that figure dropped to 38,550, which, of course represents almost a 40 per cent drop. So that we might have some understanding of what is really happening in the home ownership area, particularly as it relates to this organisation, I seek leave-I have not had an opportunity to discuss it with the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume)-to incorporate in Hansard the table contained on page 4 of the document that we are considering .

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Annual Reports: Government Response-Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment entitled 'Examination of Annual Reports', and to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

During 1981 the Senate Standing Committee examined two of the annual reports referred to it: these were the 1979-80 Annual Reports of the Department of Science and the Environment and of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO). Within those reports it concentrated on:
the Baseline Air Pollution Station (BAPS)
the Australian Balloon Launching Station (ABLS)
funding for the CSIRO.
Its report offered a number of recommendations on those issues.

PROCTEXT.PARA: 2. BAPS was established as Australia's part in a world wide network of stations designed to study the composition of the atmosphere and so, through observations over a long period of time, attempt to determine the consequences of human and other activities on the atmosphere. There have been technical and other difficulties and delays in the establishment phase of this activity and the initial reports of the work of the station having been slow in preparation. The Committee was concerned at this delay and at the possible effect of contracting out the day to day operations of the station. Accordingly it recommended that the annual report of the station be tabled in the Parliament.

3. It is, of course, intrinsic to the operation of the station that its results should be published and made known widely to the scientific community. There is no formal obligation for the station to produce an annual report since it is only one element of the whole departmental operation. Its activities are and will be reported in the annual report of the Department of Science and Technology which is now responsible for the station and that report tabled annually. Preparation and dissemination of the research and observational results will be an important part of the contract arrangement and the reports will continue to be issued at appropriate intervals. However, unlike departmental reports which generally relate to activities the BAPS report is in the nature of a scientific, technical report and is designed for a specialist audience. Accordingly whilst accepting the need to report the work of BAPS in a detailed and timely fashion the Government does not consider it appropriate to table it formally in the Parliament apart from that reference to it in the annual report.

4. The ABLS was originally established at US expense to launch moderate sized balloons for monitoring radiation levels in the stratosphere. After the program terminated in 1974 the equipment was transferred to Australian responsibility on the understanding that the Department would continue to provide a service to local and overseas scientists. Attempts were made subsequently to interest a range of local and overseas users to develop a cost-effective facility. In the event the US National Science Foundation contributed one third of the cost and Australia met the balance.

5. During the 1970's there was a trend to flying larger balloons, 1 000 000m3 in volume with payloads up to several tonnes: in addition most users wished to fly from Alice Springs rather than Mildura and some facilities had to be established there.

6. The service was criticised by both local and overseas users and it appears that a substantial investment would be needed to bring the service to a satisfactory standard. This combined with the very few local users meant that the research programs were very expensive for Australia and at the same time were not rated of sufficiently high priority to justify the further substantial investment needed. There appeared also to be too small a total workload to maintain a first class launch team trained to the high degree of skill required. Accordingly the Government decided to close the station down but to permit overseas teams, e.g. from the USA to use the facilities at their expense if they so desired.

7. The Committee believes it is important for Australia to maintain such a facility and has recommended that this take place. It was also recommended that the Government reactivate the idea of an international consortium to operate the facility, or attach a trained team to a suitable organisation in Australia whichever is the most cost-effective.

8. The Department of Science and Technology has approached overseas countries to contribute to an international consortium so far without success. Nevertheless it would be prepared to consider any reasonable proposal. Discussions are still in progress with the appropriate agencies in the U.K. and the USA. However, the Department doubts that a sufficient workload can be developed to maintain an efficient launch team and considers that the most practical solution is for Australian scientists to take advantage of visiting overseas launch teams. Accordingly the Government does not intend to maintain the facility in view of the very small number of local users but is prepared to consider a consortium, which will not require the use of departmental manpower if a feasible proposal is submitted.

9. The final matter referred to the funding of CSIRO. The Committee believed that it was essential that an organisation such as CSIRO should critically examine its research policies and activities to ensure that they are relevant to Australia's needs but expressed its concern that the work of CSIRO may have been harmed by restraints on staff numbers and funds. The Committee was concerned that CSIRO was being forced by resource restrictions to reduce and abandon significant areas of research and recommended that its operating appropriation be initially increased at the rate of the increase in the Consumer Price Index. The Committee recommended that the Government should then investigate claims that the cost of conducting scientific research increased at a rate greater than the increase in the CPI and that, if substantiated, recommended that the CSIRO operating appropriation be increased by at least that rate.

10. The Government recognises the important contribution CSIRO is making to Australia's scientific and technological development. However, the issues raised by the Committee need to be considered in the context of the Government's expenditure determination processes which recognise a wide variety of influences , including price indexes, which have to be balanced against the need to pursue particular economic objectives. In recent years expenditure restraint has been a fundamental aspect of the Government's budgetary approach and CSIRO has not been alone in being required to adjust its expenditure programs in line with the limited resources available.

11. Acceptance of the Committee's recommendations would imply a preparedness, on the part of the Government, to place CSIRO in a privileged position compared to other Departments and Authorities. Acceptance would also establish precedent for the treatment of other programs which would seriously limit the Government's flexibility in determining outlays to meet particular Budgetary requirements. Despite the importance of science to Australia's development I would not believe it proper for the Government to take such an approach.
12. The Government appreciates the effort of the Committee in reviewing these important matters. A schedule of the recommendations and comments on them follows.
No.
Recommendation
Response
Baseline Air Pollution Station (BAPS)

In view of the proposed contracting out of BAPS, the Committee believes it is important that the annual report be continued, and that it be produced with a minimum of delay. So that the Parliament can continue to monitor the operations of BAPS after contracting out the Committee RECOMMENDS that its annual report be tabled in Parliament. (Para 2.15)
Not accepted.

However, observational results will still be published and the Departmental Annual Report will include reference to the work of BAPS. The work of BAPS is only one of a great many programs whose results are published in the normal way but which are not tabled in the Parliament. The latter process is reserved for major reports, e.g. from Departments or Statutory Authorities.
Scientific Balloon Launching Facilities
The Committee believes it is important that Australia maintains a facility for the launching of scientific balloons including large balloons and RECOMMENDS that this take place. (Para 2.45)
Not accepted.

A facility such as ABLS is only required to launch medium and large balloons. Small balloons can and are launched by ad hoc teams. There are insufficient users for the medium and large balloons to maintain a viable launch crew and for Australia to bear that expense.

The Committee RECOMMENDS that the Government should examine the options of reactivating the international consortium proposal or attaching a trained balloon launching team to a suitable organisation in Australia and implement that which is found to be the most cost effective. (Para 2.57)
Accepted.
The Government will consider any proposition for a consortium.
CSIRO Operating Appropriation

The Committee is dissatisfied with the level of resources supplied to the CSIRO. The Committee RECOMMENDS that the CSIRO operating appropriation should initially be increased at the rate of the increase of the Consumer Price Index. The Government should then investigate the claims of the CSIRO that the costs of conducting scientific research increase at a rate of two to three per cent greater than the increase in the CPI. If in a wider study for the years beyond 1978-79, the CSIRO claims are substantiated the Committee RECOMMENDS that the CSIRO operating appropriation should be increased by at least that rate. (Para 3 .19)
Not accepted.

Expenditure restraint has been a fundamental aspect of the Government's budgetary processes in recent years and all Departments and agencies have been required to adjust their programs in line with the limited resources available. The proposal would put CSIRO in a privileged position compared with other agencies and limit the Government's flexibility in developing annual budgets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I would like to make a few comments about the statement. Earlier today I suggested that, when tabling a committee report, the Government's response to such a report should be provided to the Chairman of the committee at least a day before the tabling of the Government's response in the chamber. I said that for a very good reason. I received the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment about an hour ago and I have not had a chance to examine it in any great detail. I think that in future it would be most helpful to committee chairmen if such a procedure applied. It would enable us to respond far more effectively.

I note from the Government's response that only one of our recommendations has been accepted. It deals with the facilities for launching scientific balloons. We recommended that the Government examine options of reactivating the international consortium proposal for attaching a trained balloon launching team to a suitable organisation in Australia and implement that option which is found to be most cost effective. The Government has said that it will consider any proposition for a consortium, but I believe that we need a better response than that. The Government ought to examine the options and come forward with a more positive statement.

As far as the rejection of our other propositions is concerned I can only say that one in particular is a modest request. I refer to the Committee's recommendation that research funds for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation ought to be increased at least at the rate of increase of the consumer price index. The Government has rejected that recommendation, maintaining that it would put the CSIRO in a favourable position compared with other departments. I suggest that with respect to research work in Australia it is most important to recognise that we cannot afford Australia's research effort to lag behind. We are in a position to lead the world in many areas of research. This is important both from an international point of view and an Australian point of view. I stress that the Committee made what we believe to be a responsible recommendation that research funding should be increased at least to the level of the consumer price index. Further examination of the importance of research work being undertaken and the need for further funding should be considered as a matter of urgency in the near future. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRADE AND COMMERCE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Australia's Forestry and Forest Products Industries: Government Response-Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a ministerial statement relating to the Government response to the report on Australia's forestry and forest products industries and to have the statement incorporated in Hansard. The statement also comments on reports of the Industries Assistance Commission on wood and articles of wood and the Forest Products Industries Advisory Council on Australia's forest products industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Mr President, I wish to report to the Senate on the Government's responses to the Senate Standing Comittee on Trade and Commerce (Senate Committee) report on Australia's Forestry and Forest Products Industries; the Industries Assistance Commission's (IAC) report on Wood and Articles of Wood; and the Forest Products Industries Advisory Council (FPIAC) report on Australia's Forests Products Industries.

In June 1978 the Senate referred to the Senate Committee, the matter of 'all aspects of Australia's forestry and forest products industries' for investigation and report. The Senate Committee held many public hearings, conducted extensive inspections and considered a large number of submissions. The final report is comprehensive and contains recommendations covering a wide range of issues. The report was tabled in November 1981 in this place by Senator Archer, the Chairman of the Committee.

The FPIAC report discusses the influence of long-term factors on the development of the forest products industries and presents an industry view of the desirable course for future developments. The report examines each sector in detail and makes a number of recommendations, some of which are directed to the Commonwealth.

The IAC report covers the major forest products industries with the exception of pulp, paper and furniture. Part of the reference to the IAC called for a report within 60 days on assistance to certain wooden louvred goods. That report was received by the Government and in December 1980 it announced that it had accepted the IAC's recommendation that no short-term assistance be afforded the local production of louvred goods. The IAC's final report was received by the Government in August 1981.

In October 1981 the Government announced that a decision on the IAC report was to be deferred so that it could be considered along with the Senate Committee report and the FPIAC report. The deferment would allow long-term policies for the industries to be formulated after full consideration of the proposals and recommendations of each of the three reports.
The Government has now examined all three reports and I would like to mention briefly some of the major issues which are explained in more detail in the Government's responses.

Mr President, the Senate Committee's recommendations deal principally with forestry and the forest resource for which State governments have the prime responsibility. However, there are some topics covered by the report which involve Commonwealth responsibilities.

These include recommendations on public financial assistance to private industrial forestry, taxation treatment of forestry, assistance to the local production of wood and articles of wood, trans-Tasman trade in forest products, Commonwealth departmental responsibilities for forestry and forest products and Commonwealth training in wood technology.

The Senate Committee and the FPIAC in their respective reports have brought into sharp focus the special characteristics of the forestry and forest products industries which have important implications for the Commonwealth Government in its development and administration of policies for forest product industries and for the States.

Both reports point to the necessity of careful forest planning to ensure that timber availability neither markedly exceeds nor falls below the market demand at any given time, which they consider would result in a misallocation in the nation's resources or a lost opportunity for the nation's development.

To help achieve this purpose the Government has decided that the Ministers for Industry and Commerce and Primary Industry should work with the States, private growers and the forest products industries to establish a framework which facilitates improved cooperation and coordination within the forestry and forest products industries.

As a starting point the two Ministers will consult with the States, private growers and the forest products industries on the establishment of a single representative body to advise the Commonwealth Government on forestry and forest industries matters. It is envisaged that this body would replace the advising and coordination activities of the two major existing bodies providing advice to the Government, namely the FPIAC and the Australian Forestry and Forest Industries Conference (AFFIC). The major charter of this new body would be to facilitate a coordinated national cooperative approach to forestry and the development of the forest products industries.

However, the Government believes it is important that individual authorities and companies take decisions on such matters as planting, and timber production and utilisation in the light of their own commercial assessments. The basis of this commercial decision making will be enhanced in a climate of improved cooperation and coordination. The longer term assistance arrangements decided by the Government following consideration of the IAC's report on Wood and Articles of Wood will provide an important part of the future operating framework for the forestry and forest products industries.

It is important for realistic forestry planning that all parties have access to regularly updated comprehensive information on wood supply, demand and price trends and forecasts, domestically and internationally. This need has been recognised at Commonwealth, State and industry levels and initiatives have been taken to develop progressively a much improved flow of such information. The input is being provided by the States, the Commonwealth and by industry. The Government will continue to support this cooperative work. The new body, which the Government proposes, will have an important part to play.

Within the forest products industries it is not only imperative that the raw material supply be adequate and competitive, but also that the end-use industries strive for improved efficiency and competitiveness, compared with other countries, to ensure that Australia's forest resources are utilised to their optimum. It was in this context that the Government examined the form and level of assistance to apply to the goods covered by the IAC's report on Wood and Articles of Wood.
Mr President, the Government has considered the IAC's recommendations together with more recent information provided by interested parties.
The Government has taken its decisions on the IAC's recommendations and these will be announced shortly when the Administrative arrangements to implement them have been completed.
Mr President, the FPIAC has indicated it is in broad agreement with the conclusions and recommendations of the Senate report. However, there are some important differences.

The FPIAC does not agree with the Senate Committee's view that the rate of softwood plantation establishment should be sharply reduced. The FPIAC believes the Senate Committee overestimated the future supply of saw logs from Australian forests and under estimated demand, particularly export potential.

The FPIAC was also concerned that the Senate Committee did not lend other than qualified support to the need for the establishment of a national forestry policy. Another important area of disagreement was with the Senate Committee's recommendation concerning the responsibilities of the Departments of Industry and Commerce and Primary Industry.
Mr President, issues relating to the Administrative Arrangements Orders raised by the Senate Committee are under consideration by the Prime Minister.

Mr President, in conclusion I would like to say that the Government recognises the importance of the forestry and forest products industries and has welcomed the opportunity to respond to these reports. The responses which the Government has made and the decisions which are to be implemented have all been given careful consideration. I am satisfied that these decisions are the best possible , given that a balance needs to be reached within the framework of existing Government policies, between the interests of forestry and the forest products industries, the users of the products and the community.

However, there are a number of areas covered by the recommendations, particularly those of the Senate Committee, where the Commonwealth Government has no direct jurisdiction. The Government has therefore suggested that the State Forestry authorities and the Australian Forestry Council give these particular recommendations their careful attention and consider the Government's comments.
Details of the Government's responses to the Senate Committee report are as follows:
RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRADE AND COMMERCE ON AUSTRALIA'S FORESTRY AND FOREST PRODUCTS INDUSTRIES
Recommendation
Response
1. Recommendations primarily involving Commonwealth responsibilities
(a) Government administrative and consultative arrangements
(i) Commonwealth departmental responsibilities Recommendation 14 (Para 96)
The functions presently performed by the Department of Industry and Commerce in respect of the forest products industries be transferred to the Forestry Branch of the Department of Primary Industry.
Issues relating to the Administrative Arrangements Orders raised by the Committee are under consideration by the Prime Minister.
Recommendation 15 (Para 96)

Consequent upon acceptance of the previous recommendation, the staff and facilities of the Forestry Branch of the Department of Primary Industry be expanded commensurate with its increased responsibilities.
(ii) Advisory and consultative bodies Recommendation 16 (Para 97)
Industries and interest groups take the initiative in reducing the number of advisory bodies at the federal level.

Following the re-organisation of sub-committees of the Standing Committee of the Australian Forestry Council (AFC) which resulted in the formation of the Australian Forestry and Forest Industries Conference (AFFIC), there are now only two bodies besides the AFC itself tendering policy advice to the Commonwealth relating to forestry and forest products industries i.e. the Forests Products Industries Advisory Council and AFFIC. The FPIAC provides its advice on the forest products industries to the Minister for Industry and Commerce while AFFIC reports to the Minister for Primary Industry and State Ministers responsible for forestry, through the AFC.

The Government has decided that the two Ministers should consult with the States , private growers and the forest products industries on the establishment of a single representative body to advise the Commonwealth Government on forestry and forest industries matters.
(iii) Statistics Recommendation 20 (Para 106)
The Australian Forestry Council investigates the compilation and dissemination of statistical information in respect of the forestry and forest products industries, having particular regard to
(a) the information requirements of government agencies and private industry;
(b) the appropriate agencies responsible for the collection and publication of such information.

Information requirements can be viewed as falling in two separate but related categories. The first comprises the statistical information needed by industry and government agencies for making decisions on current and short-term issues. Current adequate and reliable statistics are needed for this purpose.

The second category comprises the supply/demand forecasts and trends analysis required for longer term planning. The studies required to develop that kind of information also depend heavily on the availability of adequate and reliable industry and trade statistics covering lengthy periods of time.

Commonwealth and State Departments and industry are currently reviewing their requirements for statistics on forestry and forest products with a view to ensuring that the information needs of Governments and industry are met.
(iv) Training Recommendation 21 (Para 109)

The National Timber Industry Training Committee, in concert with the Timber Industry Training Committees and Technical and Further Education authorities in each State, reviews the adequacy of courses offered in wood technology with a view to establishing, in suitably located technical colleges in all States, a course which has a common syllabus, is appropriate to the industries' needs and is recognised by the Institute of Wood Science.
Recommendation 22 (Para 109)

The Australian Forestry Council reviews the facilities available for the training of forest technicians throughout Australia with a view to encouraging the establishment of suitable training facilities in New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania.

Establishment and development of formal course content and common core curricula are primarily matters for Technical and Further Education (TAFE) Authorities. Changes within the industry and development of its training needs require that course content and facilities made available to this industry are constantly monitored.

In 1982 the Government made available $100,000 under the particular purpose recurrent grants program of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's Technical and Further Education Council to foster co-operation between two or more States in activities such as curriculum development and making Technical and Further Education programs more accessible and relevant.

The National Training Council has considered a submission from the National Timber Industry Training Council and will be seeking approval for a training development grant to facilitate industry-TAFE liaison for development of common core curricula in wood technology.
(b) Government funding of forestry Recommendation 1 (Para 20)

In any future agreements between the Commonwealth and the States for the funding of forest development, preferential consideration be given to the public financial assistance of private industrial forestry.

Subsequent to the Review of Commonwealth Functions the Government decided to discontinue Commonwealth expenditure on forestry upon termination of the programs authorised by the Softwood Forestry Agreements Act and the Tasmanian Native Forestry Agreement Acts in 1981-82 and 1982-83 respectively.

Should further consideration be given in the future to Commonwealth participation in the public funding of forestry development, proposals for assistance to the private sector would be evaluated in the light of government policies and circumstances at that time.
(c) Government assistance to the forest products industries
(i) Tariff assistance Recommendation 17 (Para 99)

In view of the present difficult economic conditions facing the mouldings and wood based panel products industries, and recognising that structural adjustment is presently taking place in the industries, the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs defers for a period of 5 years any reductions in tariffs applying to mouldings, particleboard, hardboard and plywood.

The Government deferred the decision on the Industries Assistance Commission ( IAC) report on Wood and Articles of Wood to enable it to be considered with the recommendations of the Senate Committee and the FPIAC reports.

Details of the Customs tariff changes and other related changes arising from the Government's decisions will be announced shortly when the administrative arrangements to implement them have been completed.
(ii) Import competition from New Zealand Recommendation 18 (Para 100)
The Minister for Trade and Resources
(a) investigates the extent of the New Zealand Government's financial support of that country's exports of forest products to Australia; and
(b) determines if such support is consistent with the terms of the New Zealand/ Australia Free Trade Agreement.

The Government is fully aware of the Australian forest products industries' concern at the current trading relationship between Australia and New Zealand in respect of forest products including New Zealand's use of performance based export incentives and its import licensing system.

On 10 November 1982 the Government announced that it had approved new arrangements to govern trans-Tasman trade between Australia and New Zealand which will enter into force on 1 January 1983. These arrangements, inter alia, make provision for completely eliminating New Zealand's import licensing by 1995 at the latest and halving performance based export incentives for trans-Tasman trade in 1985, with further reductions of 25% in 1986 and 1987.

In addition, an industry which feels it is being injured by dumped or subsidised imports has recourse to the procedures, including anti-dumping and countervailing action, available under Australia's anti-dumping legislation.

The New Zealand Government's support of that country's exports of forest products is not inconsistent with the New Zealand/Australia Free Trade Agreement as the use of export incentives is not specifically prohibited.
(d) Taxation Recommendation 19 (Para 103)

Within six months of the tabling of this report the Treasurer initiates an examination of all aspects of taxation as they apply to the forestry and forest products industries, having particular regard for
(a) the long-term nature of production forestry;
(b) taxation disincentives to the management of private forests for wood production in perpetuity;
(c) the allowable deduction of forest expenditure from assessable income for taxation purposes; and
(d) sales tax on equipment used in forest operations.

Examination of the taxation treatment of the forestry industry could only be meaningful if done in the context of the taxation treatment afforded other industries. In this regard, certain taxation provisions for industry generally were only recently reviewed by the Government following receipt of a report by the Industries Assistance Commission on Certain Budgetary Assistance to Industry .

The BAE is currently examining a number of taxation matters applicable to this industry. Upon completion of the study the Government will consider the need for further action. The Government has also received a submission on the matter from Tasmania.
2. Recommendations primarily involving State Government responsibilities
(a) Self-sufficiency Recommendation 2 (Para 30)

The rate of new softwood plantation establishment, both plantings and replantings be reduced to the extent that the average annual rate for the years 1976-1990 does not exceed 20,700 hectares, as recommended by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.
Recommendation 3 (Para 30)
Decision about future Commonwealth funding of softwood forestry be consequent upon further reports by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics on the desirable rate of plantation establishment.

The goal of achieving net self-sufficiency by the end of the century achieved wide support during the 1960's under circumstances very different to those which prevail today. Now, there is in the forest and forest products sectors considerable questioning of and outright opposition to a goal of net self- sufficiency; views are being expressed that Australia's export potential in forest products should not be underrated.
AFC has rejected the goal of net self-sufficiency as being irrelevant to the practical commercial planning of production levels.
Recommendation 4 (Para 33)
The Australian Forestry Council conduct a thorough review of the management of Australia's efforts to achieve net self-sufficiency in wood production, having particular regard for:
(a) the co-ordination of softwood plantation development with the installation of adequate processing capacity;
(b) the future role of the private sector in both softwood plantation development and softwood processing.

The Government supports the view that decisions on forest planting, wood production and utilisation are best undertaken by individual authorities and firms in the light of their own commercial assessments.

Individual decision makers do need, however, to base their decisions on the best available information on current and future supply and demand. To that end, work is progressing within State and Commonwealth Departments and elsewhere on improving demand forecasting procedures and towards publishing consolidated State wood production plans and demand forecasts based on common methodology. The Government considers that availability of such information will assist that State and private forestry interests in determining planting rates appropriate to their individual commercial circumstances and will facilitate the co- ordination of Australia's wood production with the output of forest products.

The Government will continue to work through the proposed new body which has already been mentioned with the forestry and forest products industries and the States to facilitate such a co-operative approach aimed at ensuring that planning and development decisions are consistent with sound economic principles and the efficient allocation of resources in the overall national interest.
(b) Forest service accounting and royalties Recommendation 5 (Para 45)
The Australian Forestry Council examines and makes recommendations to the State governments in respect of
(a) the most appropriate accounting procedures to be adopted by the forest services;

(b) the classification and treatment in the forest service accounts of all aspects of income and expenditure, having particular regard for the separation of the costs of forest management for commercial wood production from those of other forest service functions.

The Government supports the aims of the recommendations but points out that these are matters for determination by the individual States. The Government commends the recommendations and the principles underlying them to the States.
Recommendation 6 (Para 47)

The Australian Forestry Council strongly urges the forest service in each State to adopt as its method of royalty determination that recommended by the Finance Panel of the Forestry and Wood-based Industries Development Conference.
Recommendation 7 (Para 49)

The royalties applying to rare and valuable tree species, such as Huon pine, red cedar and their equivalents, be increased to reflect their true cost of production and rarity on a national basis as compared with the more numerous and productive eucalypt species.
Recommendation 11 (Para 58)

The margin between royalties applying to rainforest species and those to other species be increased to ensure that rainforest timbers are used sparingly and only for purposes where other timbers and other materials are not suitable substitutes.
(c) Forest management planning Recommendation 8 (Para 54)
Each State forest service publish at regular intervals, a forest management plan. The plan should:
(a) be formulated with the benefit of full public comment on its intentions;
(b) describe the detailed management regime to be adopted for each and every area of forest under the service's control;
(c) be explicit in its requirements so that those responsible for its implementation are in no doubt as to their responsibilities;
(d) be binding for a specified period.

Although State forest authorities generally make available to the public, statements of management policies and information on State forests, publication of 'forest management plans' would provide both the forest products industries and the general public with access to a wider range of forest planning and management information and practices than is presently the case.

The Government supports the concept of providing information to the public on forest management. It notes that this would be consistent with the principles underlying its environmental assessment policy and would allow more informed debate on environmental and resource use issues.
(d) Rainforests Recommendation 9 (Para 57)
All areas of rainforest in Australia be conserved, maintaining the characteristic diversity and vitality of the original forests.
Conserving Australia's rainforests has national implications, reflected in the Commonwealth's decision to develop a National Conservation Strategy for Australia jointly with the States.
Recommendation 10 (Para 57)
Where publicly-owned rainforests are managed for timber production, management prescriptions must include as a minimum standard
(a) the attainment of sustained yield as a high priority;
(b) selective logging;
(c) canopy retention provisions appropriate to the rainforest type;
(d) marking by forest service staff of each tree to be removed;
(e) tree marking to ensure the maintenance of the species mix of the forest in its original proportions.

These matters are the direct responsibility of State Governments. However, the Government generally supports these two recommendations in so far as they are consistent with the principle of sustained utilisation of natural resources which underlies the proposed National Conservation Strategy for Australia. The recommendations also give recognition to the highly significant environmental values of rainforests.
(e) Harvesting Recommendation 12 (Para 60)

Forest management specifications containing environmental protection prescriptions should be regarded as a mandatory minimum requirement to be augmented where required at the discretion of the forestry officer on the spot; and without real incentive or control, forest management practices for environmental protection will operate at a minimum standard.
Recommendation 13 (Para 81)
The State forest services maintain strict control of removals from Crown land to ensure that logs destined for woodchip mills are indeed being directed to the highest value end-use.
While the management and control of public forests is the direct responsibility of the states, the Commonwealth has powers in respect of export woodchips.

Consequently, there is a direct Commonweaalth responsibility for environmental assessment where forest operations within the states are associated with the export of woodchips. There is close consultation between the Commonwealth and individual states concerned on environmental protection and resource aspects of such operations.

The Government supports the continuation of the existing co-operative arrangements to ensure the observance of conditions in Commonwealth export approvals relating to environmental safeguards and the source and nature of the pulpwood to be exported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I have had an opportunity to have only a very brief look at this statement but I believe that the response is less than we had hoped for and is, in some respects , less than adequate. The main thrust of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce on Australia's forestry and forest products industries was aimed at better planning and better development of the industry for the future. The fundamental area that that involves is the necessity for timber supply and the use to which it will be put. The question of net self- sufficiency-that is, what we produce, plus what we buy, less what we export-is, of course, paramount. I was somewhat surprised to find that on page 5 of the statement it is said that the question of self-sufficiency is irrelevant. I do not see how the fundamental point of the production of a product of this nature and the planning of what we will use and what we will save can be treated as irrelevant to the whole industry. While we have that thinking behind the industry generally it will be very hard to plan for the economics in the future.

The production of timber and the planting of trees has been under considerable discussion for many years. It comes back to a choice of planting native timbers or exotic timbers-mainly radiata pine. The amount of planting has been questioned for a long time. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has undertaken intensive studies. Conference a few years ago made an intensive study of this aspect. When the Committee recommended that plantings should be adjusted to the demand, we again received the reply that our figures did not mean anything and that they were not accepted. But while we have been told that the figures were not accepted, we were not told what figures may be accepted. I believe that we are entitled to be told where our figures are wrong. The Committee put in two years' work on this report. I believe that the information that we used was the best information available. We have certainly not been given any information to the contrary. In fact the statement that we have just been given states:
. . . the Senate Committee overestimated the future supply of saw logs from Australian forests and underestimated demand, particularly export potential.

I believe we are entitled to be told why that is believed to be the case. We only have to look at the present situation to see that we have difficulty in competing with imported timbers, let alone exports to other countries. I believe other countries will have a marked influence on the trading of timber world-wide . I do not think Australia is going to be one of those countries for many years. The exotic timbers have to be used because of their rate of growth. They are not like the eucalypt which can wait 100 years in a situation of oversupply. I believe that if we are to expect the local industry to make a meaningful input into the planning and management of forestry, it has to be provided with the best information available. This has to be hard information and not just general assertions such as those we have been given.

The report says that there is going to be a better flow of information and I am very pleased about that. I am just wondering when this flow of information will start. I have been waiting for 12 months for information on the matters that we have been discussing. If I were involved in the forestry business I would need my information within 12 months. I really do not see how forestry organisations, be they large companies or private foresters, can make judgments and how they can do the best possible job for the Australian industry without those figures. The only comment in the report on this matter is that the Government believes it is important that individual authorities and companies take decisions on such matters as planting and timber production and utilisation in the light of their own commercial assessments. But those commercial assessments must surely be influenced by the provision of the best information available to the industry and I do not see how reasonable judgments can be made without those facts.

We are not told from where the export potential about which the report talks will come. I believe, again, that to enable the long term planning of the industry, we need to have this information which will have an enormous effect on the price that will be paid to the producers of private timber. We have to know whether there will be a market before we go ahead and plant large areas of timber. We do not want to prop up the industry with subsidies. It should not be necessary to do this. All sorts of concessions should not have to be paid. However, a judgment has to be made as to how much timber is going to be supplied and what sort of price will be paid. I do not think that the response dealt adequately with the questions we raised in respect of training, private forestry funding and various taxation measures. I hope that we are able to get some better information in the near future. I seek leave to continue my remarks later .
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Like Senator Archer, I too am concerned about the Government's response but unlike Senator Archer I have had very little time at all to look at that response. However, I would like to refer to that part of the response which deals with the import of timber from New Zealand. I have spoken in the Senate on quite a few occasions about this problem . In my quick reading of the Government's response in regard to import competition from New Zealand, I note that the Government says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is fully aware of the Australian forest products industries' concern at the current trading relationship between Australia and New Zealand in respect of forest products including New Zealand's use of performance based export incentives and its import licensing system.
The Government goes on to say:

On 10 November 1982 the Government announced that it had approved new arrangements to govern trans-Tasman trade between Australia and New Zealand which will enter into force on 1 January 1983. These arrangements, inter alia, make provision for completely eliminating New Zealand's import licensing by 1995 at the latest and halving performance-based export incentives for trans-Tasman trade in 1985 with further reductions of 25 per cent in 1986 and 1987.

In addition, an industry which feels it is being injured by dumped or subsidised imports has recourse to the procedures, including anti-dumping and countervailing action available under Australia's anti-dumping legislation.

The New Zealand Government's support of that country's export of forest products is not inconsistent with the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement as the use of export incentives is not specifically prohibited.

The Softwood Forestry Council spelt out in detail in a submission to the Bureau of Customs what it thought were the problems in respect of incentives being given to New Zealand timber companies. In brief they were: That New Zealand timber producers do not pay to the New Zealand Government anywhere near the amount of royalty which is paid by timber producers in Australia; New Zealand producers are given a very high level of export incentive to export their timber ; and on top of that, they are given very good freight concessions. If we add these three factors together we can see that New Zealand exporters have a distinct advantage over Australian timber producers.

I am concerned about the problem-I speak about my own State although this is prevalent in other States-of the very great downturn in employment and production of timber products in the south-east of South Australia. The timber industry is the main source of income in this area. I would have thought that this Government would have taken some action in respect of this great problem and not just fallen back on NAFTA which was the subject of an inquiry by a committee of which I was a member when I first came to this place. However, the Government cannot fall back on this agreement when imports are coming into this country to the great detriment not only of timber producers and people employed in the industry but also of small business people who are going down the drain at a rapid rate. This Government should take immediate action. I join with Senator Archer in criticising the Government for its lack of action. When this matter is again debated in the Senate I will have some harsh words to say about this matter if the Government does not take some action very shortly to try to eliminate the problems that exist in the south-east of South Australia in the softwood industry. I note that Senator Martyr from Western Australia is grinning and laughing about this matter. However, this is a matter of serious concern. Senator Martyr, a Government senator, shows that he has no concern for the people in the south-east of South Australia who, if they are lucky, are now working a four-day week. Others, who do not have a job, are losing their homes. Small businesses are losing income. They, too, are putting off employees because of this Government's inaction to prevent the import of New Zealand timber.

(2) Requests Sir John Minogue to edit such papers, after appropriate consultation with the Solicitor-General and the Crown Solicitor, so as to ensure the deletion therefrom of any material the publication of which would in his opinion prejudice the outcome of legal proceedings which have been, or may be, instituted against those alleged to have been involved in tax evasion or avoidance schemes.
(3) Directs Senators Chaney and Dame Margaret Guilfoyle to lay on the Table, as soon as possible, such papers in the form in which they have been edited by Sir John Minogue.

The effect of my motion, of course, is to direct the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to deliver certain papers to Sir John Minogue, Q.C., to edit those papers for subsequent tabling by Senators Chaney and Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in the Senate. The papers in question relate to the Government's consideration of legal proceedings against people involved in bottom-of-the-harbour and similar tax avoidance and evasion schemes. This is an appropriate curtain raiser for the resumption of the debate on the bottom-of-the-harbour recoupment legislation because it does focus attention squarely on the background to that legislation and, in particular, on the issue as to whether that legislation would ever have been necessary if the Government had acted in accordance with the law and in accordance with proper practice in the mid 1970s to take legal proceedings against these people when these schemes first came to its notice.

The papers that are in issue and described in this motion are essentially those that were described at greater length and subjected to previous debate on 23 September and more specifically on 14 October. They may be described very briefly as falling into two broad categories. In the first place there are legal opinions from Queen's Counsel and other documents of that kind showing strong reasons for believing that legal action, both criminal and civil, was available against those promoting and participating in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The second category of documents in the 14 sets of documents listed is a variety of documents, papers and other memoranda which will show equally clearly that the arguments against the availability of such legal action were feeble, insufficiently documented and insufficiently argued. That is our suspicion as to what those papers might contain, based on a description of some of them by Mr Costigan in his report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and based on the way in which they have also been described by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, in his successive statements on this general subject area. We cannot, of course, know precisely what is in them and just how devastating they are to the Government's case in this whole area until we see them.

It is because the Parliament has a proper role in scrutinising Executive behaviour and administration in these matters that we seek to see the papers to find out once and for all where the fault lay for this extraordinary scandal in Australian public administration which resulted in the loss of hundreds, possibly thousands, of millions of dollars. The papers in question were not included in the so-called telephone book which was tabled some weeks ago now for the obvious reason, it appears, that the Government is profoundly embarrassed by their content. There is no other reason why they should not be tabled and put into public domain, provided some appropriate sterilisation process occurs to ensure that there is nothing in the papers, in the form in which they are finally tabled and published, which could in fact prejudice the effective prosecution of proceedings against those involved. This, of course, is what this motion seeks to do.

Arguments for the procedure spelt out in this motion are essentially the same as those which were dealt with at some considerable length in this place on 14 October both by me in advancing a motion on that occasion and by Senator Chaney in resisting it. As a result I do not believe there is any necessity to prolong debate by repeating any of those arguments here today. I anticipate that if this motion is passed and if the Government persists with its opposition to it we will be met next with some formal claim by the Government of Executive privilege as a ground for refusing to deliver the documents in question to Sir John Minogue. That is something which, if it happens, of course will have to be debated and resolved by the Senate. I do not believe, however, that it is appropriate in this debate today to enter into the issues for and against Executive privilege. I understood Senator Chaney, from something he said in the course of the debate on 14 October, to agree with me in that respect. In essence , the debate today is simply a rerun, with a slightly different cast, of the debate that we had on 14 October and for that reason it need not be prolonged.

It remains only for me to draw the Senate's attention to the specific terms of this motion. It is, of course, in three parts. The first part of the motion is a direction by the Senate to Senator Chaney and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. They are singled out, of course, because of their respective responsibilities in this chamber, as representing, in the case of Senator Chaney, the Acting Attorney-General, and in the case of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, the Treasurer. They are the Ministers over whom the Senate has jurisdiction. The requirement of this part of the motion is that those two Ministers deliver the papers which are under their respective control to the Judge who is designated in a subsequent part of the motion but to deliver the papers only after preliminary sterilisation of them has occurred by way of meeting the requirements, such as they are, of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. There has been much argument about just what section 16 does require by way of secrecy and an awful lot of nonsense has been talked in recent weeks and months about it. However, it is undeniable that section 16 does in fact require that the names of individuals and other presumably identifying characteristics of individuals be deleted from material within the possession of the Australian Taxation Office before it is disclosed or produced to persons other than those with a duty, of an immediate kind presumably, to receive it. There may be an argument as to whether section 16 applies at all in the case of a Senate request , but that is not an argument that I seek to run on this occasion. It is appropriate I believe and the Senate believes--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is above the law; is that your point?

—No. It is a question as to the nature of the proper interpretation of section 16 and whether or not the Senate can properly be regarded as having a duty to deal with material of a kind which would in fact exempt it from the operation of section 16. That is not an argument that I seek to pursue. Since what is in issue is not the treatment of particular individuals but the basic legal and policy matters underlying it, I believe it is appropriate for the documents to be edited in a preliminary way for the purpose of satisfying the requirements of section 16. There may be some suggestion that the Senate cannot require the delivery of papers to anyone other than itself- that there should be no third party. Should that point be taken, I draw the attention of the Senate and of Senator Chaney to ample precedent in the United Kingdom for select committees of the Westminster Parliament vesting in third parties the power to inspect documents on the Parliament's behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the motion is a request to Sir John Minogue to act in the role of filter or editor of these documents. That follows references earlier to Mr Costigan playing that role and possibly also to a judge of the Federal Court designated by Sir Nigel Bowen. For one reason or another those earlier proposed arrangements have not borne fruit. In the motion that was passed on 14 October it was foreshadowed that a retired judge of Supreme Court status or above be given this role. When it became clear that the co-operation of the Federal Court was unlikely to be forthcoming, it was a matter of seeing who among the list of retired judges of that status might be available and willing to take on the task . I have had only sufficient conversation with Sir John Minogue to establish with him that he would not be unwilling to consider favourably the terms of this motion, if passed today.

I can tell the Senate that Sir John Minogue is an entirely appropriate person for this task. He has had a very distinguished career both at the Bar and on the Bench. He was appointed by the Menzies' Government to the Supreme Court of Papua New Guinea, subsequently assuming the Chief Justiceship of that Court. He subsequently came back to Australia and was a Hamer Liberal Government appointee to the Motor Accident Board of Inquiry and was subsequently the first Law Reform Commissioner in Victoria. I suggest that he is a man of great distinction and enormous experience, someone in whom the Senate and this nation can well repose the trust of doing this difficult job.

The final part of the motion is a direction to Senators Chaney and Dame Margaret Guilfoyle to table the papers, once edited. There is no need to pursue here and now the implications of any failure by them to observe the various instructions set out in the text of this motion. It is sufficient to say that the motion is in a form whereby the Ministers in question are brought squarely within the potential operation of the privilege and contempt jurisdiction of the Senate should they be minded to act against, without some other legal justification, the terms of this motion. I hope that despite the course of events so far, which have demonstrated a massive unwillingness on the part of the Government to co-operate in this process, the Government will not now resist the course of action that is here proposed. Certainly there can be no rational justification for it doing so. The truth of the matter is that the proposed filtering process will ensure that there is no conceivable risk to the administration of justice involved in the tabling of these documents and that the Government is resisting disclosure only because it has something to hide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter is beginning to seem like Senator Evans's toy.
—Alice in Wonderland.

—I note the interjection from Senator Haines about Alice in Wonderland and I share the views contained in that interjection. The Government opposes this latest sally of Senator Evans in his attempt to obtain certain legal opinions and to have them tabled in the Senate. Senator Evans has completed his claim that the refusal of the Government to produce these documents in some way indicates a cover up. I must therefore address myself again to the substance of the matter. This is a matter which I ask the Senate to consider very seriously. Important questions of public interest and of the interest of the Senate are involved. I do not believe that public interest or the interests of the Senate will be served by the sort of confrontation which Sentor Evans is seeking to engineer on what I regard as quite specious grounds. I can understand that Senator Evans hopes to gain political advantage by pursuing this matter. I suggest that that is neither a good nor a sufficient reason why the Senate as a whole should lend support to the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple reason that the Government has indicated for not believing that it should follow the course which has been suggested to it by Senator Evans in his series of motions is that we believe that this is an area where we have a responsibility to protect the public interest, in particular the public interest in the carrying-forward of prosecutions and other proceedings which relate to the contentious tax matters which have recently occupied so much of the time of the Senate. As indicated by my amendment to another motion a little while ago, it is the view of the Government that we should be engaging in debate on the substantive legislation before the Senate rather than on this side-show of Senator Evans's. I remind the Senate of what we are talking about in regard to this motion. We are talking about a series of documents which the Solicitor- General has indicated might prejudice important legal proceedings. I cannot go into detail with respect to legal proceedings which have already commenced because in no way do I wish to prejudice the proceedings which are being brought .

I inform the Senate that the documents referred to in items (i), (ii), (iii), ( v), (xi), (xii), (xiii) and (xiv) of the resolution of 23 September all relate to the Perth matter which was referred to in chapter 3, volume 1 of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The Perth matter referred to in chapter 3 is the Stirling court matter in respect of which proceedings have now been commenced against Messrs Brian Maher, Lloyd Errol Faint and Wilfrid Henry Tolhurst. Warrants for their arrests were executed on 29 October 1982 and bail has been granted. The charges in question are for conspiracy under section 86 (1) (b) and (e) of the Crimes Act to defeat the enforcement of a law of the Commonwealth and to defraud the Commonwealth. With respect to the list of documents that I have just particularised, we have the opinion of the Solicitor-General, the senior law officer of the Commonwealth-after the Attorney-General-and a man whose independence, legal skills and integrity have not been challenged, that it could prejudice the proceedings before the court. Those are proceedings in which one would have thought there would be a wide public interest that no prejudice should occur. The documents in items (iv) and (vi) on Senator Evans's list relate to a matter on which counsel has been briefed to advise with a view to the possibility of proceedings being taken.

The matter dealt with in item (vii) has been referred to the Special Prosecutor . With respect to the Special Prosecutor I suggest that the Senate should note that Mr Roger Gyles has been appointed. In less than two months he has established four investigation teams and two further teams will begin operations soon. About 20 tax investigators have been allocated or are in the course of being allocated to the Special Prosecutor. Twenty-three police officers have been seconded or are in the course of being seconded. The Special Prosecutor plans to launch court actions against major scheme promoters over the next two years. It is estimated that over 40 people are to be investigated. Police seconded to the Special Prosecutor travelled to Brisbane and were involved in the arrest of Mr Maher. The document in item (vii) relates to concerns which are presently being pursued with proper vigour by the Special Prosecutor.
