The opinion referred to in item (x) deals with issues that are relevant to proceedings or possible proceedings to which I have just referred. That is really central to the Government's attitude, which has been stated by me not just today but also in the debate on 14 October last, that the Government considers that it should not table documents which have not been cleared for that purpose by the Solicitor-General or the Commissioner for Taxation because they would be harmful to the administration of justice and because of the secrecy provisions contained in section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

It is the overriding concern of the Government to bring about appropriate legal proceedings in a situation where there is widespread and proper public concern about the activities of tax evasion and avoidance. As I said a few minutes ago, we have a Special Prosecutor who has been appointed to deal with bottom-of-the- harbour promoters. Proceedings have been commenced in one case. Four investigation teams have been established by the Special Prosecutor and two further teams are beginning operations. We have produced a vast amount of material which shows the timetabling of what was done by government which has amply exposed to public debate the Government's consideration of these matters. The only material which is being withheld is material which the Solicitor- General-whose position has not been challenged in this matter, whose integrity, independence and legal standing has not been challenged-has said might prejudice proceedings.

The third alternative which is now offered by the Opposition is that we should forgo the view of our senior professional adviser in favour of getting some opinion from a retired judge who, on my understanding, retired in 1974, who is 73 years of age and who has not been a judge for eight years. I just wonder what will be the next option which is pulled out of the hat by Senator Evans. I simply indicate that for the reasons which I have detailed in previous debates the Government does not believe that it is appropriate to transfer its responsibilities in this area to any other third party outside the Solicitor- General.

I agree with one thing that Senator Evans said. I do not believe this is an appropriate time to canvass possible claims of Executive privilege. That may be a matter for a debate at a later time on another day. I regard the approach of Senator Evans in this matter to be one of irresponsibility. That is clearly illustrated by the cavalier way in which he has treated the considerations which the Commissioner for Taxation raised in a statement which was brought down in this place in a previous debate on 14 October. That statement related to a report of a senior investigation officer to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Perth. The statement pointed out that the tabling of that document would be even more damaging than the tabling of legal opinions. It pointed out that a great many people are aware of the particular case dealt with and that in these circumstances any deletions from or alterations to the document to conceal identities or persons would not solve the problem presented by the resolution to the obligations of secrecy imposed by section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. In other words, once the parties are known the sort of deletion which is suggested would be meaningless. It is unavoidable that any information at all provided in a so-called sanitised version would offend against section 16. No attempt is made to address that problem. Whatever Senator Evans might say, its terms require a sanitised version of the document to be prepared and passed not by the custodian of the document but by the Minister representing the Treasurer- the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)-and a third person named in the motion. That third person does not come within any of the exceptions contained in section 16.

I do not propose to canvass again the constitutional issues which Senator Evans described as the high constitutional road taken by the Government. But I believe that there would be very few in the community who would not understand the simple point which is removed from any question of a high constitutional road and that is that the Government has a responsibility to bring proceedings in a proper way before the courts and that when we have the opinion of the Solicitor- General that material should not be disclosed then that is an opinion that we should be prepared to respect and to act on. I make no comment, and I do not wish anything I have said to be a comment on the worthiness of the particular person who has apparently after some conversation agreed that he might not be unwilling to be considered in the event that something happens. I simply say that that is obviously a very strange way to go about the serious business of ensuring that proper proceedings are brought before the court without risk of prejudice. I hope that on this occasion the Senate would reconsider the attitude which it adopted in previous votes on this matter, that it would cease what I regard as a by-play and get back to the serious business of legislating to avoid some of the difficulties which have occurred in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the first opportunity of being engaged in this debate which has been a saga in the Senate while I was overseas and since. Unfortunately, I did not get the opportunity to speak on the statement that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) put down on 14 October either. I regret that and I will make a comment or two on it. But that is not essential to the major issues today. I do not understand the persistence of Senator Evans in pressing as he does for this type of action-in going from one failure to another-and now endeavouring to resurrect a retired judge from Victoria, of whom I am aware, to serve a purpose which, as I will point out shortly, is an impossible purpose and one that should never be imposed on a person. I have noticed that, in fact, what the Government did in September was to table some 85 documents-a very substantial number of documents. As the Minister then pointed out in his statement of 14 October these were documents:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . which even on the most generous interpretation of what might have been tabled in the fullest freedom of information legislation would not normally have been available.

In other words, the Government had certainly gone beyond any requirements of freedom of information in making available those documents. The Government has taken views in regard to the danger which would be involved in fair trials of persons' actions, by their refusal to enter into the courses which Senator Evans has suggested one after another. The document which was put down by the Minister on 14 October is one in which naturally I, as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for some six years, am very interested.

I must say that I do not go along with some of the more whimsical extensions of the idea of separation of powers which, I think, would be suggested as denying this Senate the right to do certain things, the right to scrutinise and even the right to ask people to do certain things, such as is suggested here in the motion. I do not challenge that right; I, in fact, was here in the Senate in 1975 when the Senate insisted on bringing to the Bar of this Senate certain officers of the Government and questioning them. I am only sorry that what we did not do subsequently was adopt the minority report of that time on that investigation. If we did not get answers from them we could have taken action. I think the rights of the Senate should have been enforced in those days and should have been at least insisted on.

I still stand by the rights which I believe the Senate has. So far as that is concerned I do not accept some idea that by the separation of powers this Senate has not a very considerable right to scrutinise and busy itself about what happens in Executive government and whether Executive government is properly enforcing the laws of this country. That is one thing which the Senate has of right. The other thing-the more important thing here-is the insistence on this rather ridiculous scheme which now comes forward from Senator Evans. The same thing applied, of course, in the knockbacks which he had from Mr Costigan and from the Federal judges. In this motion the Opposition insists that the Government should send away the papers to a person who has no responsibility for Executive government in this country but who, in this case, is a retired judge. I do not want to say anything unkind. He is a retired judge who presided over, I suppose, the most peaceful little exercise in law reform in the last five years in Victoria. Very little of importance came out of that. But he may be quite capable of looking at documents. What is Senator Evans suggesting that he do? He will, in fact, be something like a special prosecutor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense-read the motion.

—I have read the motion. The honourable senator should not be so arrogant. What the motion is saying to the man is that he must have these documents and edit them. Of course, what he would need to have also is all the background material to determine, more or less as a prosecutor, what is relevant , what actions will be taken by the Government, whether these people are likely to be prosecuted by the Government--
—This is from the man who gave us freedom of information!

—We have already covered that; the honourable senator should have been listening. We ought surely to recognise that such a person would be in an impossible position unless he had all the records of government in regard to these possible prosecutions of people-not just the documents which Senator Evans is interested in having edited. It is not just a matter of editing; it is much more than that. It is giving away an executive function to a person who has no Commonwealth responsibility and insisting that all these things be made available to him. It is a ridiculous and preposterous thing for the Senate to continue to persist in this way. Executive government has demonstrated that it is proceeding with prosecutions and that these matters, on the advice of the Solicitor-General, ought not to be disclosed. I suggest that it is mere arrogance and pretence on the part of Senator Evans to persist in trying to find some person who might, if pressed, now take up this responsibility. The Government is quite right in its decision to resist this move. If some of the Ministers have to go to gaol in contempt because of this, I will happily visit them there and take them flowers but at least they will be doing it in a cause and in public duty. I hope that this motion will be defeated.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 September, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take advantage of the opportunity presented to the Senate by the debate on the Cotton Levy Bill and the Cotton Research Bill to draw the attention of the Senate to the consequences for Australian women of the Fraser Government's economic policies. Those consequences have been a deepening of disadvantage for Australian women and a serious rise in the level of inequality in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: The most pressing problem for women in Australia today is poverty. This problem is exacerbated by the high rate of unemployment amongst women, the lack of income security for women and an unfair share of the tax burden falling on women . Cutbacks in government services, implementation of the so-called user-pays principle in areas such as health and the withdrawal from vital areas such as women's emergency services by the Federal Government all have contributed to what sociologists now call the feminisation of poverty.

Let us pay some attention to the effect on women of income and taxation measures. Figures published as a part of the 1982 Budget Papers give comparative taxable incomes for males and females for 1980-81. They show that, while 13.2 per cent of male taxpayers earned less than $7,000 per annum, 29.8 per cent of female taxpayers had income under the $7,000 per annum level whereas, at the other end of the scale, 37 per cent of men had incomes over $15,000 per annum and the comparable figure for women was 13 per cent. The source of these figures is Budget Paper No. 11-Income Tax Statistics. These figures show clearly that women are concentrated in the low income brackets.

Of course, it is in these low income brackets that the largest increases in taxation have occurred under the Fraser Government. For those people on 75 per cent of average weekly earnings-currently that figure is $13,440 per annum-the proportion of income paid in tax since 1975-76 has gone up by 4.3 per cent. Since 1975-76, for those on average weekly earnings, which are currently $17,920 per annum, the proportion of income tax paid has risen by 2.2 per cent. But for those on twice average weekly earnings-that is, on $35,840 per annum-the comparable rise has been only 1.1 per cent. For those on the massive salaries of around six times average weekly earnings-that is, about $112,000 a year-there has actually been a reduction of 2.4 per cent in the proportion of income tax paid. So it is very clear that the Fraser Government has pursued taxation policies which shift the burden of taxation towards low income earners. Of course, the point of what I am saying today is that that shift is a shift towards women earners because the majority of women fall into the low income earning category.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are supposed to eat less, I think.

—And work harder. I wish to make some comments on the Government's current fad for salvaging our economy, namely, the wages freeze. One of the many criticisms to be made of this proposal is that a wages freeze, proposed in isolation as it is by the Fraser Government, would have a disproportionate impact on women. By itself, a wages freeze would have the same impact as a fierce hike in taxes and these virtual tax increases would have a regressive distributional impact-again on those on the lowest incomes. The majority of women workers are in that category and they would face the biggest increase. At the end of a 12-month wages freeze which started from now, a wage earner on 75 per cent of average weekly earnings would sustain an effective tax increase of 52 per cent. For a person on average weekly earnings, the effective increase would be 45 per cent. But, of course, for a person on three times the average weekly earnings, the effective tax increase would be only 24 per cent. So, clearly again, this proposal of the Federal Government, ill considered as it is and really an economic fad, is one which if implemented would be extremely regressive and thus extremely harsh in its effect on women wage earners.

SPEECH.PARA: Regressive policies-policies which push the poor further into poverty- constitute an attack on women. The Australian Labor Party is committed to achieve equality within our society and in particular to improve the disadvantaged position of Australian women. Policies such as a wages freeze, which would have a discriminatory effect on women and of course on all low income earners, will not be supported by the Australian Labor Party. It is worth pointing out also that the effect on women in the home of the proposed wages freeze would be disastrous. Women who are trying to manage to feed, clothe and generally cater for their families would of course be in a situation in which the housekeeping costs would go up every week but the income would be fixed and so the family would fall even further behind and in many cases, of course, that would mean that they would fall below the poverty line. The Labor Party also believes that a wages freeze will not work; it will not achieve the Government's stated ends. By reducing real spending power by over $6 billion in one year-that is an amount equal to two months retail sales nationally-a wages freeze would have a severely contractionary effect. By depressing demand, a wages freeze would be likely also to depress employment. It should be pointed out what the effect of this would be on the retail industry which is an area of high employment for women. The level of unemployment for women would rise catastrophically if such a proposal were implemented in the terms in which the Government seems to be interested in implementing it.

So, the proposed wages freeze is really just a desperate attempt by the Government to rescue its bankrupt Budget. The Budget, although brought down only three months ago, contained estimates for unemployment benefits which are now running over the original estimation by $600m-a figure confirmed, I believe, by the Treasurer and Acting Prime Minister, Mr Howard, just yesterday. If a wages freeze depresses employment, this figure could go much higher. When it is also considered that a wages freeze will depress government revenue-thus the Government will have less money with which to stimulate the economy-the whole proposal is revealed as totally self-defeating.

The rate of increase of women's unemployment, which slowed slightly earlier this year, has taken off again in the last quarter. The October unemployment figures show female unemployment at 10.6 per cent of those looking for full time work, in seasonally adjusted terms, compared with the rate of 7.4 per cent for males. As I have often said in this place, women make up the bulk of the hidden unemployed; that is, those people not shown up in the unemployment statistics because they are not eligible for unemployment benefits. In the 15 to 19 year age bracket, the gap between males and females is even wider with unemployment rates of 23.2 per cent for females and 17.7 per cent for males. At this stage, that means about one in four teenage girls are unemployed and looking for jobs. The 1981 census figures showed that almost 185,000 families in Australia have female breadwinners and a much larger number of women make an essential contribution to family incomes. Despite this, the Government has taken no steps to address the record high levels of unemployment amongst women.

Another indication of the extent to which women live in poverty is the percentage of female pensioners and beneficiaries. Sixty-six per cent of recipients of social security pensions or benefits, excluding unemployment benefit, are women. The vast majority of single parents-97 per cent of recipients of the single parent's benefit-are women. Faced with this catalogue of disadvantage suffered by Australian women, the Fraser Government has consistently failed to pursue policies which would assist women to break the cycle of poverty and move towards a position of equality in our society. If it were not for the diligence of the Senate, the Fraser Government would have gone ahead with even more disastrous policies for women-for example, its attempt to introduce tertiary education fees, which would restrict women's access to tertiary education, and the introduction of a series of new sales taxes on household goods which would have further eroded the position of Australian families.

As it is, this Government has, at the same time as it increased the tax burden on women, withdrawn from the provision of services vital to women. The Government has withdrawn from its funding responsibilities for women's emergency services, such as women's refuges. The provision of these services is now left to State governments, and in those States with unsympathetic State governments services have been dropped. The erosion of family allowances under this Government is well documented, and the family income supplement introduced in the August Budget, though welcomed by the Australian Labor Party, is means tested so severely that the vast majority of families will not be eligible for this benefit. This Government's total dismantling of the Medibank health insurance scheme has been another blow to women, who, because of their child bearing and child rearing roles in this society, are much greater users of the health system than are men. The 80 per cent increase per item in patient contribution to pharmaceutical benefits which was introduced in the August Budget can be expected to hit women hardest, especially in relation to prescribed oral contraceptives.

Perhaps the greatest failure of this Government is the failure to provide well- considered job creation and training programs to ensure women's access to the job market. It should be pointed out that the Government's major training scheme , the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme for training apprentices, has a take-up rate of over 90 per cent males. Because the scheme is tailored to meet the needs of traditional apprenticeships in the building and trades areas, areas to which women have very little access, this scheme is virtually useless for providing training opportunities for women and girls. I stress this because employment is the most important determinant of income, and while women's unemployment continues to rise and women continue to be denied training for areas in which employment is available, the financial and social position of women will continue to deteriorate. Without specific measures to improve the opportunities for women's employment, the unconscionably high level of unemployment amongst women, especially young women, can only increase.

I do not have time at this stage of this debate to put forward the Federal Australian Labor Party's proposals to overcome the economic and social disadvantage suffered by women. However, I point out that the Federal Labor Party has recently released a comprehensive policy, 'The Australian Labor Party and Women: Towards Equality', which contains a broad range of commitments in line with our policy of achieving equality for women in our society. These commitments include anti-discrimination legislation, based on the Bill that I have introduced into the Senate, which would give women equal access to areas such as education, employment in the public and private sectors, accommodation, goods and services, and clubs.

We are also committed to upgrading the administration of policies affecting women within the Commonwealth Government by returning the Office of the Status of Women to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. We are committed to a new and expanded children's services program, with priority for areas of greatest need. We will resume Federal funding for women's emergency services and we have plans to extend those services to areas of greatest need, which, of course, are the areas which have fewest of them. We draw attention also to the new health insurance plan which would be funded by an income-related levy, which would mean, in effect, a great practical improvement in women's access to health services. We have a whole program for changing a broad range of benefits and taxation measures to ensure more equitable treatment for women. The introduction of employment generating programs-a concept which even the Fraser Government is now forced to consider-is a matter of great concern to the Labor Party, and we will ensure that all employment generating programs are so structured as to ensure access by women and girls, as well as by unemployed males.

In conclusion, the effect of the Fraser Government's policies on women has been a serious deterioration in the economic and social conditions of women. Despite much good advice from its own Office of the Status of Women and from the National Women's Advisory Council, the Fraser Government has continued to formulate and implement policies which work to the detriment of the majority of Australian women. I believe that Australian women are demonstrating their response to the Fraser Government's policies at the ballot box. There has been a consistent move in the women's vote away from the Liberal Party and the National Party towards the Australian Labor Party. I believe that the women's vote will be a significant factor in electing a Labor government at the next Federal election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of an informal meeting during this week between some women parliamentarians and the National Women's Advisory Council, it was observed that probably many senators and members of Parliament are unaware or only vaguely aware of the Advisory Council's existence , let alone its activities. It seemed useful to use this occasion of the first reading debate on the Cotton Levy Bill 1982 to refer to a report that was introduced into this Parliament, but not debated, last week; that is the annual report of the National Women's Advisory Council. The Council's current composition, under its convenor, Quentin Bryce of Queensland, is probably more accurately reflective of Australian women than at any time since its inception in 1978, bearing in mind that over 40 per cent of women are in the paid work force. It is unfortunate that, along with a reduction in the size of the Council from 14 to 12 members, there is currently no Aboriginal women member, nor is there a replacement for Kath French, who so ably represented women of Perth and the south-west of Western Australia until recently.

SPEECH.PARA: The Council, obviously, is well attuned to the position of women in Australia. Major issues which are included in a list of specific representations to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) cover a wide range of concerns. These include inadequate representation of women at international meetings and conferences, such as the United Nations Conference on the Ageing and international fertility control programs, the threatened removal of the women's unit from the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, and the long-awaited ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. National and domestic issues which have been the subject of direct representation to the Prime Minister through the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) over the last 12 months include the need for representation on a wide range of authorities and committees of inquiry, concern about funding levels for crucial programs such as family planning and child care , and the long-promised and long overdue anti-discrimination legislation promised for the Australian Capital Territory.

Issues raised in correspondence and at meetings provide a comprehensive catalogue which should leave no doubts about the necessity for the existence, in one form or another, of this Advisory Council, without which official atention may never be directed to such matters as a full range of opportunity in education for women and girls, the effects of unemployment and underemployment on women and girls, the vulnerability of women with young children, premenstrual tension, the effect of taxation policies on women on low incomes-which was so ably referred to by my colleague Senator Ryan a few minutes ago-community of property, domestic violence in migrant communities, the situation of Muslim women, and the inclusion of the value of unpaid work by women in the national accounts, to name but a few.

I should like to refer briefly to three extremely valuable studies which the Council is currently undertaking. The first is a study of women who are dependent on social security. Of those who are dependent on social security 60 per cent are women. Of those who receive some sort of income supplement, including the family allowance, 85 per cent are women. Very little is known of their circumstances or what difference is made by educational levels, country or urban living, employability or how they are housed. The Brotherhood of St Laurence has been commissioned to produce an accurate qualitative profile of a selected group of women dependent on Commonwealth Government pensions and benefits as an aid to policy making. It is hoped that the findings of this study will be available by November 1983.

The subject of another comprehensive survey is disabled women. Following a phone-in consultation with disabled women and girls which was conducted in May 1981 a professional consultant has been commissioned to prepare a report which is soon to be available on the data so collected. This annual report includes recommendations following from the 403 submissions which were received during the phone-in. The recommendations address the problems of financial aspects of being disabled, transport and access, general living, communication, personal relationships and access to professional and other services. Many of these problems, as they affect the handicapped generally, were acknowledged during the International Year of Disabled Persons. Two areas of specific concern to disabled women were the establishment of relationships with men and the situation of being a mother and disabled. The report of the Council stated:

Respondents discussed both the physical problems, for example lifting a baby, with lessened strength in the arms, and the social problems, such as not joining in all the activities expected of a mother of school-age children. The incidental stresses on family relationships between parent and child and husband and wife were also raised in many comments on specific problems of finance, transport or domestic help.

Older women are the subject of a further study to be conducted by Dr Alice Day, with two specific questions to be addressed-ones which involve older women more than older men. The first point is that older women are more likely to be living alone and the second is that older women are more likely to be caring for somebody else. Questionnaires related to this study were published in the Women' s Weekly magazine of 7 July and in other publications which are commonly read by people in this age group, such as the Australian Pensioner and Prime Time. The response has been excellent. Over 800 women over the age of 60 years had completed and returned questionnaires by the end of August. Tables in the report to which I have referred summarise some of the information which has already become available. Sixty-four per cent of respondents lived alone and 32 per cent provided care for another person. Of a randomly selected sample of the respondents, 17 per cent were married, the remainder being widowed, divorced, separated or never married. Sixty-four per cent lived in their own homes and 68 per cent were reliant upon a pension as their main source of income.

When asked about difficulties in budgeting, 68 per cent reported that paying for electricity and gas was their greatest worry. Other costs of common concern were home maintenance, food and medical expenses, each of which was creating problems for over one-third of the sample. A question about the quality of life at 60 years-plus brought some positive responses. Obviously some women had found having no children on their hands a liberating experience. According to the report they had:
. . . no family to cook for, sew for, wash for, tidy up after . . . bail out of difficulties of their own making. I can do as I like when I like, how I like and as often as I like . . .

However, the majority expressed the frustration, anxiety and dejection which flow from reduced physical strength and resilience, reduced mobility and, more than anything else, reduced financial means. The report lists issues for review and recommendation at the completion of the survey, but documents general issues which clearly emerge from the survey information regarding older women on low incomes, older women living alone and caring for other people, older women and informal support systems, older women and sex roles-including the difficulties in undertaking simple house repairs and fears for personal safety- and older women and social priorities. In the meantime, the report is well worth the attention of honourable senators and members who are sensitive or should be sensitive to the needs of this growing proportion of every electorate.

Taxation was a separate issue addressed by the report. Social changes of the last decade or so pose serious questions about the basis of our present taxation system and its appropriateness to the fact that so many women are now earning their own living or are contributing substantially to household incomes. Of particular concern to women are the decline in real terms of the family allowance and the apparent discrepancy between the value of the dependent spouse rebate and the sole parent rebate. For example, in 1982 a taxpayer who had a dependent spouse who earned less than $3,602 received a rebate of $830. A taxpayer who had sole care of a child under 16 years or a full time student received a rebate of $580 if he earned less than $1,719. As we are all very well aware, many households which are currently eligible for a dependent spouse rebate have no dependent children.

In the introductory letter to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, which prefaces this report, Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, the retiring Convenor, to whom great tribute should be paid for her dedication to the cause of equality for women and her untiring efforts over the first four years of the Council's existence, drew attention to the fact that recommendations of previous reports have had to be repeated because no action has been taken. Some of these are listed under the list of recommendations to the Prime Minster during this current 12 months. It is also regretted that some extremely worthwhile initiatives of crucial importance to women have been set in train but in the slowest of slow motion.

I refer here to amendments to the Family Law Act which I believe were introduced into the Senate something like 12 months ago, the debate on which has not yet been concluded; the recommendation that there be a task force on the question of community of property in marriage, which I believe has yet to be announced despite the fact that it is well over 12 months since it was announced that this task force would be formed and the problem of domestic violence and the funding of womens refuges. This matter has been the subject of repeated recommendations. The Government could give much more heed to the Council's recommendations. It should be more acutely aware of its priorities. The excellent work being done by the Council and the Office of Women's Affairs has firmly established its credentials. The Government must recognise this fact without reservation and act accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of making some remarks at the first reading stage of these money Bills. I am prompted to do so because of claims made by Senator Carrick on 19 November that the Opposition had taken an undue amount of time in considering the Appropriation Bills. Senator Carrick claimed that the debates which were broadcast last week had attracted adverse public comment and had done no credit to the Senate. He also claimed that the debate had been almost entirely a repetition of the Estimates committee hearings and that the generally poor standard of the debate, which had been monopolised by a handful of senators to the detriment of the Senate, had also been the subject of public reaction. I know what that public reaction is. I wonder what public reaction came to the attention of Senator Carrick. Much of the public reaction which has come back to me from what I have read in the newspapers, seen on the television and heard on the radio has been absolute disgust at the enormous cost inflicted on the taxpayers' purse by two National Party Ministers. Apparently that is what got under Senator Carrick's tail when he got a bit excited. I remind him that had he been prepared to look at the time taken for the Appropriation Bills this year as against last year he would have seen that this year 17 hours 49 minutes were taken up in debate at the second reading and committee stages of both Bills. Last year the debate took 20 hours 57 minutes. So this year we got through the Appropriation Bills in 3 hours 8 minutes less than it took last year.

SPEECH.PARA: We should consider the amount of money appropriated in these Bills. An amount of $7.163 billion was appropriated in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and $1.178 billion was appropriated in Appropriation Bill (No. 2), making a total of $8.341 billion of taxpayers' money. Yet we have Senator Carrick complaining because honourable senators wanted to examine those figures. I make no apologies for the time that I took because, as I have said before, I religiously attend to my duties on Senate Estimates committees, particularly on Estimates Committee C of which I am a member. I go to every other committee when my Committee is not sitting to pursue matters that I feel are of some import. Senator Carrick knows that honourable senators cannot be in two places at once. If we cannot attend other Estimates committees to get information then we have to raise these matters-it is our right and it always has been-in the Committee of the Whole. In my case, a lot of time was taken up in complaining about the fact that I had waited exactly two calendar months from the time I sought information at an Estimates committee hearing until the Senate came to consider the Appropriation Bills. Two months after I raised those questions the answers were not forthcoming. Those questions were in relation to legal expenses of the Aboriginal Development Commission. Another week has gone by and still the answers have not been provided. I have been waiting for the answers now for about 10 weeks. The Hansard shows that I spent nearly half an hour of the time I took on the Appropriation Bills trying to get that information. It is still not here. Some of the other time that I took up was used to seek information about the way National Party Ministers have cost the taxpayers a lot of money.

I did an exercise last Saturday on the time taken on the second reading debate of Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I spent 30 minutes; Senator Walsh, 30 minutes; Senator Foreman, 25 minutes; Senator Evans, 23 minutes; and Senator Childs, 16 minutes. But two Government senators also took a fair amount of time. Senator MacGibbon spoke for 27 minutes and Senator Hamer for 22 minutes. If we look at the Committee stage, spread over 9, 10, 11, 16 and 18 November, we find that I spoke for 74 minutes and the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), who was in charge of the Bills, also spoke for 74 minutes. I have made from the Hansard a complete list of the time taken by each honourable senator who spoke in this debate. So Senator Carrick is completely wrong when he makes this claim. I say again that the reason he is upset is that his National Party colleagues have been exposed for what they have been up to.

I was very disturbed on Saturday when my attention was drawn to an advertisement that appeared in the Canberra Times, on Saturday, 20 November 1982 , headed 'Private Sale Hughes'. The advertisement stated:
Owners sadly selling long-time family home . . .
It then goes on to give all the details. The asking price is $105,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose house is that?
—It is Mr Anthony's.
—How much did he pay for it?
—He paid $18,910.
—So he is making $87,000?

—He will be making about $89,000 profit. I was hoping to ask a question at Question Time today but I could not. That does not matter because I can ask it now. I was going to refer to the advertisement and in particular to the fact that the owners were sadly selling their long-time family home, at an asking price of $105,000. I was going to ask Senator Messner, who represents the Minister for the Capital Territory, whether this long-time family home is owned by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, and whether he purchased it from the Government in 1964 for $18,910 with a deposit of $946, the difference being financed by a Commonwealth home loan over 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4 .75 per cent. I was further going to ask Senator Messner: If this home is owned by Mr Anthony, how can he rightfully advertise it as a long-time family home when he has repeatedly claimed when questions have been asked about his home base that his home has always been at Murwillumbah and at no other place? So there we have it. Mr Anthony, when under attack about his home base, claimed that Murwillumbah had always been his home base since he had been a Minister, and now he is advertising his home as a long-time family home. I have placed a series of questions on the Notice Paper and I am hopeful that we will get the answers next week. On 19 November I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) What was the 'home base' designated by each Liberal/ Country Party/National Party Minister to the Department of Administrative Services for each of financial years 1975-76, 1976-77, 1977-78, 1978-79, 1979-80, 1980-81 and 1981-82 .
(2) What change in 'home base' designation was made by each of the Ministers in the years mentioned in (1) above.
(3) What were the dates of change in each financial year.
(4) Can this information be made available before the Senate rises at the end of the 1982 Budget Session.

It is no great hardship to get information about those changes from the Department of Administrative Services because they would all be listed. I suppose it would take less than 24 hours to get that information. But it has not come in here yet. I hope that we will get it next week because Mr Anthony now finds himself in a very curious situation because he has publicly claimed-in Parliament, too, as I said during debate on the Estimates-that his home was always at Murwillumbah. Now, his home is advertised as a long-time family home. It could be a case that the Trade Practices Commission could look at, in regard to false or misleading advertising. He cannot have it both ways.

This matter is of great concern to the people of this nation. It is all very well for Senator Carrick to criticise members on this side of the chamber for taking some time in the Parliament to try to seek out information. Information in relation to this matter was first given at about this time last year, when we had to postpone examination in Committee of the estimates of the Department of the Capital Territory to drag out the information. I was grateful to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle for getting the information and bringing it forward. From then on I have presented to this Parliament a whole series of petitions on behalf of concerned citizens. So the people outside, as I have said, are very concerned that this Minister, who bought a house for something over $18,000, can advertise it for $105,000, and then repeatedly go on television and into the Press and claim for wage restraint from the workers. It is all very well for him to say that when he purchased a house at a flat interest rate of 4 3/4 per cent in 1964 and he has paid about $3,300 off the principal. Now he is going to sell it and purchase for himself, so the papers say, a luxurious home unit at Telopea Park for something like $210,000. There we have the principles of National Party Ministers.

I refer people to the cartoon in today's Canberra Times of the Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair, sitting down with a calaculator and a pen, and asking his wife as she pokes her head around a corner: 'Which home did you say we were in?' He is trying to work out how much travelling allowance he is entitled to. Of course, he was at the top of the list. I have referred to the examples of two National Party Ministers. One of my colleagues passed a note to me the other day saying, as Mr Anthony has often prided himself on being a pig farmer, that not only do they have their snouts in the trough; they seem to be eating the trough as well. There will be nothing left for the taxpayers of this country.

Many people have come to me and expressed their grave concern that some of the highest paid people in the land can avail themselves of taxpayers' money while people are out of work and some people are required to work a shorter week. People cannot get jobs, and the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) this morning was that nearly 550,000 people will be on the dole very early next year. So these are the types of people who frame the Budget; these are the types of people in charge of the economics of this country. It is no wonder the country is going down the gurgler.

The people on low incomes are suffering and those on high incomes are getting the cream on the cake; they are eating the icing all the time. They could not care less about the work force or the lower paid or unemployed people in this country. It is high time that something was done to rectify all these problems. It must be a great embarrassment even to Senator Carrick to sit in this chamber when he knows what is going on. It must be a great embarrassment to him and to the Government that he leads that almost every day the Senate meets people are petitioning the Parliament so that they can get roofs over their heads on home loan conditions similar to that which has been given to a National Party Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony. When he goes out into the country areas he claims that he is concerned about the welfare of primary producers and country residents. He has no more concern about those people than his predecessor, Mr Bob Menzies, had when he was Prime Minister. He has no more concern than has the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).

If I had the time I could give full details of what the Prime Minister cost this country-the very person who claimed, when he was Leader of the Opposition, that the then Labor Government was wasting taxpayers' money. One of his party's election planks was that Australia did not want a tourist for a Prime Minister. He said that he would stop all that. If we look at the figures-my colleague, Senator Walsh, who is the shadow Minister for Finance has gone through them-we are able to ascertain that Mr Fraser is the most expensive Prime Minister that this country has ever had. I even had people ask me the other day: 'Did he get his $145 a day travelling allowance while he was hospitalised in Melbourne because his home base is at Nareen?'. I also ask the Government: Was the Prime Minister paid while he was hospitalised? That is something we have to look at.

There are many questions which the Government has to answer. It talks with a forked tongue. It wants the work force of this country to exercise restraint in all forms. It wants people to go without homes. The banks are beginning to close on those poor devils who have fallen behind in their home loan repayments because they are out of work or are on short time. Last week I mentioned the case of the Ericksons in Adelaide who are at their wits' end trying to hold on to a home which they have built. They are now faced with the prospect of selling their home, trying to rent a property for 12 months and applying to the Savings Bank of South Australia for a home loan to buy another home. What a terrible situation these young people with three children are facing. They have to get out of their home because of this Government's policies. This Government is not doing anything to create employment. If we look at every aspect of industry right across the spectrum we see that it is running down. So much for the mining boom which was talked up month by month by Senator Carrick in this chamber. So much for the Rundle shale oil scheme which he talked about and bragged about in this chamber and about which we now never hear a word. If we go right back through the Journals of this Parliament to the time that this Government was in opposition we see statements about what it was going to do prior to its coming into government. This Government came to power under very unsavoury circumstances in the first place. We see also statements it has made ever since 1975 always telling the people what a great government it is. But the people already know what sort of Government it is. It has taken them a long time to wake up to the fact.

As I said yesterday, as soon as the hip pocket nerve pinches people start to squeak and take a bit of notice. Unfortunately, many people will suffer between now and the next election. We must get a government in office in Canberra that will try to rectify all the ills that have been created in this country since 1975. This Government has had seven years to rectify the problems which it told the people existed prior to the 1975 election. What has happened? Unemployment figures are getting higher and higher and the inflation rate is now higher than at the time the Australian Labor Party went out of government. It has been quite noticeable over the last few weeks that Senator Carrick has not referred to the Whitlam days. People now know that the Whitlam days were much better than the Fraser-Anthony days. The proof of the pudding is in the eating. I hope that the people outside this Parliament will take note of what I have said today, in particular the way in which Liberal and National Party Ministers get their snouts into the trough and have all the pickings-money that should be available for the lower paid work force in this country.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just received a message that a serious bushfire is close to Canberra. I have given permission to the local Australian Broadcasting Commission station to close its broadcast of Senate proceedings to assist in coping with that bushfire.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity of the first reading debate on the Cotton Levy Bill 1982 and the Cotton Research Bill 1982 to mention once again matters relevant to the Tehran Embassy embezzlement, particularly in light of the fact that the Senate is shortly to adjourn for the year. In my view , many aspects of this issue remain unanswered nine months after I first raised it. I wish to relate briefly what happened.

SPEECH.PARA: On 25 February this year I asked a question about an alleged embezzlement at the Tehran Embassy. A few days later the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street , sought to assure me-I suppose that that is the correct term-by way of a telephone call and subsequently by letter that his Department was unaware of any embezzlement. On going through my files, thinking about the matter, and looking at subsequent correspondence and answers to questions, et cetera, I am totally convinced that the head of the Department of Foreign Affairs, Mr Henderson, was the man who put that answer in the letter ultimately signed by Mr Street that was sent to me, I believe, in order to start what has become quite an extensive cover-up by Mr Henderson and Mr Street of Mr Henderson's long time friend, Mr Bowden, which caused, without any doubt whatsoever, Mr Street to mislead this Parliament. Subsequent information passed to the Minister by other Foreign Affairs Department officers leads me to that conclusion about information which detailed aspects of both Mr Henderson's and Mr Bowden's conduct concerning the embezzlement and cover up. That included claims for the nanny, false entertainment claims, payments to Mr Bowden's children and so on. At least two of these officers have in effect been sent to Coventry by Mr Henderson because of their honest and, in my view, correct behaviour.

My inquiries have led me to the view that Mr Henderson and Mr Bowden have been friends for many years-in fact, since their school days. There is nothing wrong with that. I guess that all honourable senators in this chamber have friends of very long standing. But in my view there is something wrong with a relationship when it leads to one person covering up and giving false information to questions asked in this Parliament when Australian taxpayers were-they may well still be-being bled for tens of thousands of dollars.

On further examination of the answers given on this issue by the Minister I have come to the conclusion that an investigation of this matter by the Australian Federal Police and the Department of Finance has been largely influenced, if not orchestrated, by someone very high up in the Department of Foreign Affairs-possibly Mr Henderson. Mr Street's long statement on 26 August was so full of errors, such as the alibi relative to Mr Bowden and the fraudulent conversion of a $8,700 cheque in Hong Kong, as to lead me to that view. I confirm my statement to the Senate on 9 September in that regard.

As I told the Senate last week, new evidence is continually forthcoming concerning Mr Bowden. One example of this evidence concerns a small businessman who has told me that Mr Bowden took him for a four figure sum a couple of years ago with the assistance of other senior public servants. I expect to be able to provide fuller details on that matter shortly. Even the dogs in the corridor of the Department are barking to the effect that further evidence is around implicating both Mr Bowden and Mr Henderson in further acts of embezzlement of Australian taxpayers' funds. I renew my call that both these men be suspended from duty while a completely impartial body investigates the issue-something that certainly has not happened thus far.

Last week in this place Senator McIntosh incorporated in Hansard a letter from two former members of the Tehran staff, namely, Messrs Witheford and Henne, which very cogently sets out to prove that Mr Henderson had lied to Senate Estimates Committee D on 10 September. If any honourable senator wishes to refer to his evidence it is to be found on page 2343 of the Senate Hansard of 17 November. By means best known to themselves, Foreign Affairs security officers obtained a copy of that letter before Senator McIntosh incorporated it in Hansard. I ask: Does this mean that parliamentarians' offices are under surveillance by the Department of Foreign Affairs? As a result of that little exercise the same security officers put one of the signatories to that letter, namely Mr Henne, under the griller-without success, I must add. In my opinion Mr Henderson has time and again, either through the Minister for Foreign Affairs or before Senate Committee D, misled this Parliament, yet neither Mr Street nor the Government seems to care one iota. I ask: Who is protecting whom and for what reasons? If Mr Street, along with the Government and Messrs Henderson and Bowden , are living in the hope that the rising of this House will allow the matter to wither on the vine, I can assure them that they are mistaken. Neither threats of intimidation to Foreign Affairs officers nor threats of legal action against the Press and me will gain them those ends.

I once again call on Mr Street, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, to suspend both Mr Henderson and Mr Bowden from duty pending a full impartial inquiry into this matter, otherwise he may well find himself down the gurgler with both of them. I said last week and I said here today that the dogs in the corridors of the Department of Foreign Affairs are barking. People are coming out of the woodwork wherever they may be. I have today placed on the Senate Notice Paper a series of questions concerning one other ambassador, namely, a Mr Loveday, who was Ambassador to Bonn. The indications of the information which has come to me would suggest that Mr Loveday may be following in Mr Bowden's footsteps in relation to the embezzlement or the misuse of Australian taxpayers' funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity of using the first reading of the Cotton Levy Bill and associated legislation to talk about a matter which I think is important. It illustrates, first of all, the inflexibility or rigidity of the Government in its interpretations of one section of our social security legislation. But also, in general, it illustrates one aspect of the many problems which are faced by disadvantaged people in our community in dealing with the bureaucracy and, indeed, in dealing with the appeals provisions which we have built into the social security system, and in particular the problems which face the most disadvantaged group in the community ; that is, our Aboriginal community.

SPEECH.PARA: As we know Aborigines face many problems. These are caused, amongst other things, by prejudice against them because of their race and their colour; psychological problems which arise out of this prejudice and which arise out of years of being treated from childhood through to adulthood as second-class citizens; problems caused by illiteracy or lack of education, leading to a lack of capacity to deal with the bureaucracy in the systems that we have developed; problems faced because they live in isolation either through living long distances from our centres of government and centres of administration or, for those who live in our cities, by being isolated by living in what are, in fact, ghettos. To illustrate these problems I would like briefly to talk about the difficulties faced by two Aboriginal families in attempting to get a double orphan's pension. The double orphan's pension is available to those who are caring for a child or children where both parents are dead or in special circumstances. Section 105A(2) of the Social Services Act states:
. . . where one of the parents . . . is dead and-
(a) the whereabouts of the other parent are not known to the claimant;

(b) the other parent has been convicted of an offence and sentenced to imprisonment for life or for a term of years, being a term not less than 10 years, and is serving that sentence at the time of the claim; or

(c) the other parent is, at the time of the claim, a mental hospital patient and the Director-General is satisfied that he will require care or treatment, whether in that hospital or in a similar hospital, for an indefinite period,

In those circumstances the other parent is deemed to be dead. Under those circumstances the double orphan's pension can be paid. It is in the interpretation of this section of the legislation-in particular, section 105A(2) (a); that is, 'the whereabouts of the other parent are not known to the claimant '-that the difficulty is often created. In our normal white society it is often difficult, as we know, to find the whereabouts of a parent, particularly a husband, who has left a family. In the Aboriginal community this difficulty can be aggravated considerably. If this definition is rigidly adhered to in a legalistic way enormous difficulties can be created. We have seen an illustration of the results of the rigid legalistic interpretation of social security legislation recently in the interpretation of what is called income when sickness benefits are being considered.

I will talk about two families in order to illustrate the problems associated with the double orphan's pension. The first case came to attention in my office through an appeal to the Administrative Appeal Tribunal, the Tribunal which was established to ensure that people had the right to appeal against bureaucratic and administrative decisions. It concerns a Mrs Kickett who is an Aboriginal grandmother with only one year's schooling and who virtually cannot read or write. She is, essentially, functionally illiterate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did she come from?

—This case comes from Western Australia; I think the other one does too. Mrs Kickett applied for a double orphan's pension in January 1981, having looked after two children of a son who had died in 1975. She had received the double orphan's pension but when she applied for back payment to 1977-which was the time when the State foster payments she was receiving ceased-not only was the back payment rejected but also the orphan's pension was cancelled. There is evidence that the daughter-in-law, whose whereabouts were unknown to the Kicketts, kept in touch with her mother, a Mrs Hansen, and that the Kicketts had some knowledge of where the Hansens were until about 1980. From the evidence, Mrs Hansen showed no interest in her children. In coming to the conclusion that Mrs Kickett in fact had not done sufficient to find and notify the whereabouts of the children's mother, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, in rejecting the application, made remarks about Mrs Kickett which one can consider unwarranted- remarks about her illiteracy and her circumstances. In doing so, I believe it showed a lack of understanding and a lack of knowledge of the difficulties which are faced by people in these circumstances. For example, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal-which we must remember was established to help people in this situation and to help people overcome bureaucratic difficulties-stated that the mother's whereabouts were a matter of 'indifference' to Mrs Kickett. The Tribunal stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Implicit in the concept of the whereabouts of a surviving parent being unkown that the claimant will take reasonable steps to pursue information . . . it may require no more than to make a telephone call or to check the electoral roll.

That Aboriginal grandmother is doing as most Aboriginal grandmothers would do, and in fact what many people in a non-Aboriginal society would do, and is trying to care for children who have lost their father and been abandoned by their mother. To suggest that a women who can barely read or write, and who obviously would have great difficulty in coping with our system, knows how to check an electoral roll or to make telephone calls, and to suggest that that will make any difference to the desire of the mother to care for those children or make any difference to the financial burden and other burdens which are faced by Aboriginal grandmothers is unreasonable. The Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney) and his Department should reconsider this case despite the Administrative Appeals Tribunal's decision. If those are to be the legalistic rulings of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal we will have to reconsider the legislation, particularly as it refers to this group of people.

The second case involves a Mrs Eades of Cranbrook in Western Australia and also concerns her eligibility for arrears of a double orphan's pension and her ability to get a double orphan's pension in respect of four of her grandchildren who have been in her care since the death of her son in January 1980. Mrs Eades claimed the double orphan's pension in Albany in Western Australia on 23 November 1981. It was known that the children's mother was somewhere in Western Australia, probably in the Perth region. It was accepted, though, that Mrs Eades was not aware of the address of her daughter-in-law, and the double orphan's pension was granted from December 1981. But when investigations were again made into the claim for arrears of the double orphan's pension for Mrs Eades it was felt that Mrs Eades would be, to quote the Minister's words at the time:
. . . capable of locating her daughter-in-law by making reasonable inquiries'.

We can get some idea of what would be reasonable inquiries in the eyes of the Department when we consider the later letters from the Minister and the results of later representations that my office and others made on behalf of this woman. Mrs Eades and her husband live on an invalid pension. Mr Eades had had tuberculosis and needed repeated treatment-regular treatment-for this condition. Mrs Eades can neither read nor write. She has no telephone of her own, and she lives some 200 miles from Perth. It was suggested that she could have contacted the mother of the children by ringing the Perth police to see whether she had recently been sighted. I am not at all sure that such a telephone call would result in any reasonable information being given, nor am I sure that the privacy provisions in our society would allow the police to give such information even if they had it. It is unrealistic that Mrs Eades, who did not know and still does not know the whereabouts of her daughter-in-law, should have been expected to locate this daughter-in-law because, in the words of the Department, the Perth police had occasionally sighted her.

We are talking about a poor family which Mr Eades, the father of the children, had been supporting on a supporting parent's benefit. The grandmother lives in a very small town. She lives in a tin and asbestos house and has about $2,000 in debts for which local tradesmen are suing her. She has lost three sons in car accidents and she has recently been hospitalised for exhaustion. The letter she received from the Department of Social Security stated:
. . . you are no longer entitled to this allowance-
That is the double orphan's pension-
You will receive your final payment on 2 February, 1982. The authority for this decision is contained in sub-section 105A (2) of the Social Services Act.

Mrs Eades then travelled 50 miles to the nearest social security office to find out what it meant but the officers did not give her any explanation which she could understand. If she travelled to Perth she would have to do so on a bus and stay there overnight. To expect this woman to find her daughter-in-law, who has shown no interest in the upbringing of the children and has not tried to contact or see the children and who, the Department says, is occasionally sighted by the Perth police, and to suggest, as the Department does, that she is not entitled to a double orphan's pension because of a lack of effort to find her daughter-in -law, is, in my view, quite unreasonable and takes no account of the special circumstances of this woman. I raise these two cases very briefly to point out that although we have legislation and provisions for people to appeal against legislation, which is meant to assist people in these circumstances, quite clearly at every stage this legislation falls down in these cases because of its legalistic and rigid interpretation. I hope the Minister will consider the situation of these two cases and of many other people in the community who get caught in circumstances such as these.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a number of matters during this rather shortened first reading debate, the first of which relates to the report, tabled earlier today in the Senate, of the parliamentary delegation to the Nordic countries. That delegation was led by Senator John Martyr. When the report was tabled I missed my opportunity to make a few comments in respect of it, so I take the opportunity briefly to do so now. I was not involved in the planning of the visit, being asked to go at very short notice, but I wish to take the opportunity to congratulate those people who organised the trip and assisted in all parts of it. It was a rather informative visit to countries which I believe have much to offer Australia by way of information and example. The people involved, whether they were in overseas embassies or within Australian departments, put together a tightly scheduled trip which encompassed most aspects of those countries that we wanted to see. The report was prepared by the Secretary to the delegation, and I congratulate him for the effort he put into it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of aspects in the report which I wish to highlight at this stage. The first one refers to the sale of Australian uranium to either Sweden or Finland. This point is referred to on page 19 and other pages of the report. I was able to be with the delegation when it visited the Oskarsham nuclear reactor in Sweden on 2 June. We had discussions with the director of the reactor . A number of points which came out of those discussions were of some worry to me particularly because of the assurances we had been given in Australia with respect to the use and final disposal of the products associated with uranium exported from Australia. The director could at no stage guarantee to us that there was any tight control. Specifically, we were told that Australian uranium was used at the Oskarsham plant and that, together with other uranium used there , it would be reprocessed. That remark flew into direct conflict with what the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) has often said to us. We were also told that there was no way of ensuring that Australian uranium was not reprocessed while other uranium used within Sweden would be processed. There is no way that the Swedes could distinguish between uranium from Australia and the uranium they use from other countries. Any guarantee that we have been given in respect of reprocessing our uranium could not in fact hold water.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carrick will assure us that in fact we monitor all the way.

—Senator Sir John Carrick will assure us in all sorts of media talks about many things. But when one reads the fine print in what he says, one will see that Senator Sir John Carrick is rather wise enough and elusive enough to be able to give us assurances that do not stick all that tightly either. We were also told by the director of the plant that no final disposal method had been discovered in Sweden and that this discovery was some time off. That is also something which Senator Sir John Carrick would not tell us. I also took the opportunity to raise with the Finnish Trade Minister in Helsinki on 9 June the question of Australian uranium because we have been assured in this country that there is some control over where our uranium goes and that in fact none of it would go to that great terror which afflicts honourable senators opposite us in this chamber, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Uranium supplies 30 per cent of Finland's electricity needs. We have two plants operating with two units in each one, providing a total of 2,000 megawatts. One plant is operated in co-operation with the USSR, the other in co-operation with Sweden. The USSR helps with the waste from the plant it co-operates with, the waste from the other plant is stored provisionally undeground, in a hill.

The Minister went on to say that he was not a technical person and that he could not really answer questions on reprocessing. But talking later to the person in Finland's Department of Foreign Affairs involved with organising the uranium safeguards agreement with Australia, we were told that it was obviously much more convenient for our uranium to be reprocessed in the USSR since, as we were told, it has the facility and obviously is not too far away. When I asked how long the material would be in the USSR, I was told that it might be there for a few months or a few years. That is an indication of the concern that the Finns obviously have in respect of our uranium; but more so it is an indication of the way in which we in Australia have been misled in our internal debates. In concluding my remarks in respect of that allegation, I must reiterate my thanks to all those people involved in making the delegation such a useful one in terms of seeking and obtaining information.

The other point to which I refer honourable senators appears at pages 32 and 33 of the report. We were able to study the operation of Statoil, the Norwegian petroleum authority, how it operates and how the people of Norway benefit from the natural resources found in their country. I quote one paragraph from page 34 of the report, which states:

All factors taken into consideration, the development of the oil sector has undoubtedly been a great advantage to the Norwegian economy, and has allowed the Government a degree of freedom to formulate its economic policies that has been unattainable in less fortunate countries.
It is no wonder that they can do this, given the fact that they have an effective taxation rate, somewhere in the vicinity of 80.7 per cent, and 83.4 per cent in respect of oil produced.

The final point I wish to raise before seeking leave to continue my remarks at a later stage is in respect of East Timor. Earlier today a question was asked in this place about Australia's attitude to the problem existing in East Timor and how we can act in the future to assist the East Timorese in their struggle for self-determination and independence. Today I also received an answer from the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. My question related specifically to what action the Australian Government had taken in pursuing the rights of the East Timorese in international forums, including the United Nations General Assembly, the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, and so on. What distresses me, however, is an article which appears on page 3 of the Melbourne Age this morning, written by Mr Ian Davis. In part, the article states:
Mr Horta said the Deputy leader of Australia's UN delegation, Mr L. Joseph, had threatened the Vanuatu representative his country would forfeit Australian aid if it failed to vote with Australia.
That is, if Vanuatu failed to vote with Australia on the East Timor question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Blackmail.

—Indeed. Senator Primmer says it was blackmail. It seems to be a rather obscene case of international blackmail which has been attempted in this particular instance. I am informed further by my colleague, Senator McIntosh, who was at the United Nations at that particular time, that this report is accurate. I am concerned that Australia is conducting its international affairs on such a low level. I hope that the Government can explain to the Senate some time today, or some time before it rises this year, how it justifies this attempt at international blackmail. As it is now 2.15 p.m. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Proposed Tabling of Papers
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate because we want to vote very quickly on this matter. The Australian Democrats vigorously support this motion by Senator Evans and the Australian Labor Party. I was impressed with the detailed arguments and the arguments of principle put forward by Senator Chaney, but I believe, as I said before, that there is a massive principle at stake here, namely, the Executive or the Cabinet versus the Parliament. If the Parliament is not allowed to see certain documents which have assumed mammoth proportions in importance, for no good reason given by the Government as far as we are concerned, then we will press for a resolution for the production of those documents, properly sanitised -I do not like that word but it is appropriate in the circumstances-in the Parliament. As I said in my speech on the tax recoupment legislation, I am not persuaded that there were not grounds for prosecution of these tax cheats without retrospective legislation. I believe that the production of these documents might well throw light on just that question. I do not know whether that is one of the reasons the Government is hesitant of producing them, but if it is, that reason ought to be exposed. We vigorously support the inititive taken by Senator Evans and the Labor Party and we commend Senator Evans for the personal work that he has done in relation to this matter.

—I think this is an unnecessary motion. We have, as a Parliament, set up an elaborate system for the release of government documents under the Freedom of Information Act which comes into effect next Wednesday. That Act defines what sorts of documents should be released in the public interest and what sorts of documents should not be released in the public interest. Senator Evans, the mover of this motion, played a considerable role in the preparation of the rules for the Freedom of Information Act. Further, that Act provides arrangements by which documents may be sanitised, as is proposed by this motion and, if they are still comprehensible, they could then be released. Further, it provides an appeals procedure to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal , if anyone has applied for documents and the Government has refused to provide them. That issue, raised by Senator Chipp, is the proper relationship between this Parliament and the Executive. One of the great beneficiaries under the Freedom of Information Act will in fact be members of Parliament. I think it would be sensible and appropriate for Senator Evans to apply next Wednesday for the documents he has asked for under the Freedom of Information Act. If they are as described, they would clearly be exempt documents though it might be possible to sanitise them, to use that expression. If Senator Evans is disgruntled by the Government decision, he could appeal under the Freedom of Information Act to the properly constituted and competent Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a resolution of the dispute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -No doubt Senator Evans will deal very briefly with the additional point raised by Senator Hamer. I only caught the tail end of what he said as I was walking into the chamber. I wish to deal very briefly with a matter which was raised by Senator Missen and one that was raised by Senator Chaney. Let me make it clear at the outset that I am supporting this proposition. I cannot see what all the argument is about. Why is there hesitancy on the part of the Government to agree to this provision? After all, the Government's first objection to it was that it could inhibit satisfactory prosecutions or the proper course of justice. I suggested that there ought to be some person qualified in the law to sanitise the documents appropriately.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney now states that one of the problems with the documents under discussion is that it would not be appropriate to table them even if they were sanitised. On 14 October, he made a statement which I accept. He said:

While the Solicitor-General has advised that some of the documents in question could with sanitising and editing be tabled under the test in the resolution, he has further advised that other documents could not be tabled even under that test. Also, I have confirmed personally with the Solicitor-General that he is still of the opinion that in the case of all the documents he previously examined their tabling would be harmful to the administration of justice in the sense I referred to at the opening of this statement.

I accept that statement that was made by Senator Chaney on 14 October. Senator Missen then suggested that the judge concerned, presumably having been away from the area of prosecution and judicial functions for some considerable time, would not be the appropriate person to do this. However, we should consider the motion before the Senate. The motion requests Sir John Minogue to edit such papers after appropriate consultation with the Solicitor-General and the Crown Solicitor. Therefore, with reference to the papers and background information spoken of by Senator Missen, surely the Solicitor-General and the Crown Solicitor will provide such information to Sir John Minogue. That is what is suggested in the motion.

Therefore, for the life of me, I cannot see any reason why the Senate does not just adopt this motion without any further delay. If I were one of those senators on the Government side who, in opposition to the recoupment tax Bills, said that the Government ought to have been engaged in prosecutions all along the line and that those Bills were not necessary, I would feel that it would be important, in order to confirm my opinion, to have the benefit of the advice that is no doubt in the papers that are as yet to be tabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.
