TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank all honourable senators for their contribution to the debate. I am indebted in particular to two of them. I mention first Senator Hamer for his suggestion about the use of freedom of information legislation as an appropriate line of weaponry in this matter. I must confess that I had almost forgotten about freedom of information legislation, its having taken so long to come into force and effect. But, I think that even Senator Hamer would concede that none of us has hitherto regarded the Freedom of Information Act as being the appropriate first port of call for a parliament intent on exposing the Executive to scrutiny in an area of manifest or likely maladministration. I would not have thought that that was an appropriate first line of action at all, although certainly it is a possible course of action which we do not overlook as a line of last resort in the event that this more direct approach proves ultimately unsuccessful.

SPEECH.PARA: I am indebted, secondly, to Senator Harradine largely for the very succinct way in which he exposed some of the travesties of the arguments of first Senator Chaney and then Senator Missen. Senator Chaney has adopted a much more absolutist position today than he did even on 14 October when he was prepared to acknowledge that the Solicitor-General himself conceded that, with appropriate sanitising and editing, a number of the documents in question could be tabled under the test in this resolution. I am further indebted to Senator Harradine for pointing out the way in which both Senator Missen and Senator Chaney have resolutely ignored the terms of the resolution insofar as it provides firstly for consultation and secondly for a series of filters or tests to be applied which will manifestly ensure that neither the pending proceedings nor the administration of justice will be in any way prejudiced by the ultimate tabling of these documents. I commend the motion to the Senate.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Evans's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, the Senate, at its rising on Thursday, 25 November 1982, adjourn till Tuesday, 7 December 1982, at 1.45 p.m.

I remind honourable senators that by tonight the Senate will have sat for three weeks in a row. In the normal sequence, after a three-week sitting, the Senate rises for a week. Notwithstanding that, in normal circumstances the Senate should have finished its business this week. But I advised the Senate several days ago that because of the likely outcome of the forthcoming Premiers Conference requiring legislation, members of the House of Representatives were being notified that the other place would resume on 8 December; that therefore the Senate would have to sit certainly during the week of the Conference and possibly the following week. I repeat that the Senate will find it necessary to sit certainly the week of 8 December and possibly in the week commencing 14 December. That being so, a decision requiring the Senate to sit next week, will inevitably result in the Senate sitting for six consecutive weeks. I make it abundantly clear that that is so. Therefore, all common sense indicates that my motion should be agreed to.

I make two points because I understand that the motion will be opposed. I have asked officers in the Records and Table Office to ascertain whether ever in the history of the Senate the prerogative of the Government to determine the pattern of sitting weeks has been challenged. I say this without any heat or qualification so that it is fully understood. The advice that I have received is that it has always been the practice of the Senate-and, I understand, the other place as well-that the determination of what shall be sitting weeks and what shall be recess weeks is the prerogative of the Government. If the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats choose to take that prerogative out of the hands of the Government, they will be deliberately seeking to obstruct the procedures of the Government in a way not seen before. That is a matter for them to judge.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliament is not the Government's plaything. Parliament is not owned by the Government. Where did you get that idea?

—I can understand the heat of Senator Chipp's interjection because he, of all people, has pleaded with me that we should always keep to the routine sitting times and that we should have recess weeks at regular intervals to ensure the health of honourable senators. Let Senator Chipp not intervene on this subject because he has made it abundantly clear that the Democrats stand for the routine sitting of the Senate. Indeed, the health of senators would demand that we would have a cyclical recess week. Opposition senators, for some strange reason, believe that they can benefit by sitting during the week of the Flinders by-election. The Opposition may enjoy breaking the long-established practice of the Senate, but it will gain no advantage by doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that the Government intends that the Senate resume in the week in which the House of Representatives resumes. That means that it is likely to sit during the following week also. If the Opposition with its co-partners, the Democrats, decides to compel the Senate to sit next week it will be deciding to sit for six weeks straight. Be that upon their heads. I say completely objectively that honourable senators opposite should understand that they will be establishing a precedent. That is the advice I have received from officers. They will also be acting against all the pleading and advice of Opposition and Democrat senators who have said that we should not break the rules of the cyclical sittings of the Senate. That having been said, the Government will be entirely unperturbed, except on a question of principle, if we see an attempt to break from tradition and obstruct the Government.

Now and again I take great joy in reading what the Democrats said when they invited electors to vote for them. In many situations they said that the one thing they would not do was to obstruct in any way the business of a government that was properly elected. They said: We have said that we would not wilfully attempt to frustrate or obstruct a government that has won a clear majority of seats. Beyond any doubt at all the Government has won a clear majority of seats. We will now see whether they keep the illegitimates honest. Protocol and the Senate's decision regarding the health of senators-in fact, everything-points to the fact that a government has the right to determine the weekly sittings of a House of the Parliament. That is accepted in parliaments throughout the world. Today, as for weeks, time that should have been government time has been occupied by other business. In due course I will table in the Senate an outline of the present sittings of the Senate. It will show how day by day an attempt has been made to take up so much time that there is virtually no time left for Government Business. Honourable senators should bear that in mind. Let nobody from now on argue that the Democrats and the Opposition are not seeking wilfully to obstruct the business of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should indicate that the Opposition opposes the motion which has just been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick). This is the first occasion on which I have discussed with Senator Sir John Carrick, in the context of a debate in the Senate, the proposed sittings for this Budget session. Although the Leader says that he has said something about the program to every honourable senator, this is the first time that any Government spokesman has said anything to me about it. I just want to remind the Leader that he wrote to me on 19 November a letter which I still find quite extraordinary because it contains some gratuitous insults about the integrity of the Opposition and about the behaviour of honourable senators in this place. This letter has, in a sense, become a document of record.

SPEECH.PARA: In that letter Senator Sir John Carrick stated that the Opposition had broken undertakings about giving the Government its Bills when it wanted them. I just want to put the record quite straight on that point. First of all, we indicated at the time of the Budget that we would give the Government the Bills which it specified by the end of October. We carried out that undertaking completely except in respect of one set of Bills-those dealing with taxation recoupment. We did not carry out that undertaking in respect of those Bills because they were not even introduced into the Senate before the end of October. The Leader of the Government talked about delays in programs. I should point out that 16 speakers from the Government side and 7 speakers from the non-government side spoke on those Bills when they were debated in the Senate. Those Bills were not introduced into the Senate in accordance with the Government's program because Government members could not agree about them when they were before the House of Representatives. They could not agree even when the Bills came into the Senate. We had these hours and hours of delay.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that to do with next week?
—If Senator Harradine does not mind, I am answering an allegation that the Opposition has delayed Government legislation.
—No, we are talking about next week.

—I know what I am talking about, if the honourable senator does not mind. He will get the opportunity to speak later. Those charges of delays, which were contained in the only communication I have had from the Government on the question of Senate sittings, are specifically repudiated and the evidence is there for people to see. The Government has been slow in introducing its program in this place. The other allegation made in the letter was that we have taken an inordinate time on the Appropriation Bills.
—Indeed.
—We took four and a half hours less than we did last year, Senator Missen, and several hours less than the year before.
—Come on!

—Yes, Senator. There was an election in 1980-1979 is the full year before. If Senator Missen, or anybody else in this place, can set an arbitrary and subjectively selected number of hours in which the Appropriation Bills can be disposed of, I do not think that would be in accordance with the standards that he normally espouses, as I understand it, as a parliamentarian. As I have said, there is no communication on this question of sitting hours other than the letter from Senator Sir John Carrick which, if I may so, was ill informed as to the facts, to say the least.

SPEECH.PARA: Included with the letter that I received was a suggested program for the Senate for the remainder of the sitting. That suggested program contained a subjective categorisation of Bills which were for significant debate, Bills for brief debate and Bills for passage if time permitted. Included in Bills for passage if time permitted were Bills which were introduced into the House of Representatives in a rush in August as being the priority Bills in the Government's legislative program. They have now been relegated to the category of Bills for passage if time permits.

We agree that the Senate has a quite heavy legislative program to deal with and if the Government asks us for undertakings about the passage of legislation we will meet any undertakings which we give. We will attempt to meet the Government in respect of those issues. Some time ago allegations of delays in the Senate program led us to look at the question of when the Senate should appropriately sit to deal with an important legislative program. We are concerned that the Senate should sit next week, as we have indicated in a number of statements in the past few weeks. I find it extraordinary that Senator Sir John Carrick comes in here and says that the Opposition parties are taking away the Government's prerogative in terms of when the Parliament sits. No person knows better than Senator Sir John Carrick in this place how an Opposition majority can take away a government's prerogative. On a unique occasion in 1975 all honourable senators opposite participated in that. They took away a government's prerogative in 1975 . To come in here in 1982 and talk about sitting hours and an Opposition--
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Button has the call.
—That was the people's decision and you know it.

—Senator Walters said that it was the people's decision and I know it. It was not the people's decision to delay the Budget. If Senator Walters had been here she would have known that. The then Opposition took away the fundamental prerogative of a government in 1975, the right of a government to exist. Senator Sir John Carrick comes in here today and claims that we are breaking new ground by suggesting that the Senate should sit next week. We are not doing even that. In 1974 and 1975 the Opposition majority determined that the Senate would sit on particular days when the then Government did not want it to sit. In June of 1975 the Opposition majority recalled the Senate in the middle of a recess to deal with business.
—There is a difference.

—'There is a difference', says Senator Townley. What is the difference in principle? There is no difference in principle at all. Leaving aside the pieties which lie behind the Government's motion, I want to come to the questions of reality. We have to deal with a quite significant legislative program of some importance. All I am saying at this stage is that it is not the responsibility of the Opposition parties that the Government is in its present legislative mess or any other mess it happens to be in. It is the responsibility of the Government. We have to deal with that program. We would be very anxious to deal with it next week. We see no reason why we should sit in the week commencing 8 December when the House of Representatives will be recalled to deal , we are told, with new legislation and legislation which, according to the Senate business sheet, we have to pass.
—Next week.

—This legislation has not even been passed through the House of Representatives yet, Senator Archer, so it could not be next week. The House of Representatives has a legislative program to deal with that week which will have to come to the Senate. Do honourable senators want to come back in the week commencing 8 December and sit around here if we do not have business to deal with, which we will have? Do they then want to wait until the end of that week and deal with legislation? We are told that we should come back that week to deal with legislation that the House of Representatives will have just dealt with. Do honourable senators want to come back here and sit on Friday and Saturday to deal with that legislation or do they want us to deal with it on the same day as it is dealt with by the House of Representatives? This would not be a sensible course. The Senate could meet in the week commencing 14 December and deal with all that legislation which is hanging over from the House of Representatives. That seems to us to be the appropriate course.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told now that, because of the Premiers Conference, the House of Representatives will be recalled on 8 December. That seems to me to be a piece of political expediency of a particular kind, but I do not want to debate that issue. We do not see any reason why the Senate should sit in the week commencing 8 December. It seems to me to be a rational allocation of time that the Senate proceed with its existing program next week and then deal with what comes out of the House of Representatives in the week after the House of Representatives has dealt with its program. That is our normal practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not our normal practice. It will be four weeks in a row and you know it.
—It is our normal practice to deal with legislation out of the House of Representatives in weeks subsequent to the weeks it has passed the House of Representatives.
—And sit for four weeks in a row? Never.

—I am not fussed about that. Let me simply say in summary: We are not departing in any new way from practices which have been followed in the Senate in the past. We are not in any way obstructing the Government's program. We are prepared to sit to deal with it. The fact of the matter is that a lot of this legislation ought to be dealt with in the ensuing week. Of all the arguments advanced in support of this motion the only one of any validity is that for some reason the Senate should never sit for four weeks in a row. I do not understand that. There have been plenty of times when we have sat for four weeks in a row or times when we have, when it suited-
—This would make it six weeks in a row.
—That is a matter for subsequent decision, is it not? If we do not sit in the week commencing 8 December it will not be six weeks in a row. That is a matter for subsequent determination.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I say in conclusion that if the Government had seriously come and discussed this question with us we might not have been in this position today. Instead of such a discussion I received a letter from Senator Sir John Carrick which, as I said, is ill-informed and insulting to the Senate. I am quite prepared to have it incorporated-

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like to incorporate it?
—Yes, I would.
—Please do.
—I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard together with a copy of my reply.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

Dear Senator Button,
COMPLETION OF LEGISLATIVE PROGRAMME
May I refer to the legislative programme for the remainder of this session.

Attached is a list showing the outstanding legislation and indicating those Bills which may be regarded as requiring some significant debate. The others, as in past sessions, might well be completed in a very short time.

It has always been envisaged that the Budget session would end on Thursday 25 November. It has always been possible, with goodwill and co-operation, for the programme to be achieved comfortably in that time without detriment to effective debate. It still remains so.

However, in spite of Opposition statements some three weeks ago that the Appropriation and other Budget-related Bills would be dealt with expeditiously, the plain fact is that the Appropriation Bills still remain unfinished. And this is so even though six full sitting days (the equivalent of two weeks of sittings ) have been allocated wholly to the Appropriations without the intrusion of other government business and with very little intervention in the debates by government speakers.

The broadcast debates of the last week have attracted adverse public comment and have done no credit to the Senate. The debate has been almost entirely a repetition of the Estimates Committees hearings. The generally poor standard of the debate, which has been monopolised by a handful of Senators to the detriment of the Senate, has also been the subject of public reaction.

The Labor Party when in office had frequent recourse to the application of gags in the Senate. On the other hand, my government, even during the period of its majority control, was reluctant to do so and remains in that attitude.

I understand that Opposition Whips have suggested that the Government should place time limits on the debates on individual Bills. If this implies the application of a gag, we would be reluctant to do so. I am not aware of the Opposition attitude to gags.

In past sessions effective arrangements have been made between the Whips to isolate those Bills which, by agreement, can be passed quickly and with virtually no debate because of consensus. The remaining Bills, which would be few in number, would then be allocated set times with an agreement that individual speakers would limit their speaking times.
If this is done, the Senate can comfortably complete its programme by the end of next week. There is absolutely no need to commit the taxpayers to the unnecessary expenditure of additional sittings.
In the light of this, may I ask for your co-operation in the detailing of the attached list into an effective time schedule for completion at the latest by Friday 26 November.
Yours sincerely, J. L. CARRICK
THE SENATE
