PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA-THE SENATE
Leader of the Opposition in the Senate Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
19 November 1982
Senator the Honourable Sir John Carrick, KCMG
Leader of the Government in the Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Carrick,
I acknowledge receipt of your letter of 19 November relating to the Senate's legislative programme.
Enclosed with your letter is a suggested programme which you envisage might be completed by Thursday 25 November.

I do not wish to comment in detail on that programme at this stage. I would point out that it is the second occasion in this session on which you have provided me with a proposed programme in a letter criticising the Opposition directly or by implication for alleged delays in the programme of the Government .

As I indicated in the Senate earlier this week, the Opposition's position is that it is prepared to co-operate as much as possible within the normal Senate sitting hours until the programme is completed. That is still our position.

Might I recall that you wrote to me on 11 October suggesting a change to Senate sitting hours and expressing concern about the passage of ''Budget related legislation which the Government needed before the end of October''.

No changes were made to the sitting hours but I undertook in a letter dated 12 October to ensure that the legislation that you identified as necessary to be passed before the end of October was so passed.

This was done with the exception of the bottom-of-the-harbour bills which were not introduced into the Senate until 9 November. The fact that the bottom-of-the -harbour legislation was not introduced until 9 November and debated until this week is due entirely to government dithering over contents of the legislation.

The fourth paragraph of your letter which alleges that there were opposition statements ''some three weeks ago'' to the effect that the Appropriation and other related bills would be dealt with expeditiously is quite incorrect. You are confusing that with the undertaking I gave in my letter of 12 October relating to urgent legislation. In the programme accompanying your letter of 11 October the Appropriation Bills were not even scheduled for introduction until some time in November.
I am sure that many senators will resent the gratuitous comments in the fifth paragraph of your letter suggesting adverse public comment about the debate of the Appropriation Bills.

I do not retreat from the proposition that the Senate broadcasts could be improved by a better standard of debate. I find this comment strange, however, coming as it does from a Minister of a government which has consistently put on standing orders debates on Wednesday afternoons when the Senate is being broadcast.

In spite of the complaints made in your letter about the Appropriation Bills I draw your attention to the fact that the total time devoted to debating the Appropriation Bills this year was 17 hours 49 minutes.
Last year the time spent on debating the Appropriation Bills was 20 hours 57 minutes.
The time taken this year is by no means abnormal.
The Appropriation Bills normally pass the Senate at this time in November.
With regard to the proposed legislative programme I would like to make the following comments:
1. The judgments which have been made as to which Bills require significant debate and/or ''brief debate'' are extremely subjective.

For example, the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill, of which the Government has made so much, should be the subject of significant debate. It provides for a new tax on fuel for road works and is subject to substantial criticism as to whether the revenue gained by this Bill will be in any way sufficient to meet the Government's claims in respect of road works which it will allegedly finance.

2. Similarly the Broadcasting and Television Bills involve a considerable departure from existing practice in the broadcasting system and are of vital interest to rural communities throughout Australia.

3. It is an extraordinary example of the government's priorities that the Omega Navigation Facility Bill and the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill should be regarded as Bills for passage ''if time permits''.
In June and July of this year the Prime Minister was describing the Defence ( Visiting Warships) Bill as the first priority of the Government's legislative programme after the Budget.
At that stage, the Government clearly regarded the legislation as potentially divisive in the community and for that reason it became a priority.
It has now been reduced to a Bill of apparent unimportance.

Similar comments could be made about the Omega Navigation Facility Bill. In respect of this Bill the Prime Minister said that the passage of this legislation was a question of ''national credibility''.

Might I suggest that the best solution to the problem raised in your letter is for the Whips to confer about an orderly programme within normal sitting hours until such time as the legislative programme for the Budget sittings is completed.

Within the sitting times available, the Opposition will cooperate. This is all we can undertake to do because we are continually subjected to changes of government legislative plans and priorities, which have been illustrated quite clearly in your letters to me.
With kindest regards, Yours sincerely,
JOHN N. BUTTON

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the only approach which the Government, which is said to be in charge of this country and wants to be in charge of this Parliament in all respects, has made to the Opposition at all.
—You do not like the wording of it so you will not go along with it. That sounds childish.
—I call Senator Walters to order. The Leader of the Opposition has the floor.
—Mr Deputy President, I am getting assistance from all sorts of--

SPEECH.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. I call the Leader of the Opposition.

—I am mortified, Mr Deputy President. I am being harassed, as Senator Missen says. The point remains that we have indicated a position about this matter. We intend to stick to it. We believe it is in the best interests of the parliamentary program and the Parliament.
—You believe!

—Yes, we are entitled to believe, strange as it may seem to Senator Archer. We are entitled to beliefs because we are elected senators in this country and we are members of this chamber. We are entitled to beliefs and I am telling honourable senators opposite what they are.
—They are all wrong.

—Of course, Senator Martyr would say that. Those are the beliefs which we have. We have indicated them quite openly in the last two or three weeks. We will indicate them again in another way in a few minutes if it becomes necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats oppose the Government's motion. I think it is odd in a way that the question of obstruction of Senate business has been raised when in fact the Opposition parties are seeking to meet to debate Government business. It is indeed rather interesting to note that if one looks at the average number of days the Senate has sat in the last 11 years one will find that it is 71 days a year. Indeed, if one goes back to the first 10 years of Federation one finds that the average number of days on which the Senate sat was 71 days a year. As of now we have sat 64 days this year. That is the reason why in fact the Government's legislative program is not finished. If we sat every day to 16 December we would sit only 73 days this year. So it could hardly be said that we are not allowing the Government to get its business through if in fact the Government does not wish the Senate to sit to discuss its business.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly, what we have in broad terms is the situation that the fixed amount of work that the Senate has to do, quite apart from dealing with Government legislation, is increasing every year. Let us examine the number of reports presented by Senate committees, work undertaken by honourable senators in this place. In 1980 there were 61 such reports; in 1981, 70 reports; and in 1982 so far there have been 94 reports. If Senate committees are to meet then presumably the Senate will have to discuss their reports. Every year more and more papers are coming into this place and we have to discuss them. Last year, for example, there were no royal commissions. This year we dealt with five reports from royal commissions. At some stage I think the Senate has to look at the amount of time for which it actually meets. There was an interjection earlier that other people in this country have to work 48 weeks or 50 weeks a year. We are elected to work and it is not necessarily an easy task. The Senate will have to face up to the fact that it will have to meet, as do other legislatures around the world, for more and more weeks a year no doubt just to get through the business. At some stage we will have to come to grips with the notion that the Senate will have to meet more frequently.

Senator Sir John Carrick raised a number of points about precedents which I think the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) has already answered. There are plenty of precedents where non-government majorities-after all, for 34 years of the 82 years since Federation the government has not had a majority in this place-have taken control of procedures in the Senate. For example, they have decided not to sit certain hours, not to sit extra days or even on celebrated occasions, such as events which occurred in 1967 and 1975, to recall the Senate during a recess for a special sitting. If that is not setting a precedent, I do not know what is. Yet, Senator Sir John Carrick came in here and talked about precedents.

I have been in this place for only a short period and the Leader of the Government in the Senate during all that time has been Senator Sir John Carrick. One of the things I have heard constantly from people who have been here a long time is that the previous Leader of the Government would not have been in this situation. That has been told to me by people all around the place. I can only relay it for what it is worth. From my observations of what has gone on in this place I think it is worth a lot. Indeed, we have a situation in which no group controls the Parliament. If this Senate is to operate efficiently there has to be co-operation between all groups in the Senate. Nothing else will work. Unless people co-operate about sitting times, speaking lists and which Bills will be debated nothing much can happen. There have been attempts to impose co-operation by majority votes, one way or the other. It does not work and the Government knows that it does not work.

Already it is Thursday, 25 November, and we are behind in debating the following Bills: Asian Development Fund Bill 1982, the five taxation Bills, the Bounty (Berry Fruits) Bill 1982, the unpaid company tax Bills-there are five of those-the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1982, the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Amendment Bill 1982 and the bank account debit Bills . We need extra time merely to clean up what is already on the Notice Paper. I believe that the Senate ought to meet to clean up those Bills so that when the Senate meets next session, in 1983, it will be able to discuss the new Bills that the Government will bring forward rather than deal with a large number of Bills left over from this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are times when one gets tired of the humbug and hypocrisy that emanate from the Opposition benches. This is one of those occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators opposite can shout me down if they want. I know that they are not real defenders of democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will stay here until I have said what I want to say; so honourable senators might as well save their breath. I intend firstly to reply to the rather irrelevant elements of the speeches by Senators Button and Macklin and then to say a little about the real issue in question here today. The real issue is whether we are going to change the sitting times of the Senate to six- week sittings, with the concomitant risks that that will have for honourable senators.
—You extended it into a five-week sitting.

—It will clearly be six weeks because the normal schedule of events requires us to sit after the House of Representatives resumes, and it is clear that there will be plenty of business to go on with in that period. I hope that Senator Chipp is not leaving the chamber because he of all people and the Australian Democrats should know that if they join in this move they will endanger the health of senators. Should any honourable senator collapse in the next few weeks, the responsibility will lie very much on their heads. They are doing this for petty political gain-some advantage from the proceedings of the Senate being broadcast during the week before a by-election.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me speak briefly about what Senator Button in his meandering way said in an attempt to suggest that the Opposition had been disposing of Government business . 'Disposing' might be a good word for it because, judging from the way in which Government business has been dealt with, it has been dying of inaction. He said that the debate on the Appropriation Bills had not been quite as long as it was last year. Year after year the debate consists of tedious repetition. we have a system of Estimates committees, yet the gasbags of the Senate such as Senator McLaren, who are here at the expense of the people, must go back over every little issue and every little triumph they had in the Estimates committees and regurgitate the whole thing for the benefit of the public. Of course, the members of the public are not concerned with these issues. The Appropriation Bills are Government business and the debate on them was drawn out to a tedious length. The Government put everything else aside to enable those matters to come forward. All Opposition senators, one after another, were determined to repeat everything they had said before. They do not have a new idea; they have to say everything three times because then it might sound impressive.

Senator Button got away from the subject and suggested that the Opposition had not been obstructive. Senator Macklin's speech was in the same irrelevant vein, because he told us that 94 reports had been brought down this year. I tell him that the number of reports brought down in the Senate has been declining. I refer to the important reports-those of standing committees. Senator Macklin added to the list 16 or 17 traditional or ordinary reports, including those from my Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Senator Archer's Publications Committee produces a report every week or so, which is an ordinary action. This argument about the number of reports brought down is a lot of nonsense. The Senate and its members are not producing the amount of work which might be produced. There is certainly a need for more genuine work to be done in committees and in this chamber, without the tedious repetition of debates on matters of public importance. We have those debates on the same subjects day after day and week after week because of the precious belief of some Opposition members that the great public out there will be listening to them and will be impressed by the repetition of their tedious ideas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Making an impression on them.

—I think they may be making an impression, but they may not realise its effect. If they read the gallup polls they may get some idea of why their popularity is going in a curious direction at present after all the talk that has gone on. We have agreed upon sitting periods of three weeks followed by a week off. That has been traditional. I believe I speak on behalf of many Government back benchers when I say that they believe they have many duties outside this chamber. I would have thought that even Opposition senators who want to campaign in the by-election could not expect to attract the attention of one little bit of Victoria by the proceedings of the Senate being on the air for the whole of next week. They would be better advised to go into the streets and by-ways of Frankston to find out what the people are thinking and to impress them with the charm of their personalities and their ideas rather than to use the free airwaves to persecute the people of Australia, particularly the electors of Flinders. That is what this debate is about. Opposition senators have been sneeringly clever about this for some time. If they can defeat the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) and take the matter out of the hands of the Government, they will say: 'We will make the Government sit on the eve of the by-election. We will enjoy the benefits of being able to argue political matters all that week'. They will not be considering Government business; they will be doing what they want. They will be boring silly the electors of the whole of Australia. That is only one aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: Has anyone considered for one moment the cost of keeping this building open for one chamber to sit for one week, with all the facilities involved? I hope that someone will do some research. I hope that one of our investigative journalists will look at the cost that these people cause the country by having all the services available for their benefit during the week while the other chamber is not meeting and while we engage in a tuppence of damn nonsense and achieve the passage of no legislation. What does it cost the country to keep this chamber here? It is an important amount. We ought to consider the cost of the humbug that we have heard today to the people of Australia. All this debate is about is some absolutely mistaken idea by the Opposition that the few unfortunate people who are listening to Parliament-I say 'unfortunate' because the standard of debate in this chamber is not good-will be influenced in their voting patterns, particularly the few people in one part of Victoria. I believe the people there will resent the greedy attitude of those opposite, particularly the Democrats. People do not send money to support them; so they think they will use the public purse as a free way to get to the public during that week. That is what this is all about. That is why they desire to take control out of the Government's hands . That is why they are trying to wreck the pattern of sittings to require six weeks of sittings, thus endangering the health of honourable senators. I hope that Senator Harradine will reconsider his attitude on this matter. I believe that what is proposed by the Opposition is destructive, is humbug and is unnecessary. I believe the Government's motion should be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hasten to assure Senator Missen that I will not reconsider my attitude on this motion. I am going to vote with the Government. I hope that the honourable senator will withdraw his suggestion. If the Senate meets next week it will do so in opposition to the wish of the majority of the Senate. The Opposition and the Australian Democrats do not have the majority in this place. So what they are doing is to block the sort of motion normally moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) in the third week of every sitting period. So in effect if the Senate sits next week it will not be because that is the wish of the majority of the Senate. Therefore, the statement made by Senator Button about the Parliament controlling itself is so much humbug. Under this circumstance the Parliament is not controlling itself because if the Senate sits next week it will do so against the wish of the majority of the Senate. I wrote down what Senator Button said. He said that some time ago the Australian Labor Party decided that the Senate would be sitting next week and that the Senate ought to sit next week. If it decided that some time ago, it kept it to itself. It told nobody else, apart from the Democrats.
—And you.
—You did not tell me at all.
—Don't you read your letters?
—You did not tell me.
—Are you illiterate?
—No, I am not illiterate. When did you write to me?
—I gave a letter to you personally on Tuesday.

—I withdraw what I said. There has been no discussion in respect of that matter. Members of the Labor Party had made up their mind and they had got the Democrats with them. Other people in this place have their prerogatives. Senator Button said that it was some time ago that the Opposition decided. Of course it was some time ago; it was at the time it was decided to hold the by-election for Flinders. So, the Labor Party and Democrats came to a shabby political deal in order to keep the Senate sitting so that they could use the Senate for political muck-raking next week. If they want to do that let them all be here at the same time to do it. Let us see how many of them will be away from the Senate. Is there any guarantee that those people who are suggesting that we sit next week will all be here or will they have pairs, as has been the custom?
—Will you be here?
—Well, I am considering that, because over a long period I have had commitments in my home State for next week.
—We had them last Friday too and we had to break them.

—I opposed sitting last Friday. Who supported it? The Democrats supported it last Friday only because they could get pairs. Since August of this year I have had sent to me by the Leader of the Government in the Senate a document which has been in the hands of every honourable senator. That document shows the times and the days of sitting. Next week was an off week when we were supposed to be doing our work amongst the electorate.
—There are the two weeks after that.
—The honourable senator's contribution to the debate was absolute nonsense. The inference from his contribution to the debate was-
—That we should sit more.

—That we should sit more-every day of the week, 52 weeks in the year. We have a representative function in this place. Our right is to go back sometimes to the electorate to be informed there. The more time that we spend in the electorate the better that will be for this chamber and for the debate in this chamber.
—Some.

—It may well be that I have been absent from that task, as witnessed by the standard of this debate. I must say that along with other senators I have been preoccupied by Senate committee work. I must say that I was looking forward this week to being out amongst the electorate doing the chores that honourable senators have to do.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the matter of the six week sitting. Let everybody be clear about what we are doing. If we vote against this motion today what we will do is condemn the Senate and the people of Australia to a six week straight sitting of the Senate. Frankly, as has been pointed out by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, that is unheard of.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not.

—All right, I must have misunderstood what Senator Sir John Carrick said. It has been suggested that it is not unheard of. But when it occurred it must have been a most unusual event and have taken place at a time when a different procedure was followed. In my opinion this desire to sit next week is all about the Flinders by-election; it is not about what legislation could be debated when the House of Representatives comes back in the sitting week commencing 7 December.
—Or what it costs the country.

—Or what it costs the country, as the Government Whip said. It will cost the country more to have us come back next week when, in fact, the Bills that are before us can be dealt with within a period of two weeks. What we are going to do is to sit for three weeks to do that. That figures. Somebody said to me the other day: 'Oh, you are sitting an extra week so that means you will get two weeks behind in your work'. That is what appears to be the case. It is par for the course. I suggest that we have a look at the reason for this proposition to sit next week. The onus is now on the Democrats, who say that they are prepared to sit for six weeks straight until 16 December. I wonder whether that fits suitably with the statements that have been made from time to time by the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp) in this place about the effect that that has on the health-I quote his words-and 'the tension' in this place. It will certainly make interesting broadcasting to hear debate in the last week of that six week session. It will be interesting to see how much business we get through and how much entertainment the public of Australia get just prior to Christmas.

SPEECH.PARA: I very much oppose this proposition to sit next week for the reason that the Parliament should not meet unless it receives the majority support of all senators. I have other things to do in the electorate next week. Arrangements have been made for a large number of people to see me. I do not know whether they are looking forward to it. If we are sitting next week it will be simply a political stunt. I am not prepared to go along with that political stunt at the cost of honourable senators' health, at the cost to the taxpayer. I urge all senators and particularly the Democrats, if they are going to stick to the statements that they have made previously, to support the normal procedure.

Finally-I want to make it perfectly clear-I must say that there were to be a number of Bills discussed the week after next. I thought that I would have had time to consider in detail the amendment that the Opposition was proposing to one Bill. That Bill will, no doubt, come up next week. I doubt whether I will have the opportunity of fully examining the information that might have been available to me on that legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't he make you quiver with terror when he makes those threats?
—Senator Chipp can quiver with terror if he likes.
—Why don't you stay down in Tasmania?
—Order! I ask honourable senators to address their remarks through the Chair.

—That is precisely what I want to do. I ask through you, Mr President, whether the Democrats will give me a pair. If so, I will be very happy to do that. One of the matters that I was going to discuss in detail in Tasmania was about the very important education Bills to which I was referring. I will not have the chance of doing that; so let that be on the heads of members of the Opposition when they come to me next week.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Sir John Carrick's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 24 November 1982.
Clause 5 (Primary Taxable Amounts).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question which arises in relation to clause 5, which I do not believe was adequately canvassed or dealt with last time around, goes to the philosophy behind clause 5 (7) (c) (ii) which was the subject of some previous discussion. This is the provision which states that, for the purpose of determining the base amount of company tax liability for which the vendors and others are to be liable under this legislation, in a situation where one is looking to the amount of that liability immediately before the last sale time-in other words before the company in question was sold to the promoters and stripped and dumped-the company tax liability is to be assessed by reference to what might reasonably have been expected to become payable by the company during the financial year in question, not by reference to what actually did become payable by the company.

SPEECH.PARA: This has been construed by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)-it has been the subject already of some discussion-as clearly establishing that the recoupment legislation will not apply where there was a pre-sale avoidance scheme which proved ultimately to be unsuccessful.

The question which arises-I acknowledge that this is not a recent invention in the Bill; it was there from the outset as the Minister told us last time around- is: What is the justification in principle for calculating the primary liability in this way? Why should a vendor get the benefit of a reduction in his tax liability by virtue of a scheme which proves to be unsuccessful when he sells the company to a promoter who then goes ahead and strips and dumps it and yet does not get the benefit of that unsuccessful scheme if he in fact hangs on to the company for the duration of the financial year in question and does not sell it to a bottom-of-the-harbour promoter.

This legislation will put in a better-off position financially someone who sold a company in whatever state of mind to a bottom-of-the-harbour promoter and where that company was actually ultimately stripped. By the way in which this clause is calculated a vendor will be in a better situation than he would be if he had hung on to the company and not had anything to do with Brian Maher and people of his ilk. What is the moral of any other kind of justification for having a clause of that kind?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The provisions of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill in this clause set out the method of determining a company's contingent tax liability which is crucial in ascertaining whether the excess consideration test in sub-clauses (1) and (2) of clause 5 is met. The excess consideration test is the legislative manifestation of the test foreshadowed by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his announcement on 25 July, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The situations to which the special legislation will relate are those in which the shareholders in a company have together sold their shares in the company for a price that made it evident that company tax on profits that had by then arisen would not be paid.

The test contained in sub-paragraph 5 (7) (c) (ii) is not new to the Bill. As we have already said, it appeared in the original Bill introduced in the House of Representatives on 23 September. I make that point because I think suggestions were made that in some way it is intended to be the pre-sale counterpart of sub- clause (3) (12).
Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.30 p.m., under sessional orders, I shall leave the chair and report to the Senate.
—Order! It being 3.30 p.m., under sessional orders the Senate will now proceed to consider committee reports.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 November, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the report be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Senate Standing Committee is similar in wording to the one that we discussed in April; that is, to change the format of presenting petitions to the Parliament. When we were debating the matter on the last occasion, I lodged my objection about it and I think that was the reason this matter went back to the Standing Orders Committee . I am beginning to wonder whether the petitions which I have been presenting here in the last 12 months on behalf of concerned citizens dealing with Mr Anthony's home loan have had some bearing on this recommendation in that the petitions have caused some embarrassment to some people, and that is why the Standing Orders Committee is now recommending--
—I moved the proposition.
—I am not a member of the Standing Orders Committee.
—I am a member.
—I am not privy to the minutes, so I do not know what happened.
—Then do not guess.

—Perhaps in future when we get Standing Orders Committee reports we may get the minutes with them so that we can see who moved what, who seconded it, and what the debate was all about, instead of being in the dark as we are now. As this recommendation will be carried-I shall probably be the only dissenting voice; but I shall still oppose it-I am concerned that we shall be reverting to the same practice as that of the House of Representatives which is that a precis will be made by the Clerks, as they do now, and the precis is not even in the presentation of petitions in the report. The precis made is not always relevant in the wording to the petition which one is presenting. I have presented petitions here in the last few days, and even though the wording of the petition has been altered, the precis that I have got is exactly the same when it refers to 'young couples'. In the last week or so, the petitions that I have presented have contained no reference to 'young couples'. The wording of that petition has been 'Australian couples', who are asking for the same terms with a home loan as have been granted to Mr Anthony. I have had to alter them on every occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: We shall not get the opportunity to do that if we are to adopt the practice in use in the other place. I am concerned about the rights of citizens, people whom we represent in this Parliament, being taken away to a certain degree. I have looked at the recommendations. I think it is said that petitions will be referred to respective committees. I serve on two Senate Standing Committees. I find that there is hardly enough time now to do the work of those committees. We have references before the Standing Committee on National Resources and we cannot find time particularly to examine a Bill that has been referred to that Committee on plant variety rights. The time has caught up on us, and we are jammed for time to do that. We have other references at which we ought to be looking. Time is not available to do justice to the work of those committees. That is apart from Estimates committees and various select committees which take up members' time. If the petitions to be presented are to be moved to some committee to be looked at, that will involve more time being taken in committee work.

I shall not delay the Senate any longer, but I record again my objection to the recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee, which will take away certain rights of citizens. There are other matters in the report to which I have objected in the past and about which recommendations have been made in the Senate and agreed to. One such matter is sitting hours. Every Thursday we are in a mess. When we debated that matter I asked questions about whether the dining room staff and the people who work behind the scenes were consulted, and I was told, 'Yes, they were consulted', but when I ask those concerned I was told that they were never consulted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you consult them about next week?

—I have no need to consult them about next week's sittings because the hours will be the same next week, I expect, as they are this week. I do not think the honourable senator consulted them either. As far as he is concerned, he made a faux pas here when he said that he would be fully engaged next week on meeting constituents but then he went on to tell us that he wanted all next week off to examine Bills. So he cannot do the two things.
—That is not what I said.

—That is what the honourable senator said and he should have a look at the record tomorrow. I do not want to engage in any debate with the honourable senator. It is not worth while. That is what he said. I just put on record again that I lodge my strong objection to having rights taken away from citizens in relation to presenting petitions to the Senate in the form that has been in evidence ever since the Senate was established. For some reason people on the Standing Orders Committee have decided to change it. I do not know what the reason is, but they seem to think that a lot of time is taken up or wasted in the presentation of petitions. If we went back over the whole period and looked at the matter, I think we would find that less time is taken up in presenting petitions than even what was taken up today in arguing about whether we ought to sit next week or whether we should rise so that Senator Harradine can spend a lot of time in Tasmania talking to constituents. Therefore, I oppose the recommendations of the Standing Orders Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that I find myself in a small minority in accord with Senator McLaren, but in this case I agree with him . I shall certainly be voting against this restriction of the people's power. That is what it is. This is not just rhetoric. The people of this country, as indeed people have expected of their parliaments for many centuries, believe that a petition is of some value. Petitions are brought into this Parliament and reiterated, and perhaps carefully chosen for broadcasting time, as with some that I put in last year on lead in petrol. Week after week, those petitions, signed, as they were, by virtually every parents and citizens association in Sydney, had an effect. They were listened to by other people and by the people who produced them. I think they believed, with some right, that purely by the presence of those petitions, purely by the fact that they had brought them in, they had contributed to this country's political life.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us face it. We are constantly cutting back the amount of feedback that the ordinary elector can bring to the political process, anyway. Here is a move to cut it back still further and, I suggest, contemptuously, because people will continue to send in petitions on matters about which they feel strongly. If a person is prepared to stand on a hot street all day for a week and collect a thousand signatures, surely that must have some effect in this place. Surely it is worth the few seconds that it takes to get up and express the view of those people. Again, as Senator McLaren has said, many other things are done and said here that could easily be economised on rather than that.

From time to time we have lengthy speeches. Some honourable senators regularly speak for half an hour in this place when what they have said could easily have been said, and said better, in 10 minutes. Time and time again the time of this place is wasted. I am utterly opposed to a principle which says that we shall decide that, whatever fulminations we feel we must get out of our systems, these are more important than the only form of regular representation that the people of this country have to this Parliament. It will be a sad day indeed if this proposal passes the Senate. I implore honourable senators to think carefully about that. It is not just a matter of our time. It is a matter of the feelings of the people outside who feel themselves represented here and the extent to which they believe they can be involved in what we do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my intention to speak at length on this subject because it is a matter that has previously been the subject of debate before the Senate. As a result of that debate, the matter was referred back to the Standing Orders Committee of which on this side of the House my colleagues Senator Robertson and Senator Robert Ray and myself, as well as the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button), are members. I say to my friend and colleague Senator McLaren that all of the members of the Opposition who are members of the Standing Orders Committee are signatories to the recommendation that is now the subject of debate in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that the Committee gave serious and detailed consideration to the resolution of the Senate to ask the Standing Orders Committee to have another look at the matter. The Standing Orders Committee, having had a look at the matter, resolved, as everyone can see, that it should recommend to the Senate the same procedure that it had recommended before. I take argument with my friend Senator Mason from the Australian Democrats that this is an attempt to cut out the right of ordinary citizens of the community to petition the Parliament. Far be it from that; indeed, it is a modernisation of the procedure to give them a real voice in the Parliament of this nation.

If Senator Mason or other honourable senators read the recommendation, it will be seen that, if the new sessional order is adopted, the President will, as a matter of practice, have a list of all petitions circulated to honourable senators and the text of the petitions referred to the relevant standing committees so that, should those committees wish to inquire into any particular petition, they may seek a reference from the Senate to do so. That has not happened to date. We all know that what has happened to date is that a senator presents a petition to the Parliament. Then he either has the petition read, as is his present entitlement, or he presents it to the Parliament and, instead of the senator reading it, the Clerk notifies the Senate of the receipt of the petition.

Petitions will still be able to be received by the Senate. The only change in that respect will be that they will all be presented to the Senate by the Clerk. But, as soon as they are presented to the Senate by the Clerk, they will all, as a matter of practice, be referred to the multiplicity of Senate standing committees for consideration by senators who are members of those standing committees. Instead of the petitions that are received by this Parliament being pigeon-holed downstairs and collecting the dust of year after year they will now be the subject of reference to a standing committee. That standing committee, if it desires to inquire further into the matter, can seek a recommendation from the Senate for permission to inquire into and report upon the terms of the petition.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a real move forward.

—The Minister has confirmed what I have already said; it is a modernisation of the procedure, a procedure that has been going on here since Federation. As I understand it, the procedure on petitions has not changed at all from the day when petitions were first presented in 1901 when the Parliament first started sitting. Now there is a determination on the part of all members of the Standing Orders Committee to see that the voice of the people has some effect in this Parliament rather than being a signature on a piece of paper that ends up in a pigeon-hole in the table office. I am firmly of the belief that this recommendation of the Senate Standing Orders Committee should be supported at least because it is only for a sessional period-a trial period. I believe the trial period will prove the effectiveness of it. Therefore, I support the recommendation of the Standing Orders Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add very briefly to the comments of my colleague Senator Douglas McClelland on this matter. Initially, I wish to assure Senator McLaren that we had no ulterior motive in bringing forward this proposition. I find it very disturbing that this is the second time that Senator McLaren has attributed ulterior motives to the Senate Standing Orders Committee with respect to some of the propositions which it has put forward. I find it embarrassing to refer to it because of the close personal friendship which I have with Senator McLaren.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me assure him that we do have-as we have on another committee on which I serve with him-harmonious discussions in our Standing Orders Committee meetings. We work very hard. I say that without any sense of-shall we say-conceit. We spend a lot of time considering the various matters referred to us. The Standing Orders Committee meets more often now than it has done in recent years. We attempt to do exactly what the Minister and my colleage mentioned-that is, to try to modernise or to improve the Standing Orders. That is the purpose of the Standing Orders Committee. We do try, as we have done in a number of other areas , to say: 'There have been some suggestions that we ought to look at some improvements'. That is the reason we meet. We came up with a unanimous proposition that we should attempt for a sessional period to handle petitions in a different way.

Senator McLaren asked: 'What is the purpose of the proposition?' Quite clearly, it is to save time. We spend up to 45 minutes-in fact more on some occasions-on the presentation of petitions. If we use the word 'save', we have to say: 'Save for what?' What will we do with the time which we will save? The proposition of the Standing Orders Committee is that this time will be spent in debating reports, Government Business, private members' Bills and so on. It does not seem a lot but if we spend 45 minutes twice a week it represents quite a lot of time. It is not only a matter of saving time totally; it is also a matter of not spending 45 minutes on petitions in the early morning or early afternoon which frustrates the work of the day and makes it very difficult for us to get started .

We know that time is a problem in the Senate. We do find it very difficult to find time to do all the things that have to be done. In the debate just completed, Senator Macklin drew attention to the fact that a lot more work now comes before the Senate. We have to make the most effective use of our time. That is what we are putting forward as a proposition. It is all very well for some to say that the contribution of some members is not an effective use of time. I deny that. Every honourable senator who stands in this place-I have no doubt-prepares his or her work carefully and hopes that his or her contribution to debate in the Senate or in the Committee of the Whole is an effective contribution to the total debate. We must ask: What is the value of the reading of petitions? What purpose is achieved by having 23 or 24 petitions read out? Senator Mason has suggested that this will help the people outside and that--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had a couple of houses sold.

—With all due respect, I doubt very much whether that was the result of the reading of petitions. There was a lot of other activity, including some media coverage, which followed not the petitions-despite what Senator McLaren said-but certain comments which Senator McLaren made in another debate. Senator McLaren does not limit himself to presenting petitions. He tends to spread his interests across the various aspects of work in the Senate and to contribute to the same topic in a number of areas.

SPEECH.PARA: We think that petitions can be more effectively handled if they are handled in the way in which we suggest. I do not have to develop the argument as Senator Douglas McClelland has done to indicate that petitions can be presented and more effectively handled than they are at the moment. I make the point that the change has been made in the House of Representatives. This is basically the way that petitions are handled in the House of Representatives. I have not noticed any diminution of petitions. I have not noticed that people have stopped standing in the hot sun-I believe Senator Mason said that-collecting signatures. They still feel it is effective. I believe that we should adopt that course. I believe we will also find that it is effective. I was quite surprised to find that Senator Mason downgraded his contribution by saying that the only representation that people have in this place is by the presentation of petitions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that. I said it was the only direct means they had of communicating with us. Look at the Hansard report.

—I would have thought that we made a contribution in that we were here representing the people of Australia and also we were able to put their point of view far more effectively, I would suggest, than a piece of paper with some signatures on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I supported the making of this recommendation by the Standing Orders Committee on the basis that every Wednesday the Senate wastes half an hour on petitions. The only effect is to bore school children and to drop the ratings of the parliamentary broadcasts. The petitions go from this place to gather dust somewhere else.
—That does not happen.

—They also-Senator Mason cannot understand this-delude people in the electorate. People conscientiously sign petitions on the understanding that they will have some effect. I am sure I do not very often, and I am sure Senator Mason does not, go through the procedures and say: 'This is a rather gigantic con; the petitions will go down to the basement of Parliament House never to be heard of again'. It has been said that the actual reading out of petitions-it takes 30 to 40 seconds for each petition-once a week is a way for people to get direct and effective representation in this chamber. If that is all it is, it is not worth having.

SPEECH.PARA: Although my colleagues have done so, I too defend us against Senator McLaren's allegation that maybe we have bowed to pressure from the Deputy Prime Minister ( Mr Anthony) on this matter following his campaign against Mr Anthony. That campaign reminds me of the inspector in Les Miserables. Senator McLaren, through every means possible, has doggedly brought the facts out and finally has achieved a magnificent result. I congratulate him on it. But I agree with Senator Robertson that petitions were not an essential element of that result. It was Senator McLaren's brilliant speeches in the adjournment debate, his magnificent first reading speeches to which, on occasion, I had the pleasure to listen and his very effective questioning on Estimates committees. All those things contributed to it; all those avenues are open to honourable senators. I also say to Sentor McLaren that he has had so many signatures on those petitions that if he continues to produce them here there will be some doubt as to their authenticity because I am sure most Australians have already signed them.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least once.

—At least once, as Senator Baume says. I agree with Senator McClelland; what is proposed is a way of expediting the business of the Senate. It is a way in which we can modernise the procedures. Finally-the main point that I mentioned earlier-it removes the farcical element of petitions that people in the electorate actually believe they will achieve something. It is all a bit of a con. They sign the petition, forget the issue and the petition is thrown in the basement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Mason and Senator McLaren are opposed to the proposed Sessional Order as such.
—We opt for the status quo.

—I am not opting for the status quo. There is merit in the suggestion by the Standing Orders Committee that as a matter of practice petitions be circulated and the texts referred to the relevant standing committees.
—But that can be done on motion, now.
—No, it cannot be done on motion now.
—I did it once.

—With respect, it cannot be done. I seek advice from the Chair on this. As I read Standing Order 96, the only occasion on which it can be referred to a committee is when the subject matter of the petition deals with the subject matter of a select committee. It can then be referred to such a committee. I refer honourable senators to Standing Order 96, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The only Questions entertained by the Senate on the presentation of a Petition shall be-I. ''That the Petition be received;'' II. ''That the Petition be read;' ' III. ''That the Petition be printed;'' IV. (in the case of a Petition against a return) ''That the Petition be referred at once to the Committee of Disputed Returns and Qualifications;'' or V. (in the case of a Petition respecting any subject then under the consideration of a Select Committee) ''That the Petition be referred to the Select Committee on-.''
The petition is then referred to the relevant select committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is probably an outdated Standing Order. It refers only to select committees and not to standing committees. It is probably just outdated; unfortunately, it is there.

—I understand the honourable senator's interjection. In other words, when this Standing Order was devised there were no standing committees. We have got to the stage where the Standing Orders Committee has reported on the matter of petitions. I agree that a valuable part of that report is the suggestion that the text of petitions be referred to Senate standing committees. However, I too believe that we should be careful about this question of not having petitions read. I think the text of petitions ought to be read. My view is that petitions on the same subject matter and with the same text ought not to be read twice. At the moment, any honourable senator can ask that a petition be read even though a similar petition has been read once already. Most honourable senators, myself included, rarely if ever ask that a petition be read if it has been read already. That is one way of getting it out of the road.

SPEECH.PARA: We could streamline the procedure by having the petitions lodged with the Clerk and not requiring an honourable senator to say: 'I present a petition from X number of citizens and I ask that the petition be read'. We could cut all that out and just let the Clerks state that they have a petition from a particular senator signed by so many citizens and read the text. It ought to be read out. In that sense, I wonder whether somebody from the Standing Orders Committee can advise the Senate whether that possibility has been canvassed. I am at a disadvantage in that I am not on the Standing Orders Committee, although I would have liked to be a member of that Committee and also the Select Committee on Parliamentary Appropriations and Staffing. I will have a talk with Senator Mason on that at a later stage. I ask any member of the Standing orders Committee whether that possibility was examined.
Question put:
That the report be adopted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON SOUTH WEST TASMANIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 November, on motion by Senator Archer:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I lay on the table the two consultants' reports prepared by the McLachlan group for the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania's report on Demand and Supply of Electricity for Tasmania and Other Matters. On Tuesday in this chamber I advised of my dissent to the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania and I now produce the tabling statement to that dissenting report.

SPEECH.PARA: Fourteen months ago when the reference was set up it was clearly on the issue of the Gordon-below-Franklin dam and the environment issues more than the power requirements. Firstly, the anti-dam argument then set out to question the need for more power in Tasmania within a reasonable time frame and, secondly, that the proposed Gordon-below-Franklin was not as economical as other alternatives. It would be reasonable to infer from this that the Tasmanian Government and the people were considered either incapable of, or irrelevant to, the making of their own decisions on these two fundamental matters.

Arrangements were made by the Committee to divide the reference into parts, considering under one heading the question of supply and demand and, under the other, matters relating to the environment, land-use and questions of Commonwealth intervention. About two months ago two additional chapters were added, contrary, I believe, to the balance of the document and the clear settlement of the supply-demand issues on which all the other matters hinged. Specifically, chapter 9, which covers archaeolgical matters, appears to me to be totally out of context, as this report makes no mention of any other environmental or land use matters at all.

The report to follow, which will cover those matters, will be incomplete without that material. Chapter 10 leaves the Committee open to quite justifiable criticism. As raised in the main report, the Committee, having not obtained its own legal opinion, heard not one independent legal witness, or canvassed or discussed any of the range of alternative views on constitutional and other contentious matters, I saw no reason to include such a chapter in the supply- demand area. Again, it will be obviously necessary in the second report where it rightly belongs, and there it will need to be considerably broadened.

It became the duty of the Committee to obtain evidence to determine whether the decisions of the Tasmanian Government to accept the Hydro-Electric Commission's projections of likely power use were reasonable and acceptable. Although some novel and interesting theories were tested, by any accepted methodology of projection the program of the Tasmanian Government has not been shaken. The determination of future demand can only be a matter of judgment, based on evidence and advice. Advice came from the HEC, Tasmanian industries, industry associations and a Government department as well as from independent people and organisations. The first group all supported the need for a major option; the others did not. The McLachlan group raised all the difficulties of accurate projection but in its bands of forecast covered the HEC estimate on the high end .

As the Tasmanian Government proposal involves an increased annual industrial use of 1.5 per cent only, as against recent recorded growth of 7 per cent and, as no government has any vested interest in extravagant expenditure, I am not persuaded that there is evidence before the Committee to reject or question that the HEC demand frame is inappropriate. For adequacy and economy the Tasmanian power supply is the envy of every other power authority in Australia. As to alternatives, I agree with the consultant McLachlan that there are only three possibilities of any consequence; namely, hydro-electricity, thermal power and an interstate undersea cable. For the several other interesting alternatives our consultants said on page 9, paragraph 3.8:

While these technologies are developing, it is not likely that they will have significant, cost competitive, reliable supply available, at least until the late 1990s. Therefore they are not appropriate as a basic or back up option for this study period.

I could not but agree. Quite significantly the thermal alternative is totally demolished on cost by both McLachlan and Zeidler, without considering the additional disabilities that such a scheme presents. Evidence important to Tasmania was given concerning environmental pollution. McLachlan on page 10, at paragraph 3.11 said:

Significant increase in capacity of coal fired power stations in Tasmania is an economically risky path to follow, compared with either the cable or the proposed hydro schemes. This path would seem to be costly compared with the other alternatives for Tasmania at present.

Quite reasonably, on all bases, a coal fired thermal unit is not regarded as an alternative to the present hydro-electric proposal. Our consultants raised hopes on a cable connection, but at the same time included quotations saying on page 31 of their report:
Sir David Zeidler concluded the cost of generation from a coal-fired thermal station was 2.86 times that of the Gordon-below-Franklin and a cable would be 2. 5 times (that cost).
The quotation continues:
In any event, the SECV has advised that firm energy is not available for importation to Tasmania from Victoria, in 'the time scale required to meet load forecasts'.
On page 11, at paragraph 3.13 McLachlan concludes:
We-
That is, McLachlan-
do not know whether Victoria would welcome a major new customer such as HEC, or whether they would prefer not to have such customers.
As well, on page 13, paragraph 3.22, McLachlan raises a powerful consideration, when he says:
Naturally Tasmania must be wary of any proposal which would bring into their power supply, industrial problems which currently they avoid.

Until all these unresolved matters are put to study and adequately considered, the cable cannot be regarded as a way to fill Tasmania's energy needs. The sociological and economic aspects of undertaking a development which would produce a substantial export of scarce employment has also not been adequately addressed and resolved, and is of great importance to Tasmania.
On the other hand, concerning the Gordon- below-Franklin, McLachlan's first conclusion states:

The Gordon-below-Franklin is a good hydro-electric scheme economically. It can provide 172 MW (av.) extra electric power to the Tasmania grid if used near its capacity more economically than any other hydro or coal-fired thermal options.
On page 34 McLachlan quotes the HEC, as saying:

Providing proper recognition is given to the depreciating value of money, it can be demonstrated that the Gordon-below-Franklin scheme, would in all probability, be the most economic hydro-electric development ever to be built in Tasmania.

I have to regard these statements as being most significant. In spite of this, the Committee's report goes to great length to explain and develop theoretical and academic approaches to the hypothetical development of the proposal under review on the basis for which no examples could be provided, and with which it appears that no similar organisations in Australia agree. In regard to the funding of the dam, neither the witnesses nor the Committee presented a case that was convincing enough to show that the theories are acceptable in practice. Accordingly, I accept the established and accepted basis and do so with the McLachlan comment on page 57, paragraph 16, that:
It is apparent that there is no uniformly accepted rate for, or method of, assessing the cost of funds invested in Government bodies in Australia.

In many areas the Committee fails to acknowledge the basic rights and responsibilities that the State not only possesses, but also for which it has to be totally responsible. McLachlan again states this very clearly on page 15, paragraph 5, when he says:

Whatever project and band is accepted, it is then the task of the body responsible for supply, in this instance the HEC of Tasmania, to provide electricity to meet actual demand as it occurs within the forecast band.
Again on page 26, paragraph 7.4, he reminds us that:
Therefore the supply authority has to decide on a projection, and make decisions to that projection years before a forecast demand is proven.

I totally support the fact that in areas where States have the responsibility to determine and provide services, they should do so, and I do not support Federal interference in such matters. The report fails to accept the summary provided by McLachlan on page 14, point 4, which says:
This statement adequately describes the ingredients of supply of electricity to Tasmania. These ingredients might be summarised as:
(1) reliability;
(2) lowest possible cost to the consumer;
(3) using Tasmania's natural resources (mainly hydro-power);
(4) providing employment in Tasmania for Tasmanians.

To go on from there I regret that the Committee gave totally inadequate recognition of this being Tasmania, not just an academic exercise. A variety of issues such as Tasmanian development and industrial policy, its employment situation, consideration of employment and the multiplier effect of suggested actions, or lack of actions, were not handled, and I believed deserved a separate chapter.

In conclusion, I share the disappointment that many will have in this report. The Committee did not consider or resolve the question of the dam; it does suggest that a decision be delayed three years or more. It feeds indecision and uncertainty at a time when State government policy is for action and development . It fails to recognise Tasmania's inherent problems. The physical isolation can be tackled only by endeavouring to maximise its few natural advantages, including the capacity to produce and sell power at attractive rates. It fails to realise that Tasmania's need for employment opportunities for its young people depends on Tasmania being accepted by interstate and overseas entrepreneurs as a place with adequate energy supplies and where opportunities for profitable investment exists. It is totally negative, and right through choses the worst alternative. Adherence to such a philosophy built on the report would make Tasmania's position even relatively worse than it now is. I do regret that the different approaches taken have prevented there being a unanimous decision, but because of the fundamental difference of approach this was not to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania rather than to the dissenting opinion just expressed by the Committee's Chairman, Senator Archer. It would not be an understatement to say that this was one of the most eagerly awaited reports that a Senate committee has ever presented. I am pleased and relieved that we have now reported after so many months of work and deliberation. I was naive enough to think that we could have had out an initial report-not as big as the one we have presented-by about last March or April. That did not happen, of course. We had an aim of July, as I remember then, and a definite and even announced date of September. As it happened, it was another two months again before we were able to produce the report. There was a huge amount of work to be done. We certainly could have gone on more thoroughly still but it was important that the report not be delayed any further. In the rush of ensuring that the report came out when it did, it is not as complete as I would have wanted. There was not enough time, for instance, to review its words as carefully as we would have wished. But I support its contents. I hope that interested parties will excuse us for the odd mistakes in words that may appear in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like particularly to pay a tribute to the Committee staff-the Secretary , Paul Barsdell, the researcher, Pippa Carron, and before her David Nimmo and the staff over at East Block, and before that at the Hotel Canberra and Annette Fischer who operated the word processors and perhaps other unseen people who had the unenviable task of trying to satisfy our demands. They tolerated our reasonable and unreasonable demands very cheerfully. In passing I would also like to congratulate the Australian Government Publishing Service on responding to my suggestion of despatching copies of the report to Tasmania on Tuesday as soon as they were tabled so that they could be sold by the Australian Government Bookshop in Hobart the first thing yesterday morning. I think it is important for this to happen as much as possible so that people are able to obtain copies of important reports promptly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did Mr Gray buy a copy? Do you know?

—No. I understand Mr Gray made his comments without having obtained a copy. He may have shelled out to buy a copy but he did not ask me for one. The question of demand, as dealt with in the report, was perhaps the most important aspect. I think as a partial answer to what Senator Archer was saying it is important to emphasise that the price of Gordon-below- Franklin power would be a good price only if it were all to be sold. I think that cannot be emphasised too much. In my view, there is even more spare capacity than we refer to in the report because of a greater than necessary allowance for drought in the system on top of planned and unplanned outages. Even with the Committee's sober assessment of demand projections we conclude in paragraph 11.7:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that construction of a major option . . . does not have to be commenced for at least three years, while still allowing the upper limit of the forecast of demand to be met.

I emphasise the words 'while still allowing the upper limit of the forecast of demand to be met'. The whole basis of our response is that there ought to be flexible supply strategy, as we mention in paragraph 11.11. It states:

The Committee decided that a supply strategy which would respond quickly to exigencies but ensure continuity of supply while minimising the risk of having substantial capital tied up in unused generating facilities, is required.
We went on to say in paragraph 11.12:
To commence construction of a major option at this time would be inconsistent with that supply strategy.

As Senator Archer mentioned, we also referred to the archaeological importance of the area and the legal responsibilities of the Commonwealth. I reject his view that it was unreasonable for us to go into those areas. They were areas that arose during the period of the inquiry and it was quite crucial that we devote our attention to them. We did take as much evidence as we intended to take on the archaeological area and it was possible for us to report on that. Senator Archer referred to the fact that we did not get an independent legal witness. I would like to ask: What is an independent legal witness? Is there such a body in this world? I suggest that there is not. What we did was take evidence from lawyers. It is not as though we had contrary opinions submitted to us on which we did not take oral evidence. The Committee had to conclude that:

. . . nothing has emerged from the inquiry which should persuade the Commonwealth Government from proceeding with the listing which involves the Government in fulfilling its obligations and responsibilities under the provisions of the UNESCO Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage.

I shall answer one or two other comments made by Senator Archer. It is a pity that his strong remarks came late in the proceedings. I think that the rest of the Committee members would have felt better about the matter if he had expressed as strong a statement as he made in the last few days when we were preparing the earlier chapters of the report. I think he referred to the report as being negative. His dissenting opinion is terribly negative about the comments that the majority made. I wonder why he joined the Committee in the first place and agreed to be its chairman. I think the gist of Senator Archer's response is no different from the sort of response from Tasmania over many years to Bills which seek to implement recommendations regarding hydro-electric power. There is the automatic response from some people that the Tasmanian Parliament should not interfere at all and should not change anything put up by the Hydro- Electric Commission. Senator Archer virtually takes this line and says that if the HEC says it, it must be true. In response to that, I would like to say that if one takes that attitude, why should the Tasmanian Parliament have the ability to pass or not to pass such Bills, and why should a committee of the Parliament have the ability to deal with the matter? If that was his attitude all along, why support the existence of the Committee?

In the couple of minutes remaining to me I shall make a few responses to the attacks made on me and other members of the Committee by the Premier of Tasmania , Mr Gray. He accused me and Senator Primmer, the other Labor member of the Committee, of taking the attitude we took because we were obliged to support Australian Labor Party policy. He suggested that we were instructed to take the line we took. I find that suggestion most insulting. I can assure him that there was no such instruction and that that sort of caucusing does not happen in respect of any members on any of the parliamentary committees. I am pleased to hear Senator Primmer and other Opposition senators supporting that comment. The members of the Committee bent over backwards to keep an open mind on the issues it dealt with and to make its decision on the evidence as presented and thoroughly dealt with by it.

Mr Gray also made the amazing suggestion that other Liberal members of the Committee apart from Senator Archer-that is, Senator Missen and Senator Hill-did not seek any additional information on the dam from the State Government. I find that remark absolutely amazing, coming from a Premier who refuses even to recognise the existence of the Committee. The Committee wrote to him several times seeking a continuation of the co-operation that had been given by the previous Labor State Government, and he did not deign even to reply to the letters. That meant that we did not hear evidence from the National Parks and Wildlife Service of Tasmania and did not have further detailed information from the Hydro-Electric Commission that would have enabled us to fill out the report a little more.

I emphasise my strong support for the recommendations and conclusions of the Committee. I point out that, despite all the huffing and puffing of Mr Gray in Tasmania, if the scheme turned out to be an economic disaster the responsibility would inevitably fall on the Commonwealth. Tasmania would not be able to deal with it. It therefore is a Commonwealth matter and it has every right to be involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. I call Senator Walters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I want to--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is it not normal courtesy in these matters to call upon a member of the Committee? We have only five minutes left in which to debate this matter. I do not want to enter into an intra-Liberal Party fight, but I should have thought that as a matter of courtesy you would have called Senator Missen who was a member of the Committee.
—Senator Missen rose in his place earlier.
—He certainly caught my eye first, notwithstanding the more attractive colours worn by Senator Walters.

—That may be, Senator Chipp, because you are closer to Senator Missen than I. I knew that Senator Missen was about to seek the call, but when I turned around the first person I saw happened to be Senator Walters. I think I called correctly. Do you wish to speak to the point of order, Senator Missen?

—I hoped to have an opportunity in the moments that remained, not so much to speak to the report but to say something about the fact that I will be absent for any debate that may occur should this report result in a Bill.
—Senator Missen, are you speaking to the point of order or are you seeking leave to say something?
—I am seeking the opportunity to speak before I leave. If I do not get that opportunity I will have to make some public statement.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, at 4.30 p.m. when we adjourn this debate if Senator Missen seeks leave to make a brief statement I certainly will not stand in his way.
—I again call Senator Walters.

—That discussion leaves me with very little speaking time. The report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania amazes me. It is most extraordinary that a group of senators from other States would tell any State that it cannot use its natural resources to expand its economy and to employ its residents at the cheapest possible cost. The area in which hydro- electric power is generated in Tasmania is very similar to the Cooper Basin gas fields of South Australia and the Yallourn Valley of Victoria. Who in this place would accept that we should tell Victoria or South Australia that they have no right to use their natural resources, that we think that those areas should be put on the World Heritage List and that they should not be able to use their natural resources for energy? The report acknowledges that Tasmania will have to build a major power station but, it states, not for three years. The three options given are hydro-electric power, thermal power or a connection with Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: As a Tasmanian representative in this place I tell the Senate that we are not interested in taking on any of the industrial problems which Victoria has. We already take on those industrial problems on the wharves. When there are strikes on the wharves in Victoria, Tasmania is denied its shipping across Bass Strait. We do not want to take on any of the industrial problems connected with Victoria 's coal. It has already been stated by Senator Archer that thermal power would be far more costly. I can assure Senator Coates that if he goes to the Fingal Valley he will be assured by the Fingal Valley residents that they are not interested in having a thermal power station to pollute their beautiful valley. Tasmania has no pollution of this kind at the moment and we have no intention of having it introduced to our beautiful island.

The Committee stated that it cannot possibly establish what the costs per unit of electricity would be. However, its adviser established the costs rather conclusively, but the Committee felt that it did not like to take that angle and said that it could not come down with any method of establishing a cost per unit . Water has no increasing costs; coal has and certainly the Victorian connection would have vastly increasing costs as time goes by. To date Tasmania has the cheapest electricity in the country. I have before me a table setting out electricity consumption and income in 1980-81 in the States. I seek leave to have this table incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 4.30 p.m. under sessional order the Senate will now proceed to consider General Business.

—by leave-I know that the Senate will move in a moment from the truncated debate on the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania to debate the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill which is seen, particularly by the Australian Democrats, as being a desirable method of ensuring the enforcement of the recommendations by the Committee. I support the majority decision. I will not be present during the debate and I merely want to say that if I were here I would vote for the Bill. I am not paired against the Bill. I believe that the Bill is somewhat defective but, with repair, could be used by the Government if it saw fit. That is a decision that must be made by the Government and there are other methods that can be adopted. Senator Hill will be outlining other methods. In general I understand the point of view that he will be raising. I think he would like to see the Bill deferred because the House of Representatives will not resume until 8 December and no action will take place until then. I think we are rushing this matter on to the Government and others who have not had a chance to read the report. If the Senate proceeds with the carriage of the Bill, I think it is probably on the whole worth while and it is another weapon which the Government could consider. I want to make it clear that that is the attitude I would take, although I will not be here during the debate on the Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Senator Mason:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to open the debate by saying that the Opposition will support the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill proposed by Senator Mason, with amendments by the Australian Labor Party. This Bill represents an attempt to implement in Australia the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. That Convention was ratified by Australia in 1974 and came into force on 17 December 1975. Honourable senators may be aware that Australia has already nominated five areas to be placed on the World Heritage List established by the Convention.
