The most recent nomination is that of the South West Tasmanian region.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Australian Labor Party supported the decision of the Fraser Government to nominate this area for inclusion on the World Heritage List. We believe very strongly that a bipartisan approach to the protection of our natural heritage must be pursued if such protective measures are to be effective . We are prepared to adopt a bipartisan approach. We have in this particular case and we hope and expect that the Fraser Government will reciprocate by passing this Bill in both Houses of Parliament. I should point out that any lesser action than the passage of this Bill would seriously undermine the Fraser Government's national and international credibility in this important area. It must be made clear at this stage of the debate that the passage of this Bill would effectively prevent the Gordon below Franklin dam. That is the position which the Australian Labor Party is supporting today.

Before I comment on the specific provisions of the Bill and explain the purpose of the Opposition's amendments, which I understand will be accepted by Senator Mason, I should like to make some comments about the South West Tasmanian region and the responsibilities of the Commonwealth Government to protect this region. The South West Tasmanian region ranks in environmental significance with the Great Barrier Reef, Ayers Rock and Kakadu National Park. It is one of the few temperate wilderness regions left on earth. The importance of the region has been demonstrated by its listing on the National Estate and its nomination by the Fraser Government, as I have said, for World Heritage listing. Evidence given to the recent inquiry by the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania supports and reinforces these decisions.

The Senate Committee's main task was to examine the demand for power in Tasmania and to form a supply strategy for meeting that demand. I am aware that the Senate has recently concluded a debate arising from the presentation of the Committee's report. But as well as considering the power situation in Tasmania, the Senate Committee received and considered a great deal of evidence concerning the environmental importance of the area and the Committee considered that that information warranted the inclusion of that area on the national and international registers. In paragraph 11.17 of the report the Committee points out that such an assessment of the importance of the area is warranted by the evidence submitted. The Committee concluded that:

. . . nothing has emerged from the inquiry which would persuade the Commonwealth Government from proceeding with the listing which involves the Government in fulfilling its obligations and responsibilities under the provisions of the UNESCO Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage.

There is an additional and I think enormously important environmental reason why this region must be protected. I refer to the existence within the region of archeological sites of amazing and, as yet, not fully understood importance to our understanding of the history of the human race. In reading the evidence given to the Senate Committee, I found that some of the most compelling evidence was that presented by Dr Rhys Jones of the department of pre-history at the Australian National University. Dr Rhys Jones, as honourable senators are no doubt aware, is a scholar of national and international repute who has specialised in Aboriginal pre-history. I must say that it is unfortunate that the information now available to us through the work of Dr Rhys Jones and also through that of his colleague, Professor Mulvaney, concerning the archeological importance of the caves in the lower Franklin region, was not available to the Tasmanian Government when the dam was first proposed some years ago-in 1979 I believe. I cannot believe that matters would have developed in the unfortunate way that they have if this archeological evidence had been available then. However, it is available now and it does create a new and very heavy responsibility on the Commonwealth Government to protect the archeological sites . I should like to quote briefly from an article by Dr Jones. Describing the Fraser cave in the Franklin region, Dr Jones writes:

A small pilot excavation into a bank of deposit on the site of the entrance chamber showed that this site is one of the richest ever found in Australia. Altogether out of less than a cubic metre of deposit some 80,000 stone flakes and tools and an equal number of animal bone fragments were recovered.
He further states:
Radio carbon dates now being done on these show them again to date from the period of about 16-18,000 years old.

In terms of their age the richness and nature of their evidence for hunters living in the last ice age tundra conditions, the limestone caves of the Franklin can be compared with some of the classic Dordogne in France. They are part of the cultural heritage of mankind.

I think that final statement by Dr Jones makes it very clear to all of us what our collective responsibility to protect the region really amounts to. We are not talking about an area of parochial interest, we are not talking about a States rights matter, we are not indeed even talking about a national issue; we are talking about an area which is part of the cultural heritage of mankind, as Dr Rhys Jones has so clearly stated.

A more extensive account of the importance of these sites and the length of time that will be required by scholars to investigate them and to benefit from the information they contain can be found in the transcripts of the evidence given to the Committee. I do not have time to draw the Senate's attention to those matters now. But I point out that the assessments of Dr Jones and Professor Mulvaney have been endorsed by many other scholars throughout the world. For example, a report in the Canberra Times of 7 September refers to 24 of the world's leading archaeologists and anthropologists who had written to the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, opposing the planned hydro-scheme dam on the Franklin River in South West Tasmania. Amongst the international scholars who were named are Professor W. Howell, an anthropologist from Harvard University, Professor Grahame Clark, from Cambridge University, Mr Derek Rowe, a research director at Oxford University and Cambridge archaeology lecturer Mr Paul Melars and several others. Again, in the report in the Age of 27 September we are told that prominent British zoologist, Mr David Attenborough, and botanist, Mr David Bellamy, have asked Mr Fraser to use any powers available to preserve the region . We can only endorse that urging of those scholars at this stage.

Without trying to accommodate and discuss at this point the nature of the evidence that is available as to the significance of this site, I simply state this: In line with the Federal Australian Labor Party commitment to Aboriginal Australia we insist on the protection of these sites. Of course, that means that the dam must not be built. Clearly, both in wilderness terms and in terms of archaeological significance, the region must be protected. Over and above the force of these arguments are the legal and constitutional responsibilities which I believe have now devolved on the Commonwealth Government. There can be no doubt that the Commonwealth Government, by being a signatory to the International Convention and through its own decision to place the region on the World Heritage List, has created for itself a legal as well as a moral obligation to act.

I am aware, the Federal Australian Labor Party is aware, of the controversial nature of this discussion of the Commonwealth's role within the State of Tasmania. We are sympathetic to the difficulties being faced by Tasmanians but we also recognise that the Commonwealth has specific and overriding powers and responsibilities in some matters of national and international significance. The South West region of Tasmania is not simply a part of Tasmania; it is a part of Australia and comes legally within the environmental responsibilities of the Commonwealth Government as a result of international instruments. The opinion from the Attorney-General's Department of 1 July 1982 on this matter has already been tabled in the House of Representatives. This opinion confirms the view I have just outlined. The Senate Committee concluded that:
. . . the Commonwealth may well be obliged to act to preserve the area and has a considerable number of powers and options open to it to enable it to meet that responsibility.

At this point we must agree on two things: First, that the region requires protection by the Commonwealth; and secondly, that the Commonwealth clearly has the power and the responsibility to protect it. Why then is there any opposition ?

I turn now to Tasmania. The Federal Australian Labor Party is extremely sympathetic to the economic difficulties that have plagued that State for some years now. We have been all too aware of the collapse of the manufacturing and the mining industry in that State, of the enormously high levels of unemployment for all age groups and of the higher cost of living caused by Tasmania's isolation from the mainland. All of these matters have been recognised and addressed at length within the Labor Party. We understand and we have some sympathy for the desperation about Tasmania's economy which led successive Tasmanian governments to adopt the idea of damming the Franklin. From the point of view of the Federal Labor Party, however, there are many serious reservations about the economic consequences of proceeding with the Franklin dam at this stage. In addition, we are committed to protect the areas for the reasons I have outlined.

We have studied carefully the evidence given to the Senate Committee and the conclusions of that Committee. We have concluded that Tasmania's need for the Gordon-below-Franklin power has not been convincingly demonstrated. For example, in Tasmania 18 bulk electricity consumers use 60 per cent of the State's power, but contribute only 37 per cent of the Hydro-Electric Commission's revenues at an average price of 0.9 cents a kilowatt hour. While future demand for power depends on these bulk consumers, they no longer have a significant influence on Tasmania's economic development. For example, these bulk users employ only seven per cent of Tasmania's work force. They are facing increasing economic problems. The companies affected include Comalco at Bell Bay which has abandonded expansion plans and is not replacing burnt out pots and the Electrolytic Zinc Co . of Australasia Ltd which has had to sack 350 people in July of this year. Temco has scrapped expansion plans, sacked 63 people in May of this year and closed its number one furnace and sister plant, Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd at Geeveston has delayed its plant closure by one month only and 350 people are likely to be sacked. No new bulk users have established in Tasmania for 10 years. Time does not permit me to make a further analysis of the role played by hydro-industrialisation in Tasmania's economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have another 20 minutes-plenty of time.

—I have some other matters to raise, Senator Harradine. Any objective assessment of available information leads one to the conclusion that hydro-industrialisation has failed to diversify and improve the economic base of Tasmania. Massive expenditure on further dams will not improve permanent employment prospects in that State.
—Who said that?

—Senator Harradine may wish to differ with this view, but he will have to produce entirely new evidence if he is to persuade the Opposition, the Australian Democrats or anybody else-except the people acting in desperation in Tasmania-that the answer to Tasmania's economic problems is the creation of this dam. There is simply no conclusive evidence to that effect. I suggest that Senator Harradine pay attention again to the Senate Committee's report. However, we are, as I said, extremely sympathetic to the problems of Tasmania and we believe that there must be a well worked out strategy for the revival of Tasmania's economy.

SPEECH.PARA: At this point I will describe to the Senate the steps that the Australian Labor Party believes ought to be taken; indeed, the next Federal Labor Government will take these steps for that purpose. We have developed a seven stage program for the economic development of Tasmania. Those seven stages include the following: In association with the Tasmanian Government we will explore alternative economically viable power generation projects with the aim of their funding on terms comparable to those which would have applied to the proposed South West Tasmania power generation development project, we want to ensure that total Federal payments to Tasmania do not fall in real terms-that is a commitment from our party, we want to support the proposed Tasmanian Development Corporation, we will ensure that Labor's regional, economic and industrial development policies are applied with specific attention to the special disabilities and needs of Tasmania. We will encourage the Tasmanian Government, in co-operation with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, to establish a South West Tasmanian management authority responsible for the management of the World Heritage area extended to include the entire South West reservation area. We will provide financial assistance for capital and recurrent expenditure by the authority including payments to the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service to meet its responsibilities in this area.

I think a most practical aspect of our seven stage plan is that we will instigate a number of initiatives to assist Tasmania's tourist industry; in particular, we will encourage and, where possible, provide finance or generous loans for the development of man-made attractions and information audio visual facilities in co-operation with Tasmania, local governments, private non-profit organisations and the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd to finance the construction of low cost tourist accommodation, we will promote cheap travel for international and Australian tourists by air and air-coach tickets which will give unlimited travel for a set period. We will examine specific tourist projects for Federal financial assistance with particular attention to projects which assist the west coast economy which, of course is badly affected by the reduction of mining production. We believe that that plan, if implemented, would lead to economic recovery in Australia and would obviate the necessity for the building of the dam. But more fundamental than that, we consider that the Commonwealth Government has to take into account the interests of this society as a whole. It has to take into account its responsibilities to the international community.

Obviously the Government is aware of the significance of the region or it would not have taken the steps which it has taken to date. It is, I suppose understandably, in a short term political sense, loath to intervene in a situation in which some Tasmanians say that they want no intervention. But this is not a situation where the Commonwealth Government can turn its back. It is not a situation in which it can simply say that its federalism policy will apply and Tasmanians can do what they like with the wilderness area. It is a much more serious situation than that. As I said, the Federal Australian Labor Party wants to adopt a bipartisan approach to this issue. We believe, as far as environmental issues are concerned, and certainly as far as the archaeological significance of the early Aboriginal caves are concerned, a bipartisan approach is the only one that will secure long term policies which provide protection and the opportunity for maintenance of the significance of this area.

For those reasons we have decided to support Senator Mason's Bill. However, we found that the Bill had shortcomings in some respects. To overcome those shortcomings I foreshadow that at the Committee stage we will move two amendments. I say briefly that the purpose of the first amendment is to allow for a plan of management to be implemented in the wilderness area. Without this amendment Senator Mason's Bill would prohibit any access by anybody into the wilderness area. We are quite convinced of the importance of having management plans implemented within such areas. I refer, for example, to the success of the national park management plan in the Kakadu National Park which is, I believe, a national park of astounding beauty where wilderness aspects are properly conserved and developed with the operation of a management plan.

The second amendment provides powers for the Commonwealth to take action to enforce the Act. I understand that that fits in with what Senator Mason is trying to achieve. Senator Mason and the Federal Australian Labor Party are trying to achieve a long term permanent protection of an areas which is of immense value not only to our nation and our region but also to the world cultural heritage. I hope that Government senators will find it within their abilities to support this Bill. I hope that during the debate we will hear that the sound work of the Senate Committee has borne fruit in changing the view of some honourable senators who were previously convinced that the hydro-electric proposal was an appropriate one for Tasmania. It is not. It would be a tragedy if it were proceeded with. As I have pointed out, there are other ways of assisting the economy. We believe that at this stage the primary responsibility of the Commonwealth Government is to fulfil its obligations under the international convention and to take proper legislative steps for the protection of the South West Tasmanian region.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to express my position in relation to the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982. I have some sympathy with this Bill. When Australia became a signatory to the World Heritage Convention it obviously indicated an intention to abide by the provisions of that Convention, and so it should. It has nominated the west Tasmanian wilderness national parks for inclusion in the World Heritage List. As such, it has identified such areas as a natural resource, a natural heritage of world significance. Again, as such, it accepts certain responibilities under the Convention. I refer to article IV of the Convention which accepts a responsibility for the protection, conservation, preservation and transmission to future generations of that natural heritage. Having said that, I understand from media reports that the Government has the matter currently under consideration. Furthermore, I trust that the Government would wish to take into account the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania which was brought down only this week. I do not know what the Government proposes to do. But the passing of this Bill is only one of the alternatives that are open to it. I say in passing that there are a number of technical deficiencies in this Bill which will be covered, I understand, by the Minister for Education ( Senator Peter Baume). Apart from those deficiencies of form, I believe that a number of options are open to the Government of which this is only one. It may, for example, in the spirit of co-operative federalism, seek to negotiate with Tasmania a management scheme and offer compensation for loss of land use. In such circumstances, this Bill would not be the appropriate way in which to act. It may decide by regulation pursuant to section 69 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act to regulate to give effect to the Convention. As the Senate would know, that Act specifically gives power to regulate to give effect to this specific Convention. In such circumstances, of course, this Act would be unecessary. Alternatively, as a third option, it might move to an acquisition, in which case there is potential for this to become truly a national park. In those circumstances this Bill would again be an inappropriate way in which to act. Therefore, I do not think that the passing of this Bill at the moment provides the best course of action for the Senate to adopt even if it is correct in form. I believe the correct procedure in the best interests of all parties is to await the Government's decision and that this Bill be deferred. If the Australian Democrats are not prepared to hold it over, I would, at this time for the reasons I have mentioned, vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill introduced by Senator Mason entitled:

SPEECH.PARA: A Bill for an Act to give effect to the Convention for the protection of the world culture and national heritage.

I ought to say at the outset that I agree with Senator Hill that there are various methods by which the Commonwealth might seek to ensure that the South West of Tasmania did not have the hydro-electric development which is at present proposed. As I say, there are several ways in which the Commonwealth might wish to bring that about. I hope that those ways would always embrace consultation and co-operation with the elected State government of Tasmania. Nevertheless, the Senate has before it this Bill, and it is this Bill to which I direct my remarks.

I believe it ought to be said initially that the Bill probably has a very tenuous constitutional base such as would enable it to succeed a challenge in the High Court of Australia. In particular, one reads in part of the preamble, in other releases and in the report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania on Demand and Supply of Electricity for Tasmania and Other Matters that some reliance is placed on the external affairs power to allow the Commonwealth to use legislative power to enter the field of land use which is normally regarded as the reserve of the States. It seems to me that the possibility of this legislation being based on the external affairs power is based on a very biased reading of the Koowarta decision which decided that the Commonwealth could enact certain provisions of a racial discrimination Act in a way which overrode inconsistent Queensland legislation and administrative action. But the High Court in that case made it very clear that the subject of racial discrimination had become a proper and genuine subject for international co- operation and action. That was evidenced, amongst other things, by international treaties and conventions on racial discrimination.

It is common knowlege, for example, that apartheid is a matter of international concern and action. Therefore, racial discrimination has that status. But the mere existence of an international convention to deal with the preservation of our natural heritage does not of itself give rise to the conclusion that action of this sort envisaged by this Bill arises from a matter of proper and genuine subject for international co-operation. I am quite sure-in this I perhaps disagree with some opinions that have been circulated-that the mere nomination of an area by the national Government would give rise to the head of power. That unilateral action falls far short of demonstrating that the preservation of South West Tasmania is a proper and genuine subject matter for international co- operative action. At the very most, this Bill, if it is relying on the external affairs power, would require a definite action by a multi-lateral body to build up evidence such as the High Court would require. So it is my belief that at the very least, it is only when listing occurs that any Commonwealth external affairs power might be argued to arise.

I find absolutely absurd the idea floated in the report of the Senate Committee that the Lands Acquisition Act could be used. It is absolutely absurd not only on the grounds of cost. How would one cost the acquisition by the Commonwealth of that huge tract of South West Tasmania? How many billions of dollars are tied up in mineral and timber resources and the energy potential of that area? However, putting aside the question of cost, I can tell the Senate now that Tasmania is not up for grabs in the same way as was Louisiana or Alaska. There is no way in which Tasmania is going to allow the Commonwealth to acquire that huge tract of land at whatever price. I am saying quite clearly that we would secede from the Commonwealth rather than let a land acquisition of that scope occur. I accept those arguments which would have to be resolved in the High Court and which are concerned with the constitutional basis of the legislation.

I direct my attention to the Bill itself which purports to carry into effect within Australia in particular Article 4 of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. Article 4 states:

Each State Party to this Convention recognises that the duty of ensuring the identification, protection, conservation, presentation and transmission to future generations of the cultural and natural heritage referred to in Articles 1 and 2 and situated on its territory, belongs primarily to that State.

We find that the objective of presenting the natural heritage of South West Tasmania and ensuring its transmission for presentation to future generations is not provided for adequately in the Democrats' Bill. Therefore, certain very fundamental amendments are proposed by the Australian Labor Party. In other words, we accept the Democrats' Bill as a draft. However, accepting for the purpose of argument that Australia does as a nation signatory to the Convention find itself obliged to carry Article 4 into effect, the Labor Party puts certain amendments forward in order to carry that obligation more adequately into effect .

I believe that the way in which the Democrats' Bill was originally drafted and presented to the chamber evidences their entire failure to appreciate that the debate in Tasmania is not about hydro power per se. Tasmanians are not so obsessed by the generation of pollution-free energy from a continually renewable resource that that takes precedence over all other values, although the attraction of such a method of generating energy is obvious. But for Tasmanians the debate is about jobs-the employment of the hundreds of workers who would be involved in the construction of the Franklin project and the jobs that Tasmanians believe will be made available by the users of electricity in the future.

One may say that Tasmanians have the wrong belief of a link between this project and the creation or maintenance of jobs. That is an arguable proposition . However, I can assure the Senate that any solution offered by this national Parliament which fails to recognise that key crucial issue which is so central to the consciousness of Tasmanians is doomed to failure because that is what explains the resistance of so many Tasmanians to the movement to stop the construction of the dam. It is not a question of resistance to aesthetic values or appreciation of wilderness values. There would be no population in any other area of Australia more aware of natural environmental surroundings than those who live in the most decentralised towns, cities and villages of Tasmania. One can take various indicators, such as the number of bushwalkers and the trout fishing licences, which all testify to the appreciation of and participation by Tasmanians in the beauty of which they are justly proud.

Jobs are the key to the settlement of this issue. If one looks at the current situation one can see why that is so. The October figures on unemployment in Tasmania show that some 18,600 Tasmanians are looking for full time work. That represents some 11.8 per cent of the population. Amongst 15-year-olds to 19-year -olds, 5,800 are looking for jobs at the moment. Those figures do not take into account those who will be leaving school or other educational institutions this year and coming on to the market. That is one indication of the concern which honourable senators can imagine is felt in so many households in Tasmania. That is why, as I said, any carrying into effect of a Commonwealth obligation to prevent this particular hydro-electric development in South West Tasmania must be accompanied by a concurrent plan for the creation and maintenance of jobs in Tasmania.

As I said, the Australian Labor Party opposes this Bill as it is drafted because it does not expressly allow for the types of management and zoning plans for the South West area which we would see as absolutely necessary to have in place in order to allow human activity such as would be appropriate to the integrity of South West Tasmania. It would be intolerable if, as a result of the passage of this Bill, an elitist approach to access to the area were to prevail. It would be equally intolerable if the Tasmanian Government were not a participant in the development of such a management scheme. The Northern Territory and the Queensland State Government, for example, participate in the development of the Kakadu National Park and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. In fact, the policy adopted by the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party in relation to South West Tasmania was announced some two weeks ago. My colleague Senator Ryan adverted to that policy. Amongst other things it states that a Labor Government would:

(5) Encourage the Tasmanian Government in co-operation with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Services to establish a South West Tasmanian Management Authority responsible for the management of the World Heritage area extending to include the entire South West conservation area.

(6) Provide financial assistance for capital and recurrent expenditure by the Authority, including payments to the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service to meet its responsibilities in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —In your amendment you are talking about Commonwealth law.

—We cannot try to produce Tasmanian legislation from this chamber. One thinks of the Kakadu National Park, with its personnel jointly provided by the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth Governments. In short, it would be intolerable if the preservation of this area of natural heritage from the construction of a particular hydro-electric development were to mean the exclusion from the area of other forms of development, particularly tourism, which are compatible with the integrity of the area. I should like to give as an example the management plan of the Kakadu National Park. In that area tourism, commercial fishing, buffalo raising and residences for the Aboriginal and white populations are provided but only after detailed consideration of the effect of any of these human-related activities on the flora, fauna, soil geological formations, water, land reserves and particularly Aboriginal settlements and archeological sites. The net result in the Kakadu National Park area is that a co-operative management plan is worked out which, quite apart from the commercial activity which is taking place there-activity which is compatible with the integrity of the area-provides some 20 000 visitors a year with access and facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Commonwealth itself is not to support the construction of the dam because of certain international obligations it believes it has taken on, I see a very real and concrete obligation on the Commonwealth to provide Tasmanians with an assurance that a co-operative management plan will be developed for the South West of Tasmania which will provide construction jobs in the area by providing access facilities to the tens of thousands of Australians and overseas visitors who we are told would wish to visit the area. Then it needs to continue employment opportunities in the running of those facilities. Such a plan would take some years to develop. Here I believe lies the significance of the three- year pause which the Senate Committee has reported could be undertaken without putting Tasmania's economic future in jeopardy, even allowing for a high demand for power in the next decade.

I believe several obligations would fall on the Commonwealth during that three- year pause. Firstly, there should be the development of such a co-operative management plan as I have outlined and as the Labor Party's amendment to this Bill will provide. Secondly, there ought to be the provision of funds equivalent to the expenditure on the Franklin Dam for other construction-related activities throughout Tasmania. If the dam went ahead the next three years would see an expenditure on the project of some $80m in real terms. That is largely payable by way of wages and salaries to Tasmanians directly or indirectly working on or supplying the project. That $80m would be spent by those employees in support of themselves and/or their families, again largely within the Tasmanian economy. Any Commonwealth decision which effectively withdraws that spending power from the Tasmanian community must take into account the devastating impact that will have on the already very high unemployment rates that I have outlined to this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a good lawyer.

—Well, maybe. I repeat: To implement the three-year pause so as to make this Bill in any way acceptable to the Tasmanian community, the rest of Australia which is adamantly opposed to the dam must accept the fiscal responsibility flowing from that stance. That is the position of the Australian Labor Party in relation to this Bill. If it be thought that the national Parliament has some obligation arising out of the listing, should that occur-and it has not yet-of the South West Tasmania wilderness area on the World Heritage List, and should it be held that this Parliament has the constitutional authority to enter the field of land management use in Tasmania, legislation such as this might be appropriate. I believe it is seriously defective until amended in the way in which the Labor Party has indicated to allow for human activity compatible with the area to take place, and moreover, human activity of an employment-generating kind. If the Bill is so amended, its implementation could be undertaken with the fullest co-operation of the State Government, as has occurred in the case of other great national parks in Australia such as Kakadu and the Great Barrier Reef. It is only on that basis that I find myself able to support an amended Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —No one who has just listened to Senator Tate's speech can fail to understand the dilemma which must face any Australian Labor Party senator from Tasmania. The honourable senator's speech set out with some force all the reasons why he should not support the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982. Both Senator Tate and Senator Ryan were having a bit each way. Senator Tate has questioned some of the constitutional basis for the Bill. Senator Tate set out some of the problems of the constitutional basis on which the Bill rests. He has questioned the cost of acquisition. He has questioned the appropriateness of the use of the Lands Acquisition Act. Of course, he should vote against the Bill. Anyone who listened to his speech would conclude that Senator Tate should be voting against the passage of this Bill for the reasons which he set out and articulated. But being a member of the Labor Party Caucus he is in fact going to support the Bill. I invite anyone from Tasmania who listened to what he said to look at how he votes and to put the two together.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, Senator Ryan set out very clearly the views of the Federal ALP. By way of interjection I asked her whether those were the views of the Tasmanian ALP. She did not take up the interjection. Let us not forget that it was under the Australian Labor Party that the dam was conceived, that the project was initiated. It was under the Australian Labor Party that the legislation was introduced into the Tasmanian Parliament. I suspect that the views of the Labor Party in Tasmania do not match those of its Federal counterpart. Having said that, this Bill is not just about South West Tasmania. It is a Bill which considers every area which has been listed or presented for inclusion in the World Heritage List. It is a Bill which affects every part of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nominated.

—Every part which has been nominated, as Senator Harradine says. The Bill purports to give effect to the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage in Australia. That is an international treaty which Australia ratified in 1974. That Convention imposes certain obligations on each signatory party concerning a number of matters- identification, protection, conservation, presentation and transmission to future generations. That is what the Convention provides. It affects those properties situated on its territory which form part of the world cultural and natural heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Bill is promoted by Senator Mason for its political value in relation to South West Tasmania it is suggested, and I suggest, that honourable senators should address themselves to the wider implications of this Bill, to what it can mean. I start by saying that the need for this legislation is doubtful. Legislation already exists in Australia which has the capacity to protect places nominated for the World Heritage List. The inference of this Bill is that there is neither adequate legislation at Commonwealth or State level nor willingness on the part of governments to fulfil the obligations arising under the Convention. Commonwealth legislation is available. The available legislation includes the Australian Heritage Commission Act establishing the Register of the National Estate; the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act; and the legislative framework for the protection of Kakadu National Park. Those pieces of legislation exist already. The States have their legislation covering national parks and the protection of the natural and cultural heritage.

The Bill does not provide any power in relation to the Convention greater than could be available through existing Commonwealth legislation-for example, section 69 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act provides for the Governor-General to make regulations for and in relation to giving effect to various specified international agreements, including the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. That Act is in place. That power and capacity exists. There would be little doubt that the Commonwealth already has some constitutional power to enact provisions-perhaps those which this Bill covers, although Senator Tate has put some question upon whether that power really exists. As indicated, it may require resolution eventually in the courts.

Having said that and recognising that Australia has a federal system of government, the mere existence of legal power is not of itself a good reason for Commonwealth action on any issue unless that action is necessary. In many issues the responsibilities are more properly left to the States to administer. The States and Territories would almost certainly view this Bill as an unwarranted intrusion into matters that they consider to be their primary responsibility. The acceptance of this responsibility is implicit in their recommendation to the Commonwealth of properties for nomination under the Convention, with all of its obligations. It is the States which have nominated to the Commonwealth areas which should be nominated for inclusion in this World Heritage List.

The Bill provides that any person at all may bring proceedings to the Federal Court of Australia for an order declaring that an action is a breach of this Bill and seek an order to remedy or restrain a breach of the legislation. I would like to concentrate for a moment upon that point-the fact that any person may bring proceedings to the Federal Court. There is the possibility, of course, that there could be frivolous or vexatious applications to the court but apart from this the unrestricted conferring of standing before the courts could lead to pressure for similar provisions to be inserted in other Commonwealth, State or Territory legislation. The provision of standing under this legislation is very wide and I believe will not make for practical application of any Bill that is passed.

The Commonwealth's long-standing legal policy is, to put it in broad terms, that a plaintiff must show that he has a special interest over and above that possessed by an ordinary member of the public or that a plaintiff is likely to suffer damage over and above that which is likely to be suffered by an ordinary member of the public before he or she has standing in any matter. This Bill sets aside that long-standing policy and gives the very widest standing. The Attorney -General (Senator Durack) has referred the general question of standing to the Law Reform Commission for inquiry and report. The question of who should have standing is a difficult one. The Commonwealth is waiting for a report from the Law Reform Commission and Commonwealth policy in relation to standing will be reviewed when the Commission's report is received. That is not expected for some months but honourable senators should be aware that what is being proposed under this legislation is contrary to existing policy, is much wider than the standing that has generally been given and is likely to be inappropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could be dragged before the court by somebody from California, Moscow or Timbuktu.

—By anyone; anyone could be dragged before a court if any area is nominated. As this legislation seems to be drafted, someone from the tip of Cape York could drag before a court someone who has a property in Perth. The Bill would implement its intention by making it unlawful to do any act or take any action which is likely adversely to affect a property that has been nominated for or included in the World Heritage List. It does not have to be included; it just has to be nominated. This aspect could give rise to a volume of litigation in that the words 'adversely to affect' are not defined in the Bill. They are capable of a very broad interpretation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills examined this proposed piece of legislation and remarked on the 'very little identification of the scope of unlawful actions' which were included and also commented on the ' absence of any list of specific offences.' Surely Senator Mason should be concerned that his colleagues in the Senate have criticised his Bill for those shortcomings. He does not seem to be concerned. But surely he should be concerned that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills also drew attention to clause 6 and noted that this might be regarded as trespassing unduly on the personal rights and liberties of citizens. Surely that should be of concern to the honourable senator. Surely he should be concerned that legislation he is putting up is criticised in this way by a committee of the Senate. I certainly hope that he can indicate that he has taken actions to correct the drafting of this inadequate legislation to take account of and to overcome the objections from what is regarded as a dispassionate all party committee which has criticised his Bill. As it stands, and as it has been criticised, the Bill can properly be described as draconian in some of its provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a heritage Bill trampling on the heritage of our civil rights.

—I acknowledge the interjection of my colleague Senator Harradine. The Australian Labor Party has proposed some amendments to the Bill put forward by Senator Mason. These amendments seek to exclude actions, which might otherwise under the Bill be unlawful, where these are authorised by a zoning or management plan made under the provisions of-I ask honourable senators to listen to this-the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act or other Commonwealth legislation. The amendments would also impose an obligation on the Minister to bring proceedings in the court if the Minister believes on reasonable grounds that a breach of the legislation has taken, is taking or will take place.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look for a moment at the ALP amendments. The ALP amendment that exempts actions made in accordance with management and zoning plans would not cover management and zoning plans developed under State legislation for the management of areas in that State. The amendment refers only to Commonwealth legislation as making certain things lawful. Therefore, if this piece of legislation were enacted, actions proposed in accord with management and zoning plans developed under State legislation would be unlawful. For example, a maintenance access track within the Cradle Mountain-Lake St Clair National Park would be unlawful even though it was otherwise made in accordance with approved plans for the management of that area. What a ridiculous piece of proposed legislation this is . It is badly drafted and full of holes. I am surprised that Senator Mason is not ashamed of it, with this kind of consequence to flow from it. It does not apply just to south Tasmania; those deficiencies apply to the Bill wherever it has application throughout Australia.

The obligation of the Minister to bring proceedings-which involves the other amendment by the Labor Party-in the absence of what constitutes what might be called reasonable grounds places an enormous burden on Ministers. But it must be apparent to honourable senators that this Bill, if enacted, would make it extremely unlikely that any State or Territory, knowing that this legislation existed, would ever make a further recommendation of properties for nomination to the World Heritage List. Senator Mason could be now bequeathing to Australia the end of any further nominations to the World Heritage List, because no State in its right mind would want to place itself under this kind of legislation. If that is what he is out to do then he should proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will be embarrassed if Malcolm announces this tomorrow. Your face will be very red.

—While the Commonwealth is not required to receive recommendations to the World Heritage List from the States and the Territories, it has been the practice that the Commonwealth and the States work co- operatively to develop nominations to the World Heritage List. I say to Senator Chipp that I am merely pointing out the errors in the drafting, composition and construction of a Bill that has been presented in all seriousness to the Senate for consideration. Indeed, we know that South West Tasmania is the interest that people have here, and we know that it was nominated for inclusion in the World Heritage List by Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: There are so many implications for Commonwealth-State relationships arising from intrusion by the Commonwealth into areas which are traditionally areas of responsibility of the States that this Bill should not be supported. It is unthinkable that Senator Mason, a senator for New South Wales, could take action such as this which would make it almost impossible for another Government of New South Wales to want to nominate any other area to the list. The Bill is directed at the situation in South West Tasmania, but there are other existing means of achieving the purposes which he and his colleagues wish to achieve. While we cannot support the Bill for a number of technical reasons, which I have set out, it is not an adequate piece of legislation in the form in which it has come to the Senate.

Let me make it clear that the Government recognises that it has obligations concerning properties which form part of the world cultural and natural heritage . The Government will continue to advance, through consultative mechanisms such as ministerial councils and ad hoc arrangements, the development of a co- operative approach with the States in identifying and protecting the nation's heritage. I have indicated some of the deficiencies in this legislation. We think that it should not proceed. In the event that the Senate chooses to pass it, the situation will arise where the Senate will have passed a piece of poor legislation full of errors and producing effects which I do not think were the effects that Senator Mason was seeking to achieve. In that case, the House of Representatives would have to carry out a review role and put its mind to reviewing what is a piece of inadequate legislation presented to it from a Senate which has not considered the legislation to an adequate extent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to Senator Peter Baume who, of course, is a Minister. I would be fascinated to know whether the thrust of what he had to say was approved by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I would have thought that the tone of Senator Baume's address and his lack of enthusiasm for the content or the meaning of Senator Mason's World Heritage Properties Protection Bill were certainly not shared by the Prime Minister. I have some sympathy for the situation in which the Prime Minister now finds himself. I believe-I do not have to tell the Senate that I am not, never have been and never will be an apologist for the Prime Minister, but I do give him credit where it is due-on this issue his views are similar to those of the Australian Democrats and members of the Australian Labor Party. I am sure that the Prime Minister wants to save this act of wanton criminal vandalism being perpetrated on one of the most beautiful areas of the world. The Prime Minister knows, through the courtesy of Dr Norman Sanders, the Australian Democrats representative in the-
—Do you say that we are a third rate State?
—I can do without the help of Senator Harradine, and I want him to know that. It would suit me if he left the chamber.

—I raise a point of order. Senator Chipp said that the Prime Minister had been advised through the courtesy of Dr Norman Sanders about the situation in Tasmania. My point of order is that that statement is totally incorrect.
—There is no point of order.

—Senator Harradine knows full well that there is no point of order . Notwithstanding his lack of many talents, at least he knows the Standing Orders of the Senate. He knows that all he has succeeded in doing is interruping my speech. I will not dwell on a remark that Senator Harradine made to my Whip a couple of hours ago when in a most statesmanlike comment Senator Harradine said: 'If you bring this House back next week I will not vote for anything the Democrats want until the end of the session'.
—That is not so.

—What sort of a man is it who will sit in this place and prostitute the vote he has in this place for reasons such as that? He said: 'If you bring me back next week I will not support anything the Labor Party or the Democrats want'.
—Order! I ask Senator Chipp to direct his attention to the Bill which is before the Senate at the moment. I ask Senator Harradine to stop interjecting.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, are you saying that if Senator Harradine was heard to give the reason that he would not vote for any Democrat initiative because we voted to make the Senate sit next week that that is not relevant to this Bill? Is that your ruling?
—I just asked you to direct your remarks more towards the Bill than towards Senator Harradine.

—I would be delighted if Senator Harradine assisted me by leaving the chamber and listening to my remarks in his office. It would make the atmosphere here, as far as I am concerned, a great deal more comfortable.
—Do you say that we are a third rate State?
—Order! I ask Senator Harradine to cease interjecting.
—I was in the middle of saying that my esteemed colleague, Senator -I am sorry-Dr Norman Sanders-
—He will never be a senator.

—If Senator Harradine wants to put a bit of money on that I will be glad to accommodate him. Senator-elect, Dr Norman Sanders has, by his intrepid flights over this area in which this vandalism is being perpetrated by the Premier of Tasmania, produced photographs which show the present devastation being created to this beautiful wilderness. I know that the Prime Minister has been informed of this. I know that he is looking for some sort of a formula whereby this wilderness can be saved. Unhappily, because of the extreme remarks of Mr Gray, he has painted himself into a political corner from which he is finding it very hard to manoeuvre. The foolish remarks made by the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) further embarrassed the Prime Minister. I am worried that so much time will elapse that the bulldozers of the vandals will have done their work. Unless we can get some action to save the Franklin River and its environs before the end of summer, it will be too late. I have colour photographs which I have shown to many honourable senators which depict what the Hydro-Electric Commission has done in the short space of four or five weeks. The extent of the damage that it has caused is almost unbelievable. A fire has got out of control and 2,300 litres of oil has been lost in the Gordon River.
—That is untrue.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, are you going to control this person behind me or do I have to deal with him again? Can you not induce him to go into his little corner and lie down?
—Senator, you have not raised a matter on which I can rule.

—This Bill will achieve the intention of the Federal Government in that it will give teeth to its intention to nominate the Franklin River for world heritage listing. If the Bill is passed by the Senate today that timing will enable further assistance to be given to the Prime Minister to make the kind of decision that I know he wants to make. Mr Gray has to be allowed to save face. The only way in which he can save face is to be offered some form of compensation. I am sure that that compensation can be forthcoming from the Prime Minister but some sort of pressure has to be exerted in regard to the present situation. About two months ago I moved an urgency motion in this place and every Labor, Liberal and National Party member of the Senate voted against it. That urgency motion was to the effect that this Senate should express concern at the vandalism being carried out.
—That was before the Senate Select Committee report.

—Perchance I jumped the gun; maybe I was premature. As Senator Tate says, it was before the Senate Select Committee report came down and that was a quite proper reason given by honourable senators on both sides for not supporting that motion. But now that report is down; it was brought down on Tuesday afternoon. I do not know that people can plead that proper opportunity has not been given to study its implications. That excuse can no longer be made. I want very briefly to refer to a couple of issues that have been raised. I am interested in the suddenly appearing consuming interest in this issue exhibited by Senators Crichton-Browne and Martyr. It is interesting that two Western Australians should put themselves down to speak in this debate for half an hour and quarter of an hour respectively. Clearly this debate will be talked out this afternoon.
—Why?
—If the honourable senator knew the plans of those on the other side, he would see that a Liberal Party filibuster is well on the way. It has been well organised.
—We talked for well under our time. We are not trying to filibuster you. We talked for only 15 minutes.

—I am not suggesting that the Minister is. The States rights issue will be raised. I do not object to people talking about States rights. I have had some experience with people who have raised that issue. I have held eight or nine or ten portfolios during my parliamentary career and have chaired several ministerial councils, as referred to by Senator Peter Baume. I was a Minister for a period longer than Senator Baume has been a Minister so far. No doubt he has chaired some ministerial councils.
—Half a dozen, at least.
—Half a dozen would have told him--
—Not chaired, but attended.

—If he has been to that many ministerial councils, he would know of the almost pathetic attitude of some State Ministers who sit around a table and discuss with their Federal counterpart and State counterparts a certain proposition, whether it be in relation to mining, forestry, drug control, crime control or whatever. I have been associated with all those matters. Ministers sit round the table. The officers of the various governments would have met the day before and an agenda would have been arranged. An unanswerable case would be put to those ministerial councils that, for the good of Australia, certain States rights ought to be released and transferred to the Commonwealth. In those situations the Commonwealth Minister, whether, for example, it be the Minister for Education or the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will consult with his Cabinet and will get some authority to negotiate. If the States are to give up some of their rights, they will need some compensation or whatever. I have sat at many of those ministerial councils where unanswerable cases for the national good, for States rights to be even temporarily forgone have been put to those councils. These pathetic little men with their pathetic little advisers say: ' Don't give up these States rights to that nasty, centralist Federal Government'. The good of Australians or the national interest is just totally subsumed in this pathetic, almost criminal, retention of these States rights that these little men hang onto. This is exactly what we are seeing in Tasmania at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Do the States rightists say that the question of drilling for oil on the Great Barrier Reef should be the sole prerogative of Mr Bjelke-Petersen? If they want to continue their ridiculous States rights reasoning that far, let them say that . Or will they be Democrats and say that a State has the right provided it has a referendum? If the populations of Katherine, Darwin and Alice Springs have a referendum and get a 51 per cent vote to send bulldozers into Ayers Rock to crush it up for road gravel to build a road from Alice Springs to Darwin, will these people say that that project should proceed because this precious States rights authority should be retained? What an absurd proposition that is! The Tasmanian South West wilderness is in the same category as the Kakadu National Park, the Great Barrier Reef and Ayers Rock. It is a world asset not just a Tasmanian asset.

TALK.START.PARA: —You support our amendments then?

—Absolutely. We thank the Australian Labor Party for them. We believe that the Labor Party amendments improve the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill. Unless this Parliament moves soon on this question, it will be too late. If this Bill is passed today or next week, the political scenario would then be as follows: The House of Representatives will resume on 8 December -in about two weeks time. If the conservationists in Australia, those people who believe that the Franklin River ought to be saved, write letters to every Liberal back bencher in the House of Representatives pleading with them to support this Bill and to make representations to Mr Malcolm Fraser-I suggest that they do not waste any more shot and shell on other Ministers, with great respect to them, because the final decision in this matter will be made by Mr Malcolm Fraser-I believe that we will then have a chance of saving the Franklin River. But the rapidity and the ruthless, incredible efficiency with with the Hydro-Electricity Commission is moving into this beautiful wilderness and destroying all before it have to be seen to be believed.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I believe that there is something else that can be done. For those people who are voting in the Flinders by-election on Saturday week, for whatever political party they vote-it is not my wish in this speech to try to influence them on that decision-here is a magnificent opportunity to do a write- in. One was organised in the Lowe by-election and an amazing number of people in that outer suburban area of Sydney, approximately 12 per cent of all voters, wrote 'No dams' on their ballot papers and then voted for the political party of their choice. In the ACT House of Assembly elections something like 40 per cent of people wrote 'No dams' on their ballot paper. Again, the timing of the Flinders by-election with regard to saving the Franklin River is exquisite. If we can get something like a 15 per cent to 20 per cent write-in of 'No dams' on ballot papers recording votes in the Flinders by-election that would be another factor that could assist Mr Fraser in making up his mind. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to support the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill and to support the amendments which have been foreshadowed by my colleague Senator Ryan. I agree with Senator Chipp that the amendments improve the Bill. It would have had very substantial defects relating to the use of national heritage areas of Australia if those amendments were not adopted. We are involved in a debate which has been long standing and will be long standing into the future about the dichotomy of views on conservation and development.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to look briefly at the respective merits of the arguments which seem to me to apply in relation to those two issues in the instant case which has been discussed in the course of the debate on this legislation. I am very disappointed with Senator Peter Baume's contribution to the debate. What he was really saying was: 'Look, there are a number of technical objections to this Bill', as if there are not technical objectives to all Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are quite substantial, though.

—I follow that. If the will and the concern were there to do something about the issues raised by the Australian Democrats in this Bill the Government-as any responsible group of senators in this House is entitled to do- would have moved amendments to improve the legislation further. Of course, as Senator Baume pointed out the Government in the House of Representatives or members of the House of Representatives will have opportunities to improve the legislation if that is necessary. It seemed to me that the substance of his remarks was to ask for an adjournment on the real issues involved and to say: ' Look, there are technical objections to this piece of legislation and therefore we should not pass it, having regard to the high standards we have in this chamber on technical matters'. I understand him in a sense seeking an adjournment in dealing with the real issues in the way in which he did. But I regard it as unfortunate that the Government should adopt that attitude to what is an important piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: With my very incomplete knowledge of the conservation aspect on South West Tasmania, I accept the views which the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania advanced at page 222 of its report. It states:
The Committee accepts the views of these experts that the archaeological discoveries near the Franklin River are of . . . importance-

The Committee stated that in its view the ecological value of the area was of such national and international significance as to be consistent with the nomination of the area for the World Heritage List. It went on:
The Commonwealth may well be obliged to act to preserve the area and has a considerable number of powers and options open to it to enable it to meet that responsibility.
The report goes on to deal with Commonwealth responsibilities.

What concerns me is the alternatives to the conservation of the South West Tasmania region; that is, the development of it by the construction of a dam. The unfortunate point about the debate concerning development is the fact that the building of the Franklin dam has been portrayed as a suggested solution to enormous problems in the Tasmanian economy-very real problems about which all honourable senators should be concerned. That argument is advanced as a type of Trojan horse. If a dam is built, some time perhaps in the 1990s, Tasmania, because of low energy prices, will attract industries, and many of the problems which are now endemic in Tasmania, particularly unemployment problems, will be resolved. That is a simplistic view which seems to me to be quite wrong. I say that in no spirit of antagonism to those who hold the view, but it seems to me to be totally misconceived. If we look at what is happening to Australian industry generally, the sort of industries which might appropriately be attracted to Tasmania and the decline in demand for energy in Tasmania at present, we will see that that argument does not stand up and that Tasmania in the 1990s is most unlikely to seek the sort of energy production which the dam involves. That seems to be the essence of the argument which we have to meet. I have to say, because of the tone of the debate and interjections that have been made by Senator Harradine and others, that whilst it is all very well to say that Tasmania and Tasmanians are entitled to make decisions about these matters, we have responsibility as a Parliament to pass Budgets and to deal with taxpayers' money.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tax recoupment Bills, too.

—Yes. We supported those, as the honourable senator will recall. We have responsibilities in relation to those matters. I must say in relation to Premier Gray of Tasmania that I find it extraordinary for him to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The dam won't cost Australian taxpayers anything.

It is true that the Hydro-Electric Commission has to borrow on the market in order to build the dam, but if the projected power is not needed by the 1990s or cannot be sold profitably Tasmania would not be able to pay the bill for the dam and would not be able to repay, without Commonwealth assistance, the enormous amounts of money which would have to be borrowed. It would then be for the Federal Government-that means Australian taxpayers on the mainland as well as in Tasmania-to service the loans to keep the Tasmanian economy afloat. There is nothing new about that statement. I say it with no disrespect to Tasmania, but it is the most obvious mendicant State in Australia. Tasmania, per head of population, has relatively enormous receipts of Commonwealth revenue to assist its economy and to try to deal with many of its problems. That, of course, is within the knowledge of all honourable senators. I have no objection to that. I feel that Commonwealth money coming from mainland taxpayers can be well spent for that purpose. One of the functions of this Parliament is to ensure that as far as possible equitable economic conditions exist in each State of the Commonwealth, but that involves a large expenditure of taxpayers' money in respect of Tasmania. To that extent we have a very real interest in the loan arrangements for the dam and as to how those loans are to be serviced and repaid . The second remark which Mr Gray made is this:
Mainlanders should keep their fingers out of Tasmania's affairs.

I find that an extraordinary contribution to what should be a serious debate because the same Mr Gray is constantly visiting Melbourne, where I as a taxpayer live, and Sydney, where Senator Mason as a taxpayer lives, drumming up support for Tasmania, imploring mainland investors to save Tasmania from economic stagnation and inviting them in those ways to contribute to the Tasmanian economy. He is, of course, as a responsible Premier, putting forward the same sort of case on behalf of his State at Premiers Conferences. He does not then say that mainlanders should keep their fingers out of Tasmania's affairs. His whole campaign, recently, illustrated in his numerous public pronouncements, has been based on the notion of the mainlanders being hostile to Tasmania in some way, yet being called upon to rescue the Tasmamian economy. In February of this year he said:
A Liberal Government will get $500 million investment into Tasmania by Christmas 1982.

His concern is again illustrated by that statement, which has led to a degree of extremism in the debate about South West Tasmania, particularly when he refers to people who express passionate concern about the building of the dam as traitors and Third World guerrillas.

I support the legislation. I wanted to indicate in general terms why I do so and to raise one other issue, that is, the question of Commonwealth-State relations which Senator Chipp dealt with and which I, in a sense, have dealt with in the context of the support which this Parliament has to give to Tasmania on an ongoing basis. I think it is in the same category as Senator Peter Baume's technical objections to this legislation to say that the Commonwealth Parliament has no right to interfere in these matters and should leave all of these questions to State governments. Senator Chipp points out that we did not do that with the Great Barrier Reef and, as Senator Peter Baume, a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, ought to know, this Parliament has not done that in relation to Aboriginal matters. Indeed, consequent upon the referendum of 1967, additional powers were given to this Parliament in relation to Aboriginal affairs. If today, throughout Australia, we had a referendum on the question of South West Tasmania, I believe it would be carried in every State except Tasmania. Senator Crichton-Browne, with his intimate knowledge of Western Australia, shakes his head. So I retract and say that it would be carried in every State except Tasmania and Western Australia, where Senator Crichton-Browne 's views appear to reign supreme. The important point is that such a referendum would be carried, and one would not want to have one.

The point I am making is simply that Australians, wherever they live, have a legitimate right to be concerned about an issue of this kind. Governments have an obvious responsibility to be concerned about an issue of this kind and I believe it to be in that spirit that the Australian Democrats' Bill was brought into the Senate and it was in that spirit that the Opposition moved its amendments to the Bill because they seemed to be sensible additions to the legislation. I do not see it as being a responsible attitude to say that this is wrong in terms of some technicalities and therefore the Senate should never pass it because what people in the Australian community are concerned about are attitudes to this very fundamental issue. I hope the Senate will adopt the Bill as amended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982 is a heritage Bill only in the sense that it will trample on our heritage of rights and civil liberties. I reject totally the statement made by Senator Chipp that I am voting against matters brought by the Australian Democrats into this chamber from now until the end of the session because of the fact that we are meeting next week. That is not the situation with regard to this Bill. It certainly will not be the situation so far as one Bill is concerned which will probably come up for debate next week. I refer to the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Bill. I will make one point perfectly clear; I thought I explained it during the previous debate. One of the consequences of the Senate's sitting next week is that I now will be unable to engage in discussions with the people who were important for my consideration of the forthcoming education legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the measure before us, namely, the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982. Why do I say that this Bill is a heritage Bill only in that it will trample on our heritage of rights and civil liberties? Negatively, that is so. It has been pointed out by the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Senator Peter Baume) that if this Bill goes through, there will be no Premier of any State who will be prepared to nominate any area or object of his State for inclusion on the list of the World Heritage Commission. The provisions of this Bill are absolutely draconian. The stated aim of the Bill is:
. . . to ensure that South-West Tasmania would be saved for future generations in accordance with Australia's obligations under the World Heritage Convention.

That aim is not included in the Bill itself. It is the stated aim of the Bill as expressed by Senator Mason in his second reading speech. The question of responsibility and the process of determining what the current generation wants and what the future generation may want is central to any democratic form of government. I suppose that it is central to any form of government. Governments exist to make those decisions and to determine those issues.

Apart from that question, the Bill raises grave issues with regard to civil liberties. It raises the fundamental question of whether our affairs should be determined by a direction dreamt up by the World Heritage Committee in Paris. The Bill, as has been admitted around the chamber, is probably the most open- ended and confusing legislation that has ever been introduced into the Federal Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even by Senator Mason?

—Senator Mason, by inference, recognises that by saying that he will cop all the Australian Labor Party amendments which, in fact, do an asset stripping job on the Bill. In short, the Bill permits any person to haul before the Federal Court another person who acts, or proposes to act, in a way that is likely adversely to affect the protection or even the rehabilitation of something which has been included on a list submitted by the Federal Government to a Committee in Paris. Does the person who makes the complaint have to be an Australian citizen? The answer is no; there is nothing in the Bill to suggest that such a person has to be an Australian citizen. Does the potential villain need to have done something wrong? Again, the answer is no; the Bill makes that person liable even if he intends to do something wrong. What if he breaches an order of the Federal Court? He will go to prison or be fined. What is the penalty? There is no penalty under this legislation save, of course, for one of the worst penalties in the book-that is, for comtempt of court. The penalty under those circumstances is open-ended. See what I mean about trampling on the heritage of our civil rights and liberties. Where are the civil libertarians?
—The Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee pointed out that it trespassed on the rights of people.

—Exactly. So the penalty is open-ended. It is a trampling on our heritage and civil liberties. The person who is able to set all of this in train need not be an Australian citizen. The person who drags the Australian citizen-the Tasmanian elector, or whoever it is-before the Federal Court need not be an Australian citizen but could conceivably be--
—An Eskimo.

—An Eskimo or a resident of California, Moscow or London. This may be merely because a government, not necessarily the current Government, but any future government, places an area-or, for that matter, a painting, an inscription or a group of buildings-on a list posted to a committee located at the Place de Fontenoy in Paris. The World Heritage Committee is a sub-committee of a committee of the United Nations. The ordinary citizen is quite powerless to vote its officials out of office, much less influence what it decides. Is this not a ludicrous situation with which we are faced in the Senate today? The Senate is supposed to be--
—A States' House.

—A States' House. We can become too worked up about that; nevertheless it should represent the interests of the States. I object very strongly to the fact that the proposer of this legislation, the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Mason, and Senator Chipp today quite deliberately refused to dissociate themselves from the statements made by their representative in Tasmania that that State is a banana republic and a third-rate State. Senator Tate made a valiant effort to defend the Labor Party's situation in regard to this Bill.
—He thinks it is a terrible Bill.

—Of course he thinks it is a terrible Bill. As the Minister indicated, one need only listen to the contribution made by Senator Tate to be influenced to vote against the legislation, even as it is proposed to be amended by the ALP. I give full credit to Senator Tate. His legal training obviously enables him to take a brief on a matter about which he is not convinced. But all that is needed is his vote to defeat this legislation. I would hope that he and other senators from Tasmania, as well as honourable senators in this chamber who are concerned about the need for the Senate to protect the rights of the States, would also vote against this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Many attacks have been launched against Mr Gray, the Premier of Tasmania. I do not agree with Mr Gray on quite a large number of issues. But let us not forget that the proposed development in the South West was adopted by both houses of parliament in Tasmania with only three dissentient voters. Are all members of the Tasmanian Parliament troglodytes or barbarians? Do they not have to live with the situation in Tasmania? Do they not understand what is occurring or the environmental benefit of South West Tasmania? Numerous inquiries have been carried out in respect of this area. A watchdog parliamentary committee has been established. Statements made in the Senate regarding the leakage of oil are simply not in accordance with the facts of the situation.

I say in conclusion that I have only recently received a copy of the amendments foreshadowed by the Australian Labor Party. Senator Tate indicated what a horrific thing it would be to utilise the land acquisition powers for the purposes for which this Bill was designed. I agree with him. The honourable senator adverted to the cost to the Commonwealth of such a proposal. I also agree with him in that regard. But what is being proposed in the amendment is virtually the same thing as is being proposed in the Bill but without compensation. To suggest that the Australian Labor Party's amendments will improve things very much is to stretch imagination to its very limits. The amendments, in part, read:
Nothing . . . shall render it unlawful for a person to to do any act or take any action which is expressly or impliedly authorised by a zoning plan that has come into operation under-
Certain Commonwealth Acts are then set out. The section continues:
or any such zoning plan or management plan as may be provided under a law of the Commonwealth, including a law in respect of South West Tasmania.

That is putting the gun at the head of the whole of the Parliament of Tasmania. It is saying quite bluntly that if we pass this heritage Bill provision will be made for the Commonwealth legislature to enact a zoning plan. Of course, no provision has been made for a veto power by the State concerned. This sort of legislation could affect my State today or the States of Western Australia and New South Wales tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —No provision for a Tasmanian management plan either.

—That is right. As the Minister says, most plans, of course, are set in place under State law, not under Commonwealth law.
