The Australian Labor Party's amendment to the Bill does nothing to alleviate my fears of the draconian nature of the measure and its aspect of trampling on the heritage of our rights and civil liberties. It is doing that by reason of the nomination of the area to a committee in Paris. If we agree to that we are shedding our responsibilities not only as a State in this Federation, not only as a House of the Parliament-the Senate-but also as a nation. I urge all honourable senators to vote against this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall, under duress, be brief. I say from the outset that I do not like the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982. I will not support it. I will vote against it. In my view it is the sort of Bill that represents everything I am opposed to as a States righter and as somebody from Western Australia. As I look at this legislation I am drawn to the conclusion that the sea of sand that separates us from the rest of the country is the only reason that the eastern States have not had their sticky fingers on Western Australia. That is something for which I am forever grateful. Senator Chipp said that a puerile, pathetic and poor argument had been put forward about States' rights and that this had nothing to do with States' rights. In my view this Bill, as much as any other principle, is a matter of States' rights. This is an issue of States' rights.

SPEECH.PARA: What an absurd proposition it is to suggest that all wisdom resides in Canberra , that all knowledge and all wisdom resides in this building and that the members of Parliament-the House of Representatives and the Senate-have a greater knowledge, greater wisdom, greater judgment and greater capacity to make decisions of this type than the people of the various States and the various State parliaments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the others must be pretty crook.

—Yes, that would be right too if that proposition were correct. It is very much like saying that all wisdom resides with one judge in a court. That is why there is more than one judge. It seems to me that in the short time I have been in this Parliament I have heard nothing from the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party particularly in respect of legal matters. We have heard these puerile claims that the State members of Parliament are inadequate, incompetent, inefficient, insensitive and unable to understand--
—They want to get rid of the State parliaments.

—The Australian Democrats are on record as saying that they would abolish State parliaments. Mr Hawke is on record as saying he would abolish the States House as I recall. Mr Hayden said that he would abolish the Senate. It is the same thing. If you abolish the Senate you abolish the States' House. There seems to be some misguided concept amongst some honourable senators opposite that all wisdom resides here. It is interesting how they are all equal in their own States. It is just a question of the luck of the draw as to whether a person gets an endorsement for the Senate, the House of Representatives or the Upper or Lower House in the State from which that person comes. We have all been through that process. Suddenly, once honourable senators opposite arrive here they feel they have a superior knowledge that overwhelms, overcomes and imposes itself far above that of the poor plebeians who seek to make judgments and laws in respect of their own States.

SPEECH.PARA: As long as I have been in the Senate I have noticed that State governments and State politicians have been treated as minors, mendicants and second class citizens. As I said, frankly that is not the view that members of parliament take when they go back to their own States and when they go before their own State councils for preselection. The States and the members of the State parliaments more than anybody else ought to be sensitive, and conscious and ought to be aware of the need, the wishes, the ambitions and the aspirations of the people in their own States. If they make a mistake they are ignominiously removed from office in a very short time. I would have thought that they would be the best judges of the consequences of their decisions. They are very mindful of the needs and the wishes of their States. Primarily, they are concerned only with their own States. They are best able to make judgments on the balances between conservation and development and growth and the stifling of growth. They are accountable to their voters.

As long as I have been a member of the Liberal Party, particularly the Liberal Party of Western Australia, I have always understood one of its basic tenets to be a belief in the devolution of power away from Canberra, not towards it. This is another of those classic centralist pieces of legislation which are so enthusiastically embraced by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. It flies in the face of everything that I have ever supported as a Liberal. It seems perhaps unnecessary to remind ourselves that this Parliament had powers vested in it as a result of the original States coming together in the first place to hand over certain specific powers clearly written into the Constitution, the residual powers remaining in the hands of the States. It is a very poor excuse to use the external affairs powers to surreptitiously undermine the fundamental intentions of those powers to provide a capacity to introduce this type of legislation. I am very much opposed to it.

I am always interested to note that in referendums on these sorts of issues the people in Canberra overwhelmingly support decisions in Tasmania or elsewhere. I suspect that a great majority of the people in Canberra are civil servants who would probably get lost once they went past Queanbeyan. I wonder how many of them have been to Tasmania to enable them to make these sorts of judgments. I wonder how many of them have been to Western Australia to see its magnificent countryside and to decide whether people in that State have the capacity and the sensitivity to distinguish among growth, development and conservation. I have no doubt that were there a referendum in Australia as to whether the Federal Parliament ought to have power to introduce this sort of legislation it would be overwhelmingly defeated not only in Western Australia, Tasmania and Queensland but also in many other States.

I note with some fascination that very often the difference between conservation and development is the difference between the haves and the have- nots. With due respect, I am referring not to those in this Parliament who are making such determinations but to the community at large. Those who seek employment or who have employment in growth industries very rarely are the ones who call for conservation. It usually comes from those people who are secure on middle income salaries which they draw as a result of somebody else's profits, endeavours or capacity or who are drawing on the taxpayers for their form of income. Invariably we find that those who seek to make their own way in life rely on their own capacity and that those who rely on those sorts of people for employment oppose these sorts of proposals. I conclude by saying, as I said at the outset, that I am opposed to the proposition. It is the sort of legislation that would have no support whatsoever in Western Australia. I would rue the day when this sort of proposition was ever put in any part of Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleagues in the Australian Labor Party , I support the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill and will vote accordingly. Equally, like my colleagues I make it clear that I regard the Bill in its present form as something of an unworkable hodgepodge. My support for it is conditional on an acceptance by its proponents and by a majority of the Senate of the amendments that we have proposed.
—That has been conceded.

—I acknowledge that that has been conceded, but a number of the criticisms made in the course of this debate have been directed at the Bill in its primary terms rather than to it as it is proposed to be amended. That point has to be acknowledged. I think one has to accept that the Bill in its present form not only denies the opportunity for the rational development of tourist roads and of other aspects of the area but also will probably go so far as to deny the average bushwalker the right to urinate behind a tree. That said, I think the only contribution that I want to make to this debate is one that is motivated by some comments on the Commonwealth's constitutional power and, in particular, the external affairs power to support legislation of this kind.
—Comments made by whom? Senator Tate?

—Comments that have been made by others in this debate and in particular by my colleague Senator Tate. A variety of powers with potential application to support legislation of this kind has been canvassed-the trade and commerce power, various financial powers, the implied nationhood power of the Commonwealth and so on. But it is clear that primary reliance is being placed on the external affairs power in the text of this legislation; that certainly is the particular power that has attracted the most lively comment in this and other contexts. I think it is clear that there is a great deal of wishful thinking evident in a lot of circles around this country since the Koowarta case about the scope of the external affairs power. It is certainly true, as my colleague Senator Tate very cogently pointed out, that mere participation by Australia in some treaty or the mere taking of action by Australia under some treaty to which it is a party cannot itself necessarily give the support necessary constitutionally for legislation which purports to give domestic force and effect to Australia's treaty obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: But that said, I think it is appropriate perhaps to give a slightly different emphasis from that given by Senator Tate and those commentators who may share his perception of how all this works, to the significance, in the context of the world heritage issue, of Australia making a nomination of an area, on the one hand, and on the other, securing the actual listing of that area on the World Heritage List. I understood Senator Tate to say-indeed, I have heard a number of other people make this point-that the nomination itself is likely to be of no particular constitutional significance at all, but the listing of the area or any other area on the World Heritage List, with the multilateral international recognition that this would imply, would be of real significance in giving constitutional support to this legislation. I simply say that I am not so clear that that is an appropriate dichotomy to identify in this area; I am not at all sure that things are as clear cut or as simple as that.

What seems to be the test after the Koowarta case is that the subject matter in question be such as to have the capacity to affect Australia's international reputation or Australia's international relations. It may be that even the listing of a particular subject area on something like a World Heritage is insufficient to make it an issue of international importance so far as Australia 's reputation, standing and relations are concerned. Alternatively, it may be that the mere nomination of an area to put it on such an international list would be sufficient in all the circumstances to evidence the international status that that area enjoys and give it the characteristic of being a subject matter upon which the international reputation of Australia might depend.

I think if anything is clear in all this rather muddy debate about the scope of the external affairs power, it is two things. First, that it is not necessary to have a treaty for any particular subject matter to be international in character for the purposes of attracting the external affairs power jurisdiction; there may be some subject matter that is not the subject of a treaty but which nonetheless is manifestly international in character in the sense that Australia 's reputation is at stake in anything it does in relation to that area. Secondly , it is clear that if we have a treaty that is not necessarily the end of the matter at all; the mere existence of a treaty does not necessarily give it the force and character of being international in status as a result. What matters is whether the action or inaction on the matter is such as to be likely to affect Australia's international relations.

When one looks at the kind of subject areas which might satisfy this description the question becomes very interesting. It is clear now, in the light of the Koowarta case if not before, that racial discrimination is a subject area that is properly international in character and in which Australia's performance is likely to affect our reputation and international relations. It is almost as clear that human rights matters generally satisfy that description in this modern age. The question that has to be resolved in the context of the present debate is whether the protection of a nation's cultural and natural heritage is these days such an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —And world heritage.

—Indeed. Maybe one can refine it further and refer to the protection of a nation's cultural and natural heritage in areas that are of potential universal significance. That may be another way of describing and narrowing the issue and the argument. I simply want to say that while I acknowledge that there is room for doubt in this area-certainly the issue is not nearly as clear-cut as it is for racial discrimination and human rights; one has to be a real constitutional optimist to suggest otherwise-I believe that the external affairs power, quite apart from other possible heads of power-I do not want to go into that in the short time available tonight-probably is good enough to support this legislation. I further believe that it is strongly arguable in the context of South West Tasmania that the mere nomination of South West Tasmania in this international treaty forum is enough to evidence the status of that particular area as being a proper subject for Commonwealth legislation under the external affairs power.

SPEECH.PARA: The elements of the agreement are as follows. What we have, in the first place, is a multilateral treaty in place which is manifestly not a mere device, not a put up job to serve the domestic interests of one or other of the parties to it. It is a multilateral treaty on a subject matter, it appears, of genuine, to that extent, international concern. Secondly, we have a situation where the Commonwealth has clear-cut obligations under that treaty to protect areas which are of outstanding universal value even without those areas being listed formally on the World Heritage List. That is perfectly clear by any reading of articles 4 and 5 of the Convention and the definition of natural heritage.

It is further clear, as we all know, that the Commonwealth has nominated the area of South West Tasmania for world listing as being of outstanding universal value. No one has seriously suggested that in so nominating South West Tasmania the Commonwealth has acted other than in good faith in implementing its obligations and the opportunities open to it under the international treaty. It is nonsensical to claim, as a number of senators have claimed, that if we take this view about South West Tasmania assuming international status by virtue of the Commonwealth's nominating it in this treaty forum, we are opening the door for the Commonwealth to identify some sleazy part of inner suburban Melbourne equally as an area of international heritage significance, thus opening the door for some manifestly absurd exercise of the Commonwealth's legislative power. I simply do not think that follows. There is a good faith element in all these sorts of applications of constitutional law in this area and there does not seem to be any serious suggestion that good faith has been lacking in this particular case.

Finally, in this chain of reasoning there are plenty of reasons for supposing that international attention would be attracted and serious adverse reaction guaranteed if this area of Tasmanian wilderness thus nominated were to be destroyed. The preservation of the South West seems to me to be the kind of issue about which it can be claimed that Australia's international reputation and standing are at stake. If this is so, then neither the formal nomination, nor ultimate listing, is particularly crucial. The nomination is simply the process by which the Commonwealth has identified in good faith an area as possibly coming within that description of something of international significance so far as its beauty and other characteristics are concerned.

The only other point I wish to make is that all of this argument has, of course , a larger relevance than just in the purely technical context of the scope and operation of the external affairs power. It is the case that the Tasmanian south -west is an area of international significance. As such, the whole question, I suggest, ought to be approached with a rather larger spirit than has been shown by a number of contributors to this debate here this evening. Of course Tasmania 's economic problems are acute and alarming, and of course it is that concern that has motivated most of the resistence within Tasmania, and perhaps also in this chamber, to the kinds of concepts and thoughts embedded in this legislation . But it is not nearly so obvious that those economic ills and that anguish of Tasmania will be corrected by this particular Franklin dam project.

In the absence of any clear-cut demonstration that the State's economic ills will be resolved by this project-in fact the evidence strongly suggests the contrary-it seems to me that there is very little justification for the wallowing in parochialism that we have heard from so many of the contributors to this debate. The concept of wounded State pride and injured State feeling that has gone into the contributions of so many of the opponents of this legislation, both from Tasmania and from elsewhere, seems to be misconceived when what is in issue is an area manifestly of the national and international significance of south-western Tasmania. The kind of hostility with which those who have defended this legislation have been treated by the opponents of the Bill seems to me to do no justice to the genuineness of those who hold very strong views about the desirability of protecting South West Tasmania, nor does it acknowledge the very real force of their argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am totally opposed to Senator Mason' s World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982 and to the Oppositions amendments. I do not think that there would be anything left in the world which would surprise Senator Evans. There are some things that he has said, though, that surpise me. For instance, I am very surprised that he, as an eminent lawyer , would have nothing to say about the construction and the drafting of this Bill . I should have thought that the Minister for Education, Senator Peter Baume, had made it very plain that this legislation was ill-conceived and badly drafted and therefore, if it happened to be passed, it would be very bad law indeed, wanting almost immediately amendments to make it workable.

SPEECH.PARA: Just in passing, I wonder whether, in the most friendly of ways, I could pass on to Senator Mason some advice that Senator Withers passed on to me a long time ago. It was quite simple. He said: 'Remember this: There are more people who have talked their way out of this place than ever talked their way into it'. It seems to me that that advice might well be profitably and charitably passed on to Senator Mason now. After all, how much bread, money or better living conditions would this Bill put into the mouths or hands of his constituents in New South Wales? I do not think that they would be terribly interested in legislation of this kind. I think that they are expecting something different from Senator Mason. But that is my opinion. He ought to know best how to handle his own constituency.

It seems to me that Senator Harradine and Senator Crichton-Browne have already suggested, very strongly and wisely, that these world heritage concepts are world government concepts and that they cut across very strongly what should be well established boundaries of interest and jurisdiction. I cannot see that this Federation of the Commonwealth and the sovereign States can live peacefully together if the Commonwealth is to interfere in such detail with the basic affairs of the States. I am certain that there will be many more disturbances in the State of South Australia between Mr Bannon and various people with whom he does not seem to get on if the Australian Labor Party persists in supporting Bills of this nature. The States will not put up with that.

I am certain also that in Western Australia and Queensland we have a very deep sympathy for the present Tasmanian Government which finds itself so sorely beset by members of this Commonwealth Parliament who ought to be attending to their own basic problems in their own parties and assisting us to get the best results in this chamber. Heaven knows, they talk about these subjects in their matters of public importance day after day. We will have the same sort of ridiculous litany of matters of public importance next week concerning the problems of this Commonwealth. Why should honourable senators opposite want to interfere in the affairs of the States when they ought to be applying themselves more appropriately to the matters that concern this Commonwealth?

Senator Baume's speech made very clear indeed the problems that Senator Mason's Bill-which, as I said, is ill-conceived-will cause if it becomes law. I think Senator Baume properly suggested that it was hardly a serious Bill. If one looks at what has happened during this debate it is quite plain that Senator Mason does regard this as a serious Bill. Of course, the Australian Labor Party supports it. Anything that breaks down the authority of the States will be supported by members of the Labor Party. Their record on these matters is very clear. When the Labor Government was in office it tried unsuccessfully to break down the essential relationship between the States and the municipal governments -the cities and so on-within those States. The Labor Party brought forward a plan for regional authorities which was designed to upset the relationship with the State governments and their municipal authorities, to cut across the State government boundaries and to go directly to the regions. That is centralism at its worst. That is one of the bad aspects of Senator Mason's Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Directly responsible to Canberra.

—As Senator Kilgariff, who is a Territorian, would know, the Northern Territory cannot be run from Canberra. This is why the Northern Territory is moving steadily towards a total self-government of its own. When the Territory has that self-government, it will not want Canberra to interfere so intimately in its affairs. I recollect that Mr Paul Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, has had plenty to say about that subject in recent times. I thank Senator Kilgariff for the interjection. It has given me the opportunity to include the Northern Territory with Western Australia and Queensland. Members from those States are prepared to speak quite authoritatively and honestly for State rights. I appreciate that. I see that Senator Harradine is also trying to assist me. I thank him for that.
—Assist you to talk the Bill out so that a vote will not be taken tonight.
—That is a most uncharitable remark. It may even be a compliment to my capacity to talk rather longer than I had intended.
—You could talk under the Franklin River.

—My colleague can talk about the mussels under the Port Melbourne pier but I must not be diverted any more by these interjections. It is important for us in this chamber to remember that Senator Mason's Bill is directly related to the problems and the issue of South West Tasmania. That is just another mechanism to obtain cheap publicity for the ill-considered views of small groups of conservationists who are very vociferous and who are determined to get their own way at all costs. Already we have seen the failure of governments in Tasmania because of the ill-considered actions of these small groups of conservationists. Clear evidence has been presented to me--
—What small groups of conservationists?
—I have seen photographs, sketches and propaganda which are demonstrably false.
—Fifteen thousand walked down Melbourne's streets. Do you call that a small group?

—It is all right for Senator Chipp to talk about vociferous activities. I congratulate Senator Chipp and all the other people who are involved in this campaign. They have built an enormous bushfire out of the flame of a match. Earlier Senator Chipp said that Dr Norman Sanders had flown over the area. But those flights are nothing to the flights of fancy that this chamber has heard from Senator Chipp. This has been a most remarkable performance. I pay tribute to Senator Chipp's capacity to organise these things-he understands this -for his own quite proper political purposes. That is what this democracy is about. But Senator Chipp and those who support him have to realise that there is a strong group of people in this community who do not blow their bags and who sit quietly and look at these things. Senator Chipp's followers imagine that they have almost a total right-almost a dictatorship, if you like-to impose their views on this community. A very big group-I submit that it is a much larger group than Senator Chipp and his followers know about-is totally opposed to all of these wild activities. These people can see where it is going to lead. They can see that it will lead to a breakdown of the essential areas of authority of this Commonwealth Government and its relationship with the States.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is an utterly disgraceful situation when a small group can hold up the whole development of a State by mobilising opinion outside that State. It is a most remarkable but still disgraceful state of affairs. If this mechanism is allowed to continue to flourish and to prosper, we will have enormous difficulties with all of the States. I have already flagged the opinion of many in Western Australia. I am supported by my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne from Western Australia. I know Senator MacGibbon feels the same way and we have heard from Senator Kilgariff as well as Senator Harradine, who certainly represents a very strong proportion of the people in Tasmania. These people are very concerned about what is happening and they will have memories when the next Senate election comes around.

Senator Chipp's remarks were interesting. He has mentioned before that States rights are an issue. That is something that he ought to appreciate because he is here as a senator representing Victoria. As I said before about Senator Mason, I cannot see how these activities are directly related to the function of a senator from his State. I cannot see how a senator from Victoria can involve himself in the affairs of another State when the people in that State are represented adequately or otherwise by their own team of senators. It does seem to me-I offer a personal opinion here-to be almost an impertinence for honourable senators from one State to go into another State and to seek to impose their organised views about the affairs of people within that State.

Will this Senate, founded in the concept of States rights and responsibilities allied with Commonwealth rights and responsibilities, now seek to destroy the very foundation on which it rests? I hope every citizen is listening to what is happening. This debate is not about world heritage; it is about the abandonment of the States to an all-powerful Commonwealth. I am not suggesting that our Government will assume this role of an all-powerful government and destroy the States. The very essence of the Liberal Party's philosophy and policy is against that concept, but as has so often been said before, we may not govern for ever. Of course the Australian Labor Party will support this Bill. It knows that the more States' authority is broken down the more a centralist, specialist, socialist concept will be possible. This Bill is bad. It is ill-drafted and ought to be thrown into the deepest part of the river, along with the ALP amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The River Seine.

—I am reminded by Senator Harradine of the River Seine. The River Seine would be very appropriate. It is a long way from here, it is very deep and it runs into a very deep bay. That would be a very appropriate place to put it. We in Western Australia do not want this sort of interference in our State. I would have to say, with all respect to Senator Mason, that I would not relish the Australian Democrats chances in the next Senate election. He has created this situation and has made it very difficult for his colleagues in Western Australia. I should thank him for this but I do not like to see a good man making a mess of what might be a good job. I think that this World Heritage Properties Protection Bill is essentially bad. It should be rejected by the Senate, and it should be rejected for the right reasons. It cuts across boundaries in a way that legislation should not. It cuts across State boundaries and interferes with that essential relationship that exists between the Commonwealth and the States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I was always opposed to this World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982 but having heard the speakers for it I am now very opposed to it and I find that I cannot contain myself in the face of this heresy. The point at issue is not that the Commonwealth has power to legislate in the area as Senator Evans spent hours trying to tell us. There is no argument that the Commonwealth can legislate in this area if it wants to. The real point is that we should not have to legislate in this area at all; we do not have a need to do so. Therefore, we do not need this Bill. Stripped to its basics there is just a very simple little ploy going on here. The ploy is just one of the things where, if a person does not have a majority position or a position where the majority of the people in the Australian community support him he tries to outflank the whole deal by appealing to a supernational body, in this case the World Heritage Commission, and thus avoid in the process the wishes of the people whom he represents.

SPEECH.PARA: This is one of those paths that we are going down increasingly in Australia on many issues where we are tied into being signatories to overseas bodies and when we do not examine all the consequences of what is involved by signing on the dotted line, let alone looking at how the decisions were arrived at or at the people who arrived at these decisions. The impression somehow is created that all overseas bodies are much more ethical, much more honest, and much more responsible than national bodies. The logic of that escapes me but it is a line that is sold very consistently by people who want to get support for issues for which they do not have support in their own countries. I take the view that the converse is often true, having had quite a bit of experience with overseas bodies. The composition of international organisations is nowhere near comparable with the composition of national bodies. That is not surprising because people only come together for a few days at a time, once a year, once every two years or once every five years. Their internal communications and cohesion is very poor. One always has communication problems through language difficulties and translation and all the rest of it. The intimate meeting of minds for a highly technical or a well reasoned argument is often missing. I am not saying that it cannot be attained but very frequently it is not attained and the broadest of communiques or resumes of meetings are put out because they are the only ones on which people can reach agreement.

I want to speak out against this Bill. I want to speak for Queensland and also for Australia. Quite simply we are involved here with an abdication of Australia 's sovereignty and an abdication of sovereignty held by the individual States. There is no getting away from that point whatsoever. Unlike Senator Mason and members of the Australian Labor Party I just do not have a feeling of inferiority about being an Australian and looking after Australia's affairs. I am proud of the workings of this Parliament and the other parliaments in Australia. I am proud of their achievements and their abilities to reach the right conclusions in certain circumstances. We are a developing society; we are a changing society. We have made mistakes in the past and I promise honourable senators that we will make mistakes in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wouldn't promise that. It would be like the other one.

—Senator Button is a mistake. I am happy to live with those mistakes. I would rather have those mistakes which were occasioned by Australians and not occasioned by a bunch of people living in other countries who are not answerable to the Australian community in any way at all. I say that with some feeling because I have lived a large part of my adult life in other countries. I enjoy and appreciate the achievements of other societies of other countries and I can live in harmony with them. But that does not diminish in any way at all my love and my enthusiasm for Australia and Australian society. I am proud to be able to back the judgment of Australians. I do not see that we have to abrogate that right to someone in New York, in the United Nations building, or anyone else, for matters that go on in our own back yard.
—Particularly in Paris.

—Particularly in Paris. I thank Senator Harradine. What we are dealing with here is a philosophic division between those of us who believe in going our own way and the centralist belief of the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party. We live in Australia in a federation and a federation just happens to be the hardest of all political systems to make work because it means that we have a group of separate sovereign States and we cannot ride over those people in a jackbooted fashion. We have to co-operate, communicate and co- ordinate. In other words, we have to live like adults. I can understand that that would be a bit hard for some people to do. It would be particularly difficult for the Democrats.

—I raise a point of order. We all know what is happening here tonight. It is three minutes to seven. The Bill could come to a conclusion tonight but it is obvious that the Government is filibustering to ensure that it does not get bad publicity. Mr Deputy President, I ask for your guidance as to how we can stop this abortion of the process of the Senate.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Quite frankly, I find that an insulting allegation. It is not worth wasting my time discussing it. I was talking about the Democrats. I do not find it surprising if they wish to abolish the States because they are on record on many occasions as having said that. Senator Mason a year or so ago was talking about the abolition of State governments and the setting up of the old socialist doctrine of regional seats of government or some equivalent shire scheme such as that to administer Australia from some central source. I find that an heretical belief for someone who also holds a seat in the Senate, which is the States House. Ever since federation the sovereignty of the States has been maintained. Indeed, if we had not had a federation we would not have had a Commonwealth of Australia because we had six States that all had a proud and successful history of achievement before 1901.
—We nearly had three in Queensland.

—Yes, we nearly had three and we will have three one day. But the characteristics of the federation are that we have to respect the diversity of human nature, of human achievement and it also relates very well to the geography of Australia, the great distances that are involved and the different regional attitudes that come from having this Federal system. A consequence of that which is lost by people here is that States must, therefore, be different and States can be different. They can quite legally, legitimately and properly have different values as to how they want the societies in their States to be run. It is impossible for Canberra to decide what needs to be done in my own State, in Burketown or Birdsville and it is even less possible for someone in New York or in Paris to make that decision for us. I am prepared to trust people to behave as adults and to be responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: The solution to Senator Mason's problem is to embark on a public awareness campaign to create a heightened awareness of the environment. My respect for the environment and the ecological movement is second to none but what we have already in place through the national parks system is a system which is functionally adequate, which can be upgraded and which can satisfy the needs of the preservation of the environment. In fact, it is only through having the support of the local people, by involving them in things like an enhancement of a national parks program that we will get the environment preserved. Unless people feel a relationship to what is going on locally, unless they feel they have a direct responsibility themselves to that environment they simply will not be concerned about it. The issue of south Tasmania is not the reason that this Bill should be brought in. It is always very bad from a legislative point of view to bring in general legislation to cover one particular point.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd: Aboriginal Development Commission-World Heritage Properties Protection Bill

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd: Aboriginal Development Commission-World Heritage Properties Protection Bill

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: The the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some time last week, Senator McLaren raised the matter of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd and the Aboriginal Development Commission. Yesterday, my office was contacted by the adviser to the Point McLeay Community Council; and, later, one of my staff spoke to a Mr H. J. Rankine, the Chairman of the Point McLeay Community Council. These people contacted my office because they were particularly concerned at some of the statements and allegations which have been made by Senator McLaren over a period of a year or more. They believe that, for some unspecified reason of his own, Senator McLaren is attempting to make some sort of political capital out of the Aboriginal situation in the area. They believe that his attack is scandalous and that it is demoralising them. The community is unhappy because it feels that it has no right of reply. Mr Rankine and others also believe that the community around them is being divided one against the other, black against white, and that the people's-
—Black against black as well.

—Black against black as well and, for all I know, white against white and any other colours in between. The point is that they feel that Senator McLaren's comments are divisive and demoralising, that the Aboriginal community is given no opportunity to rebut them and that they are destroying the confidence of the people who live in the area in the Aboriginal community and also the ability of the Aborigines to control their own destiny. Indeed, they went so far as to say to one of my staff that they believe that he is being generally anti-Aboriginal in standing up for what appears at least the defence of one particular white man.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, I received a particularly long telegram signed by H. J. Rankine J.P., Chairman of the Point McLeay Community Council. I intended to have this telegram incorporated in Hansard in order to save the time of the Senate; but, since Senator McLaren has come into the chamber, I presume that he will want to make some sort of response to my remarks. Since this telegram arrived late and I do not have a copy of it, this means that I will have to read it, as a courtesy to Senator McLaren, and for that reason I apologise to the Senate for keeping it longer than I intended. The telegram is addressed to me and it reads:
Senator Janine Haines
The Senate
Parliament House Canberra

As Chairman of the Point McLeay Community Council and as a representative of the Point McLeay Aboriginal community over the past twenty years I strongly deplore the political antics and ill informed grandstanding on Aboriginal matters by Senator McLaren in the Senate as reported in Hansard dated 17th November 1982. Senator McLaren's views are biased towards a minority faction and certainly do not reflect the beliefs of my Council or that of many Aboriginal people within this community. Senator McLaren's unsubstantiated attacks on hardworking and longserving officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission which he so vigorously castigates are totally unwarranted and certainly divisive in our relationships with these departments. The senator's fervor would be better channelled to more useful purposes than that of headstrong political mudstirring and faction polarisation. The assistance received by my Council from the Aboriginal Development Commission was a direct response to resolutions passed by my Council seeking support in its endeavours to regain control and use of its lease holdings upon which Ralkon Agricultural Co. has continued to occupy in defiance of all previous attempts by my Council to remove a small faction that occupies Council lands to the detriment of the Council and the Aboriginal community as a whole. I particularly bring to your notice that in 1974 I originated the concept of a farming project on Council lands and as a result of this concept the Council negotiated the purchase of Bartletts Farm through the then known ALF Commission (now ADC) to compliment existing Council farm lands. It was never intended that the farm's management be other than as a sub-committee to the Council and under the direct control of the Council for the general benefit of the Point McLeay Aboriginal community. The dispute between the Council and Ralkon Agricultural Co. is of many years standing and is currently the subject of litigation therefore these intrusions by Senator McLaren can only be harmful to the settlement of the dispute. Clarification of many issues now the subject of litigation can be obtained by reading the Commonwealth Ombudsman's report on the dispute and to which document I respectfully refer you.
H. J. RANKINE, J.P., Chairman Point McLeay Community Council

It would appear from the telegram and from the telephone conversations between my staff and people at the Community Council yesterday that there is considerable concern in the community about what has been said in this place over a number of years; that morale at Point McLeay is particularly low; that division is reaching some fairly scandalous sort of peak, from what I understand ; and that the people there would like at least their side of the story put as well, that is what I have attempted to do this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that Senator Haines did not advise me of what she intended to do tonight because I am not fully conversant with what she has said. I will not enter into any prolonged debate on this matter tonight. First of all, I should like to ask who solicited the telegram and I would advise her that Mr Henry Rankine, who is supposed to have signed the telegram, was one of the first people from the Ralkon Agricultural Co . who came to my office some years ago and, as a director, asked me to help that community. I repeat that Mr Rankine was a member of the first delegation and he was, at that time, a director of the Ralkon Agricultural Co.
—Has he asked you to do anything in the last year? He hasn't, has he?
—You can just shut up. You know nothing about this.
—Order! The honourable senator will address the Chair.

—Senator Haines has also read out from a telegram another falsehood about a Commonwealth Ombudsman's report. There is no such report available. Senator Peter Baume could verify this. I have mentioned this in the Parliament many times. When Senator Chaney was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I spoke to Professor Richardson and asked him to make that Ombudsman's report available to Senator Chaney on a confidential basis. I was informed, and I have said this in the Parliament on many occasions, that under the Ombudsman's Act there is no way that Professor Richardson can make that report public. Because of the long delay in the Commonwealth Ombudsman's office in compiling the report, the Ralkon Agricultural Co. wrote and asked that the case be no longer proceeded with. There is no Commonwealth Ombudsman's report.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not enter into a debate on this matter tonight. I will read what Senator Haines has had to say and I will make some further inquiries. When I have read what Senator Haines has had to say, I will have some more to say about this matter. She did mention that Mr Rankine has said that the whole matter ought to be cleared up. It is on the public record-there is an item on the Notice Paper and I referred to the matter last week-that I sought to have a Senate select committee established to inquire into the whole ambit of the problem at Point McLeay. The Australian Democrats would not support that public inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are making the problem.

—I am not making the problem. The honourable senator is not aware of the whole situation. I have a whole file on this problem. I made some parts of it available to Senator Macklin some time ago when I sought his support to have a Senate select committee set up. But as I said, I will not speak at length on this matter tonight. I have spoken at length on it many times. I will be asking Mr Rankine what has brought about his change of mind because, as I said, he was a member of the first deputation which came to my office at Murray Bridge quite a few years ago to ask me to do something to help. What has changed his mind in the meantime I do not know, but I will make some inquiries about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not enter into the matters raised between Senator Haines and Senator McLaren. I think it is proper that Senator Haines has brought this telegram into the Senate . Senator McLaren has indicated that he wants to look at it later and at a later stage we will examine the matter on its merits.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to comment on a remark made by Senator Bolkus just before the adjournment debate. He said that there was an attempt by the Government to talk out Senator Mason's private member's Bill, the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill. I should like to put on record that that is totally without foundation. Senator Bolkus was not present for all the debate. He may not have seen what was going on. The speakers list, as it was settled, contained the names of Senators Ryan, Hill, Tate, Baume and Mason. A number of other senators joined the debate. If the Australian Democrats say that the Government talked the debate out they should do it against the background that Senator Chipp himself added his name to the list of speakers, as did Senators Button, Evans, Harradine, Martyr, Crichton-Browne and MacGibbon. The extra speakers came from all parties represented in the chamber; they came from the Democrats, the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party. The Independent senator was also a speaker. Senator Bolkus may, when he understands that matter, wish to reconsider what was an entirely false and improper accusation made by him.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.11 p.m. until 1.45 p.m. on Tuesday, 30 November 1982.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has the Australian Government taken in the following forums in pursuance of the right of the East Timorese people to self-determination and in pursuance of the right of the human rights of the East Timorese: (a) United Nations General Assembly; (b) United Nations Commission on Human Rights; (c) United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees; and (d) United Nations Childrens Fund.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has taken the following action:

(a) United Nations General Assembly-Australia has participated in debate on resolutions on the situation in East Timor on the UN General Assembly every year since 1975. Australia voted for the resolution adopted in 1975, abstained in 1976 and 1977, and has voted against resolutions introduced since 1978. UN resolutions on East Timor have also been opposed in recent years by the great majority of other countries in the region, including New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, India and Japan.

(b) United Nations Commission on Human Rights-The question of East Timor has not arisen in annual sessions of the Commission on Human Rights, and thus there has been no occasion for Australia to take action there. The Commission has, however, established a working group in disappearances which is currently investigating allegations of disappearances in East Timor among other places. Australia has consistently taken a close interest in the activities of this working group.

(c) United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees-The Office of the UNHCR is a strictly non-political, humanitarian organisation the focus of which is on refugees or displaced persons outside their country or origin. Australia has not pursued the question of East Timor within the UNHCR as it would have been inappropriate to have done so.

(d) United Nations Childrens Fund-UNICEF has undertaken a special assistance project in East Timor which concentrates on health and nutrition programs. The UNICEF representatives in Indonesia visited East Timor in April 1982 in connection with drawing up details of the project. On 28 July 1982, the Australian Government announced it would contribute $250,000 to this project. The Australian Government will continue to give careful consideration to requests for assistance to improve the social and economic well-being of the people of East Timor. UNICEF activities in East Timor are in line with its overall aims of promoting practical projects to assist mothers and children.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many statutory bodies (qangos) are funded by this Department.
(2) What is the title of each body.
(3) Who is in charge of each body and what is that person's salary.
(4) How many staff, permanent and/or casual, are employed within each body.
(5) What is the specific function of each body.
(6) What has been the annual cost, for the past three years to the department operating each body.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The following statutory authorities are within my portfolio:
Australia Japan Foundation.
Australia Centre for International Agricultural Research.
The current (1982) edition of the Commonwealth Government Directory which lists statutory authorities provides the name of the head of the Australia Japan Foundation.
Remuneration of office holders is detailed in the 1982 Review of the Remuneration Tribunal (Tabled in Parliament on 19 August 1982).
Details of expenditure and staff numbers are given each year in the Appropriation Bills Nos 1 and 2.

The Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research has been established within my portfolio since publication of the current edition of the Directory. Details requested in relation to the Centre are as follows:

(a) The Director of the Centre is Professor J. R. McWilliam. His salary was determined by the Remuneration Tribunal Determination Number 12 in its 1982 General Review which set the Director's salary at $49,100. The Director is responsible to the Board of Management of the Centre for the conduct and control of the affairs of the Centre.
(b) There is one permanent staff member, three on loan and applications have been called by advertisement for the filling of five professional scientific positions.
(c) The functions of the Centre are-

(i) to formulate programs and policies with respect to agricultural research for identifying agricultural problems of developing countries; and/or finding solutions to agricultural problems of developing countries;
(ii) to commission agricultural research by persons or institutions in Australia (whether the research is to be conducted in Australia or overseas) in accordance with such programs and policies; and
(iii) to communicate to persons and institutions the results of such agricultural research.
(d) the Centre began operations on 3 June 1982. The expenditure in the financial year 1981-82 was $10,989.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1935) Senator Georges asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister a question without notice concerning the World Disarmament Campaign (WDC).

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following response to that part of the question relating to the funding of WDC:

One of the decisions of the recent United Nations Second Special Session of Disarmament (UNSSOD II) was to launch the World Disarmament Campaign designed to mobilise public opinion world wide. The Australian delegation to the Special Session was an active member of the group which drafted the text on the WDC incorporated into the Final Document of the Session. The Government considers that the WDC can make a contribution in Australia to support existing efforts to inform and to generate public understanding on disarmament issues.

It was decided at UNSSOD II that the United Nations would provide the substance of the information for the Campaign and coordinate its implementation throughout the world. In doing this the United Nations will work closely with governments and non-governmental organisations.

The Second Special Session also decided that the WDC should be funded from within the existing United Nations budget and from voluntary contributions of states and non-governmental organisations. Australia's financial support for the Campaign will be drawn from the substantial contribution made to the regular budget of the United Nations. The Government does not propose to make an additional contribution to UN funds for the WDC, nor will it be providing funds directly to non-governmental organisations for this purpose.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1688) Senator Primmer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What action has been taken by the Department of Foreign Affairs in the interest of Father Brian Gore, currently held in detention in the Philippines? Is the Minister aware that seven Filipino Christians have been similarly held in detention in Davao City since being arrested on the night of 16 January 1982 , amongst them being Leonor Sevilla, who is well known among Victorian Christians for her work amongst the poor in the Philippines? Will the Minister take up with the Filipino authorities in Australia the case of Miss Sevilla and the six others and seek either their early trial or discharge from prison.
In addition to the information I provided on the case of Father Gore, the Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 16 January, Leonor Sevilla, together with six companions (Rolly Trinidad, Puring Trinidad, Hemenegildo Florida, Elias Casilac, Tarcintia Bitar and Lourdes Samson) was detained in San Vincente, Davao del Norte Province. Reportedly the arrests were related to local opposition to Government moves to resettle large numbers of farmers to assist its military operations against the New People's Army organisation. All were transferred to Davao City and, on 22 January, charged with possession of subversive material. Ms Sevilla and five of her companions were also charged with membership of a subversive organisation.

As a result of the filing of a habeas corpus petition by civil liberties groups the seven were flown to Manila on 8 February. The Supreme Court on 9 February gave the defence and prosecution ten days to file their cases. I am informed that the defence lawyers submitted their petition on 19 February and the Solicitor-General submitted his on 20 February. Since the seven were returned to Davao, I understand there have been no developments in the case.

I do not think that, in the circumstances, it would be appropriate for the Australian Government to seek to intervene. The Australian Embassy in Manila follows developments in cases such as these including, where possible, through the lawyers of the persons detained. The Philippine Government is, I believe, aware of the interest in Australia in alleged violations of human rights in the Philippines. As for the Australian Government, it is deeply concerned about violations of human rights wherever they occur. The Government's position on internationally accepted standards of human rights is well known including to the Philippines Government. This position has been reiterated in a number of international fora.
